fields.headline: BA risks Atlantic price war
fields.standfirst:
Airline less likely to jump back into the black with latest round of fare cuts

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: British Airways has quietly cut business class fares to the United States and other international destinations by up to a third, risking a fierce price war with rivals on its most profitable routes.
fields.body:
British Airways has quietly cut business class fares to the United States and other international destinations by up to a third, risking a fierce price war with rivals on its most profitable routes.

A new package of Club World fares covering New York, Seattle, San Francisco, as well as South Africa, Hong Kong, and Japan, was announced in the airline's internal newspaper at the weekend.

The initiative is aimed at "passengers who are able to be flexible with their flight times and can plan journeys in advance". It coincides with figures released by its European rival British Midland showing that business travellers flying from Britain to the United States typically pay double the fares charged on similar journeys departing from the continent.

The new fares are being introduced ahead of this summer's "open skies" discussions with American and British regulators, which could see a sharp increase in competition at Heathrow. This, in turn, is pushing the British carrier towards a merger with its Dutch rival KLM.

However, the move will be seen as a high-risk strategy by new chief executive Rob Eddington since, historically, the airline's transatlantic services have yielded about 80% of BA's profits.

The chairman Lord Marshall and Mr Eddington, who took up his position three weeks ago after the abrupt departure of Bob Ayling in March, have stuck with Mr Ayling's strategy of moving BA up-market, chasing high-margin business passengers with features such as flat beds on long flights and at the same time cutting capacity.

Yet this aggressive round of price cuts comes at a point when annualised fuel costs are already running £140m above budget, according to company insiders, and may incense City analysts who were given no indication of the new price strategy when BA announced its year-end profits just over a week ago.

A consensus in the Square Mile that strong economic conditions and slower capacity growth on transatlantic services would allow BA to bounce back to profit this year - after last year's £244m underlying loss - is now likely to be scrapped.

Profits on transatlantic routes are seen as crucial in covering ongoing losses from BA's European operations, where losses all but doubled to £310m last year. The north Atlantic business made £308m last year, down from £451m a year earlier.

British Midland - which is campaigning for its own transatlantic services from Heathrow - published figures yesterday claiming that transatlantic business passengers can save almost £3,500 on a flight to Los Angeles by departing from Milan rather than Heathrow. It says fares from Britain to the US are up to 207% higher than those from the continent.

"Things have not got any better for the consumer," Sir Michael Bishop, chairman of British Midland, said. "In fact, they have got worse. Given the low exchange rate with the dollar, this should be an opportunity to benefit from more trade and tourism through increased transatlantic air travel."

He added that BA was also squeezing capacity in economy class: "We should not be fooled into thinking that all is rosy just because fares are advertised at £199 return. As everyone knows these are limited in number and subject to various restrictions."

fields.headline: The tango entangled
fields.standfirst:
Maria de Buenos Aires
Peacock Theatre, London *
fields.trailText:
Maria de Buenos Aires
Peacock Theatre, London
*
fields.body:
The British stage premiere of Maria de Buenos Aires should have been an important event. Astor Piazolla called his only stage work, a "tango operita", but it's more than just a conventional operetta spiced with some of Piazolla's unfailingly potent melodies. The composer and his librettist, Horacio Ferrer, used this story of Maria, a kind of Latin-American Lulu, whose rags-to-riches rise and fall is turned into a metaphor for the whole history of the tango itself. The score is a patchwork of narration, songs and instrumental numbers, the whole mixture bound together by Piazzolla's magical invention. First performed in Buenos Aires in 1968, it gave a whole new dimension to the tango.

The version put on by the Covent Garden Festival, the work of the group I Fiamminghi, and imported from Belgium, was such a musical and theatrical travesty that little of the work's power and even less of its dramatic coherence survived. Remorselessly amplifying the band and the voices squeezed all the charm out of Piazzolla's music, and made the text (sung in Spanish) incomprehensible, while the badly danced tangos and preening gestures of the verismo staging credited to Frank van Laecke, bore so little relationship to Ferrer's scenario that anyone without prior knowledge of the score would have been totally lost. It was a desperately disappointing evening.

fields.headline: Blame the neighbours
fields.standfirst:
Five Kinds of Silence
Lyric Theatre, London
**
fields.trailText:
Five Kinds of Silence
Lyric Theatre, London**
fields.body:
Prize-winning radio plays don't automatically make good theatre. And Shelagh Stephenson's sombre study of paternal abuse leaves many questions unanswered when exposed to the merciless examination of live performance. The situation is stark and simple: Janet and Susan, two women in their mid- 30s, shoot at point-blank range the father, Billy, who has sexually tyrannised them since adolescence. Over 80 minutes the play then backtracks to discover the source of Billy's cruelty and his wife's complicity. We learn of Billy's traumatic childhood and of his militaristic craving for order along with his wife's religiosity that leads her to identify with Christ's sufferings: abuse, Stephenson suggests, is a process with roots in the emotional deprivation of parents.

One can't argue with that. But her play is also based on the premise that society turns a blind eye: the fifth silence, beyond that of the characters, belongs to the local community. In the actual presence of the characters, questions arise. Where are the neighbours? Did the daughters never go out to work? The play, is set in the industrial north: not an area renowned for minding its own business.

The play is directed with quiet integrity by Ian Brown and well performed by a strong cast. Tim Pigott-Smith as the soliloquising Billy exudes a manic rectitude, Linda Bassett is his congenitally fearful wife and Gina McKee and Lizzy McInnerny convey the daughters' blank helplessness in the face of psychiatric questioning.

Until July 8. Box office: 020 8741-2311.

fields.headline: Comeback
fields.standfirst:
New acts bolster fortunes of Branson's V2 record label
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The successful reinvention of 1960s star Tom Jones as an icon for a new generation of pop fans has enabled the recently ennobled Richard Branson to refinance his V2 record label.
fields.body:
The successful reinvention of 1960s star Tom Jones as an icon for a new generation of pop fans has enabled the recently ennobled Richard Branson to refinance his V2 record label.

The strong performance of Jones's best selling Reload album is expected to allow Sir Richard to complete a complex refinancing of a US bond issue next week - that will value V2 at about £335m.

Lenders to V2, who include Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Goldman Sachs, are likely to be left with a 25% stake in return for cancelling £93m of debt owed by the company.

Morgan Stanley managed two bond issues that raised £75m in 1998 to allow Sir Richard to return to the music business six years after he sold Virgin Records to Thorn-EMI.

As part of the refinancing Sir Richard says he plans to inject a further £45m for the business to spend on new artists.

Among the record company's biggest selling artists are The Stereophonics, with whom Jones is seen performing, left, at the Brit Awards 2000 in March when he won best British male artist.

In 1991, V2 recorded sales of £35m and losses of £37.9m, but Sir Richard claims losses will fall to £22m in the current year, with sales climbing to £44m.

fields.headline: Corporate baby
fields.standfirst: When your colleagues bring in their new born
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: When your colleagues bring in their new born
fields.body:
The hot question with the Blair baby is not who the Godparents will be or will Tony be emptying the nappies in between trips to the dispatch box, but whether the child will be accompanying his mother in to work for the traditional "Here's one I made earlier" office lap of honour.

Working mothers seem obliged to go through this ritual. Whether truly wanting the litany of fawning praise for the rugrat, or feeling the need to provide a flesh-and-blood sick-note for the time off giving birth, I don't know, but it happens and it happens on a regular basis.

The PM (power mum - or career mother as the press likes to dub them) is forced to do a circuit of the company clutching a warbling bundle in her arms and with an industrial-size nurture pack from Mothercare strapped to her back. As she is not known by sight in most of the departments (communication by email alone) she will often be mistaken for a refugee who somehow slipped past security.

The problem with the baby visit is - for those of us without children - knowing what to say. We can congratulate colleagues on a done deal, we can commiserate when the market drops or a client turns feral. Commenting on the offspring can leave us speechless, though.

A quick survival guide for corporate baby encounters


 Learn a script. The good thing about babies is that they have a lot in common. Coming up with something innovative in the way of comment is not recommended. Flatter its appearance. Aim your remarks at the baby to add sincerity, as in "Hello, beautiful, aren't you gorgeous?"

 Avoid telling the poor harassed mother who has spend nine months carrying the thing and then suffered hours of agony to give birth to it that it looks just like its father. Pick out features that resemble the maternal side.


 The great bonding question to ask the mother is "Does it sleep through the night?" Prepare to look surprised/shocked/sympathetic/impressed when you get the answer.
 Always refer to the child "it" to avoid gender errors. Never rely on clothes-colour assumptions. Blue may mean a boy or a girl.


 Wear a raincoat. Take no notice of the mother's assertion that it is "Not a sicky baby". The comment that invariably follows this is "He/she's never done that before" as you wipe sick stains off your Armani.


 Keep a set of keys handy. Babies love the noise and they act like a rattle. Never allow the baby to take the keys. Phoning a parent to tell them their child may well have swallowed the key to your desk drawer is not the easiest of conversations.


 Never offer to pick the child up. If you do, hold it face-away, claiming it will need to keep sight of its mother. Never place it over your shoulder. Sick-on-back-of-suit-stains may go undetected until you get home.


 Never bounce the baby playfully as this can trigger projectile vomit.


 Support the back of the child's head. The unprepared childless may be shocked to the point of seizure at the impression new-borns can do of having been given a broken neck.
 Never pat the child on the head. This will make its eyes roll like a fruit machine. It will also show you are more at home with dogs than kids.


 Never ask: "What is that rash on its face?"


 Never say "Funny how all new born babies look like William Hague."


 Give a gift but do not offer a new baby money as it will eat it.


 Give a gift that will last. Small clothes tend to be outgrown before they have even got off the premises. A voucher for Guicci or Dolce & Gabbanna is always acceptable.


 Practise the smile you will employ when you study the small bundle of vomit and somebody asks whether you are getting broody. Avoid expressions of horror in response. Phrases like "Ah yes. If only my womb/Bernard's sperm count wasn't...." End the sentence in tears. That should shut them up for good.

SURVIVING WORKPLACE BLUES Depressed? And why shouldn't you be? Work has always been a good place for negative mood enhancement, a sort of instant check-in clinic for depression and paranoia. Office Melancholy is the new stress, a sort of afterburn for all the hurry sickness that always tends to strike when the deadline panic dies down.

O.M. is fighting to get a life outside work and then discovering that you don't have one. It's the angst that develops when your remember your friends are all boring and that hobbies are horrible. It's finally getting home on time to watch EastEnders only to discover that Dirty Den is now forgotten history and even Grant the Grunt has gone awol.

O.M.-INDUCERS: * You didn't get that weight off/join that gym for the millennium and you've just realised you're not going to do it by spring, either. * You did a course in assertiveness but you still keep saying yes to all that extra work. * You went shopping on the net but couldn't work out how to buy anything * The sight of all those grinning teenage Internet squillionaires in the paper each day is making you feel like a very old under-achiever. * You read the Madonna quote that: 'Everyone in England seems to be so well-read and cultured' and realised the last book you got through was 'Bridget Jones's Diary.' * You can't get the hang of down-dressing. * You just heard your own message on your voicemail and realised you sound like a dork with a mask on. * Your boss has been on a course in motivating staff and his/her behaviour towards you all is now so nice that you have nothing to moan about over the cup-a-soup. * You lost interest in Posh and Becks but the newspapers didn't. * You somehow lost the ability to deal with small decisions and crises. Replacing the battery in your electric toothbrush is somehow beyond your stretch as is deciding between a skinny or full-fat latte.

INSTANT PICK-ME-UPS: * Pay a colleague you hate a sincere-sounding compliment * Watch 'Sex In The City' without prejudice. * Your office is terminally drab. Wear something bright to give your brain a colour-boost * Visit a museum or a sex shop during your lunch break * Stick up the picture of Prince Charles wearing the Rasta hat back to front. Know you're not the only person able to make a complete and utter plonker of yourself in public. * Learn a party trick and perform it at work * De-stress your desk. Spend an hour spring-cleaning it, throwing out all the old papers you never read and even sorting through the garbage beneath it. Untangle the phone wire and create a working pen pot - throw out all the dead biros and only keep the ones you like using. * Book another hour in your diary to do all those jobs you hate that you have been putting off. * Forget about the diet - decide to stick to healthy eating, instead. * Exercise raises your mood. Do some desk-bound ones, like lifting both feet together and holding them a few inches off the ground or pulling your stomach in towards your spine and holding the pose for a few seconds. * Learn a useless skill, like yodelling or Morris dancing. * Record a new voice mail message, doing an impression of Daffy Duck * Empty out all your pockets and spend the cash you find on a lottery ticket * Carry dice with you to make all those unimportant decisions. Or flip a coin. * Ring a client up just to say hello, rather than press for business. * Buy a clockwork toy and let it loose on the office floor * Buy a gateau and share it round the office, even though it's nobody's birthday * Talk face-to-face, rather than using E-mails

Or flip a coin. * Ring a client up just to say hello, rather than press for business. * Buy a clockwork toy and let it loose on the office floor * Buy a gateau and share it round the office, even though it's nobody's birthday * Talk face-to-face, rather than using E-mails The hot question with the Blair baby is not who the Godparents will be or will Tony be emptying the nappies in between trips to the dispatch box, but whether the child will be accompanying his mother in to work for the traditional "Here's one I made earlier" office lap of honour. Working mothers seem obliged to go through this ritual. Whether truly wanting the litany of fawning praise for the rugrat, or feeling the need to provide a flesh-and-blood sick-note for the time off giving birth, I don't know, but it happens and it happens on a regular basis. The PM (power mum - or career mother as the press likes to dub them) is forced to do a circuit of the company clutching a warbling bundle in her arms and with an industrial-size nurture pack from Mothercare strapped to her back. As she is not known by sight in most of the departments (communication by email alone) she will often be mistaken for a refugee who somehow slipped past security. The problem with the baby visit is - for those of us without children - knowing what to say. We can congratulate colleagues on a done deal, we can commiserate when the market drops or a client turns feral. Commenting on the offspring can leave us speechless, though. A quick survival guide for corporate baby encounters  Learn a script. The good thing about babies is that they have a lot in common. Coming up with something innovative in the way of comment is not recommended. Flatter its appearance. Aim your remarks at the baby to add sincerity, as in "Hello, beautiful, aren't you gorgeous?"  Avoid telling the poor harassed mother who has spend nine months carrying the thing and then suffered hours of agony to give birth to it that it looks just like its father. Pick out features that resemble the maternal side.  The great bonding question to ask the mother is "Does it sleep through the night?" Prepare to look surprised/shocked/sympathetic/impressed when you get the answer.  Always refer to the child "it" to avoid gender errors. Never rely on clothes-colour assumptions. Blue may mean a boy or a girl.  Wear a raincoat. Take no notice of the mother's assertion that it is "Not a sicky baby". The comment that invariably follows this is "He/she's never done that before" as you wipe sick stains off your Armani.  Keep a set of keys handy. Babies love the noise and they act like a rattle. Never allow the baby to take the keys. Phoning a parent to tell them their child may well have swallowed the key to your desk drawer is not the easiest of conversations.  Never offer to pick the child up. If you do, hold it face-away, claiming it will need to keep sight of its mother. Never place it over your shoulder. Sick-on-back-of-suit-stains may go undetected until you get home.  Never bounce the baby playfully as this can trigger projectile vomit.  Support the back of the child's head. The unprepared childless may be shocked to the point of seizure at the impression new-borns can do of having been given a broken neck.  Never pat the child on the head. This will make its eyes roll like a fruit machine. It will also show you are more at home with dogs than kids.  Never ask: "What is that rash on its face?"  Never say "Funny how all new born babies look like William Hague."  Give a gift but do not offer a new baby money as it will eat it.  Give a gift that will last. Small clothes tend to be outgrown before they have even got off the premises. A voucher for Guicci or Dolce & Gabbanna is always acceptable.  Practise the smile you will employ when you study the small bundle of vomit and somebody asks whether you are getting broody. Avoid expressions of horror in response. Phrases like "Ah yes. If only my womb/Bernard's sperm count wasn't...." End the sentence in tears. That should shut them up for good.

fields.headline: Nicholas Hodges
fields.standfirst:
Purcell Room, London
***
fields.trailText:
Purcell Room, London
***
fields.body:
Nicolas Hodges's recitals always boldly go where few other pianists dare. He has made a huge range of contemporary piano music his personal fiefdom and he delivers it with an accuracy and an energy that sometimes defies belief.

Every one of the works in his Purcell Room programme was a premiere. He gave the first performance of Justin Connolly's rather impacted Sonatina No 2, its nine short movements reflecting references from Greek and Egyptian mythology. He introduced to this country a very 60s sub- Stockhausen piece by Konrad Boehmer, and a glistening pair of recent miniatures by Elliott Carter. He also gave London audiences the first chance to hear Salvatore Sciarrino's Two Nocturnes, and the final chapter of Michael Finnissy's latest gargantuan piano cycle.

Etched Bright with Sunlight is designated as the fifth book of Finnissy's The History of Photography in Sound. The use of the word photography, says the composer, "is designed to question 'music' (sound) as Art as distinct from the 'truth' of life - as photographed." So in this half-hour piece musical quotations are embedded in Finnissy's swirlingly complex writing: the main theme of the Love Scene from Berlioz's Romeo and Juliette is glimpsed through dense swathes of chords; a north African melody is heard, one of Bach's potent bass lines underpins gritty counterpoint.

Hodges delivered the welter of notes with wonderful clarity, and he was equally assured in the very different worlds of Sciarrino and Carter. Carter's Two Diversions are each concerned with a different kind of musical contrast - a steady pace set against a constantly changing one, one line accelerating against a line slowing down. The effect is never formulaic but exhilarating, as so much late Carter is.

fields.body:
Kicked out by Blair

This weeks' planned launch of the Football Foundation has been delayed - because Tony Blair didn't want the people's game spoiling his image as a weighty statesman. The unveiling of the new grant-making body, to which the Premier League will contribute five per cent of its lucrative television deal, was scheduled to take place on Tuesday. However, Tuesday is the Prime Minister's first full day back at work after his 'holiday mode' paternity leave. It seems Blair's advisers thought pictures of him kicking a ball around as his first public engagement upon returning to the political frontline after 'Leo leave' might attract adverse media comment, and decided that the PM was too busy to attend. 'There are so many important issues in the PM's in-tray - elitism, Northern Ireland, Sierra Leone - that doing a football event might have looked frivolous,' explained a source. The Foundation, which will dole out between £20m and £50m a year to improve the game's grassroots, will now be launched in July - with or without the world's biggest Newcastle United fan.

Out to grass

Wembley will boost grassroots sport by carving up their famous turf and giving 30,000 chunks to local football and rugby league clubs and charities to use in fundraising. Any club that is affiliated to the Football Association, or the British Amateur Rugby League Association, or any charity registered with the Charity Commission, can apply for a piece of the surface - which has contributed to countless sporting dramas - free of charge from Wembley Stadium and QXL.com. Each bit comes complete with a certificate of authenticity. To bag a chunk to raise funds for your club, call 0800 314151 or visit www.wembley-endofanera.com, before 30 June.

Keegan: coach, pundit, superstar

Yesterday's wafer-thin 'controversy' drummed up by one newspaper over Kevin Keegan's decision to become an ITV pundit at Euro 2000 once England have been knocked out was a little late. Keegan was announced as part of the network's tournament team at their Euro 2000 launch weeks ago, with no ensuing hullabaloo. But in the event of England not making the final, Keegan will also be contributing regularly to Sportal, the sports website behind that amusing spoof 'pregnancy' Euro 2000 ad on television featuring a joyous England coach proclaiming 'it's a ball!' (pictured). 'If his team don't go all the way, Kevin will tell Sportal users how the tournament went for England, what their plans are for the future and who he thinks will win Euro 2000.' Start sharpening those excuses, Kevin.

So much for football clubs' new-found 'interest' in what their fans think. A dedicated QPR season ticket-holder - who just happens to be a senior executive in the BBC's sports department - and two fellow Loftus Road veterans have just moved their seats after the club refused to act against two foul-mouthed morons who sit nearby in the South Africa Road stand. 'This pair of annoying idiots shout all the time, use the same tedious phrases over and over again, use profane language against every opposition player in sight and continually lambast all referees as useless. It's hugely irritating,' explains the disgruntled Rs fan. 'This has been going on for two years. Yet despite repeated complaints by us and others, all the stewards have done is have the odd quiet word, which hasn't changed anything.' fields.headline: Northants revived and kicking
fields.standfirst:
Lancashire 187-6
Northants 191-3
Northants won by seven wickets
fields.trailText:
Lancashire 187-6

Northants 191-3

Northants won by seven wickets
fields.body:
Northamptonshire donned their maroon Doc Marten boots, made locally, and gave Lancashire a sound kicking yesterday to end a dismal run of four successive defeats. Their first win over this opposition here since 1974 was also a first defeat of the season for last year's champions.

The Steelbacks had only passed 140 once before in the National League this season, and as they had the disadvantage of batting second in Midlands gloom on a slow pitch, the locals were not unduly optimistic.

But when their batting comes together it does so effectively and quite menacingly. Mal Loye, who has emerged from last year's doldrums, charmed 61 while Jeff Cook, 28, played with the aplomb, confidence and power of an Australian - no surprise then that he was born in Sydney. He completed his seven-year qualification period this year and, if he continues to perform like this, the wait will have been worthwhile.

David Sales saw them home with an unbeaten 51 off only 53 balls. He looked very pleased with some of his stroke play, pausing hand on hip to admire a particularly well executed drive. Inspired, he flat-batted Glen Chapple to the midwicket boundary two balls later.

John Crawley juggled his bowlers around but was without the injured Peter Martin and neither Ian Austin, jogging in like a man wearing some dodgy kitten heels, or any of the other stalwarts could stem the flow. The Lancashire fielders were as sprightly as ever, led by Warren Hegg, but they just couldn't get through to the fragile tail.

Earlier, the Northants bowling was notable for the return of Jason Brown. It is one thing to be forgotten by your country (as Devon Malcolm, Mike Watkinson, Crawley, Neil Fairbrother, Hegg and Graeme Swan can attest), but quite another to be forgotten by your county. Brown took four for 26 on his Sunday league debut three years ago, but hasn't played another game since.

Still, he took any excitement in his stride. His two for 32 could have been three for less. He would have had Watkinson caught on the boundary had Malcolm not drifted in from the rope; Watkinson rubbed salt in the wound by heaving him for another six in his next over. Hegg had a brief biff at the end but Lancashire's innings was held together by Fairbrother who nurdled and winked his way to another one-day 50, but to no avail.

fields.headline: Tudor stops last-wicket heroics
fields.standfirst:
Surrey 333 & 142
Hampshire 210 & 263
Surrey win by 2 runs
fields.trailText:
Surrey 333 & 142

Hampshire 210 & 263

Surrey win by 2 runs
fields.body:
As Dmitri Mascarenhas's top-edged pull soared towards Mars, Alex Tudor steadied himself, held his nerve, pouched the return catch, then sped off on a lap of honour that might have finished in Hyde Park had his team-mates not hauled him down and smothered him in grateful kisses. For Hampshire, so close to one of the most heroic wins in championship history, anti-climax could scarcely have been more acute.

When Mascarenhas was joined by the last man, Simon Francis, six overs after lunch, the target was strictly notional. While Shane Warne remained, swatting a lacklustre Saqlain Mushtaq to all parts, a Hampshire triumph was not impossible. But now he had gone, caught and bowled by the Pakistani the ball after reaching a feisty 50.

There were 93 to get and Adam Hollioake could call on four Test bowlers. Yet the pair refused to be cowed, still less to offer a chance.

Gordon Greenidge, one of Hampshire's most renowned old boys, was fabled for his ability to bat better on one leg than two; now Mascarenhas, the only Dmitri to play first-class cricket but noted mostly for his capacity to squander an enviable talent, emulated him.

Making light of a pulled hamstring, though leaving the running to Jason Laney, he mixed judicious defence with some meaty clumps that gradually turned the champions' strut - so apparent as they reduced the visitors to 87 for six - into a wary, weary trudge.

Francis's contribution was even more startling. With a previous best score of 11, he is deemed an inferior batsman to Alan Mullally, which is like being considered a lesser ski-jumper than Eddie Edwards.

Tea arrived with the requirement down to five. By now Mascarenhas's faith in his partner was such that he twice took singles from the first ball of an over, leaving Francis to defy Tudor, Martin Bicknell and the new ball.

Mission all but accomplished, Mascarenhas, who might have been party to the highest 10th-wicket alliance to win a first-class game in England, elected to finish it with one swipe, but Tudor, whose eight wickets and an unbeaten 64 were the keys to Surrey's first success of this term, was an apt executioner.

Harassed by feeble form and funding problems at their new HQ, Hampshire may nonetheless regard this as a turning point. Mullally, in his first four-day outing for his new employers, blew away the Surrey top order on Saturday and Warne swept up the remnants.

The batting headaches, however, have attained migraine proportions. One more run each from Laney, Robin Smith, Derek Kenway and John Stephenson, who mustered 32 runs in eight innings between them, and the contest could have gone the other way.

fields.headline: Goodwin turns tables on England
fields.standfirst:
England 374
Zimbabwe 285 for 4
fields.trailText: Before this test, as ever since he became England captain, Nasser Hussain stressed that his side needed to strive for consistency if they were to climb the international ladder. They were, he said in the Trent Bridge long room last Wednesday, still rated one of the worst sides in the world. But repeating such sentiments can have an opposite effect to that intended.
fields.body:
Before this test, as ever since he became England captain, Nasser Hussain stressed that his side needed to strive for consistency if they were to climb the international ladder. They were, he said in the Trent Bridge long room last Wednesday, still rated one of the worst sides in the world. But repeating such sentiments can have an opposite effect to that intended.

Yesterday, with the euphoria of Lord's long behind them, England's cricket regressed to the sad days of wild, uncontrolled bowling and ragbag fielding, and Zimbabwe, stung by their abject performance in the first test, took advantage.

Torrential overnight rain had delayed the start until 1.40pm but the play thereafter was dominated by Zimbabwe's batsmen. From 51 for two overnight the visitors had reached 285 for four by the close, only 89 adrift of England's first-innings 374.

The game may be beyond winning for Zimbabwe - Mike Atherton's 14th test century and the rain have seen to that - but they have regained their dignity, whereas it seems that Hussain and the coach Duncan Fletcher have barely started the process of transforming England.

The day was a personal triumph for Murray Goodwin, 11 not out at the start, who shortly after 5pm tucked Andy Caddick behind square-leg for the single that brought up the third century of his 19-test career and his second in three Tests, after his 113 against West Indies in Kingston. As his team-mates celebrated on the balcony he greeted the milestone with the understatement of a fellow who had unfinished business to attend to, gently acknowledging team and spectators and placing a lingering kiss on the middle of his blade.

He was still there after 6 hours in total when bad light stopped play with almost seven overs remaining. During his 148 he had added 122 for the fourth wicket with Andy Flower, who after scoring 42 edged Darren Gough's third delivery with the second new ball on to his stumps, and 129 for the third wicket with Neil Johnson, who made 51 before he cut furiously at Gough and was athletically caught by Alec Stewart.

Goodwin, born in Harare 27 years ago, emigrated to Western Australia with his family at 13 and made 91 and 77 for the state on his first-class debut, against England at the start of the 1994-95 Ashes tour. His hundred here was only the second for Zimbabwe in their four Tests against England.

If the home side had done their homework it did not show. Goodwin is short, holds the bat with his right hand clamped low to the blade and with the top of the handle protruding over his top hand. All the indications are that he is a customised cutter and puller, nifty on the back foot. Short and wide is his stock in trade.

Yet this for the most part was what England bowled to him. Caddick found neither rhythm nor the right length and, again, high expectations on a still helpful pitch were not matched by performance.

Gough, as enthusiastic as ever but lacking the fire of Lord's, also suffered, although he has taken three of the four wickets. Ed Giddins appeared to be on the rebound from his man-of-the-match award in the first test, and Chris Schofield was given a sharp reminder of the standards required at test level; of the 73 runs he conceded in his 18 overs, 40 came in boundaries. Shades of Ian Salisbury?

So although there were some punchy drives, the bulk of Goodwin's 20 boundaries were hit square of the wicket on either side off the back foot. Sadly, it looks as if England missed a trick during the humidity on Saturday, for while Atherton was making his way to 136 before being caught at extra-cover, and later while Schofield was completing an unexpected half-century in his second test, the ball had been moving around alarmingly for the Zimbabwean seamers.

At Lord's there was a feeling that England had been slow in pressing home their advantage with the bat, given the poor weather forecast. But they got away with it. Here Hussain might have shown more faith in his bowlers by pulling out of his innings while the movement was there and letting them off the leash.

It will be countered that this is a series: England are one up and are not about to offer any remote chance of messing that up. At a time when we crave series wins against anyone, that is understandable. But it is a pity all the same.

webTitle: Lara flops as Chanderpaul hits top form

fields.headline: Lara flops as Chanderpaul hits top form
fields.standfirst:
W Indies 164 & 301-9 dec
Worcestershire 232
Match drawn
fields.trailText:
W Indies 164 & 301-9 dec

Worcestershire 232

Match drawn
fields.body:
Brian Lara, everyone agreed, had never played better. There were fierce drives and wristy flicks through midwicket as well as languid cuts in the direction of point.

The bowlers looked a little rueful as they blew on bruised fingers while the spectators stroked their chins and, nodding to each other like sages, agreed that the master had surpassed even himself.

Unfortunately for him and West Indies cricket Lara was playing in the nets after being dismissed for one for the second time in this match. And for the second time in this match he had wafted at one down the legside to give Steve Rhodes a regulation catch behind: two innings, six balls, two runs.

The last time he played here, two years ago, he scored 144 for Warwickshire. But the West Indies coach Roger Harper, whose voice is so deep that he could make the famous old American bass Paul Robeson sound like a choirboy, looked unconcerned.

"We haven't really had a chance to assess his form yet," he intoned. "But he's a top-class player and I'm confident that as the tour progresses he will come into his own. He is feeling very confident."

Soon after he was dismissed by Stuart Lampitt yesterday Lara headed for the nets and drew a crowd almost as big as that watching Shivnarine Chanderpaul extend his overnight 14 to an unbeaten 161 as the tourists went on to 301 and a draw.

Lara's net began with some personal coaching from the captain Jimmy Adams, who provided 10 minutes of throw-downs. "We've got time to get Brian right," he said. "He's been away from the middle for a long time."

The man who holds the Test and first-class batting records then moved to another net where, for 20 minutes, the tourists' assistant coach Jeff Dujon fed balls into a bowling machine. Here, he played exotic shots to all corners of his imagination. But he was also bowled three times, once without offering a stroke.

West Indies, resuming on 45 for two, lost Chris Gayle at 92 and Lara one ball later. At 93 for four, a lead of just 25, they were in danger of defeat.

Chanderpaul, though, displaying remarkable stamina for one who has recently suffered from mental exhaustion, batted for almost six hours, struck 24 fours and did not give a chance in his 310-ball innings. Despite his indifferent recent international form he looked ominous here.

The tourists have only 10 days to get the rest of the squad in form before the first test at Edgbaston. Some, however, are more in need of rest and Courtney Walsh, the world record holder with 449 test wickets, will take as much as he can get.

The veteran fast bowler explained: "My only worry is my sore right ankle. I turned it over in Barbados against Pakistan and as we played back-to-back Test matches it never had the chance to heal.

"I'm hoping to have a gentle bowl in the next couple of days. I need a bit of rest but that's something very difficult to come by, the way schedules are."

fields.trailText: Disappearing hunt supporters |  Home truths |  Police numbers |   Unsung hero   |   Blair's old idea  |  Executive stress |  Sad to lose Andy
fields.body:
Disappearing hunt supporters

At long last, the Countryside Alliance's true motives are being exposed and its covert mantra of 'exaggeration, exaggeration, exaggeration' laid open for all to see (News, last week).

The Alliance (formerly, lest we forget, the British Field Sports Society) claims that 300,000 hunt supporters attended the 1998 Countryside March. However, under the scientific scrutiny of Edinburgh's Napier University which used sophisticated counting techniques, the attendance was calculated to be a maximum of 151,000. Moreover, a Mori poll of those attending found that only 40 per cent (60,400) attended because of hunting, a figure borne out by the Daily Telegraph poll which showed 77 per cent of rural dwellers disapprove of hunting.

That he will eat a dead lamb or sheep is undeniable; that he attacks them when alive we believe to be a convenient fiction of careless servants.'
Nic Davies, Burton-upon-Trent, Staffordshire

Home truths

Baseball was not invented in 1846 (Sport, last week). Abner Doubleday (believed to be from Oxfordshire) standardised the game earlier in the century, but he certainly did not invent it. The game was previously played to various standards both in North America and Europe. An earlier version, 'International Rules' baseball, is still played on Merseyside and in South Wales and a similar game, known as Town Ball, is played in Massachusetts.

In Jane Austen's book Northanger Abbey , on the first page, her heroine is described as being fond of 'cricket and baseball'. Jane Austen would have known the game as something like that played on Merseyside, where fourth base is just short of 'home'.
Zoe Bremer, London

Helping men manage violence

I was angered by the negative message given by the article 'Therapy for wife-beaters cut because it fails to cure' (News, last week).

I am a counsellor, working in primary care, where an increasing number of men are asking for help to manage their anger/violence. I am in the process of setting up a group for such men. The philosophy of the group will be based on respect and trust for individuals who wish to change their behaviour. My aim also is to encourage men to take responsibility for their violent/abusive behaviour, rather than placing the responsibility, as usual, with women to either manage men's violence or to protect themselves from it.

I am optimistic that by continuing to work with violent/abusive men, I will have less work to do supporting, empowering, and putting back together the lives of women who experience domestic violence.
Sue Dominey, Leeds

Police numbers

Further to your article on the National Crime Squad (News, 14 May), the 52 officers we have returned prematurely to their forces went back over a period of more than two years, out of a total of more than 2,000 officers who have served on the Squad during that time.

Of those 52 officers, only seven have been returned because of allegations of corruption. Three were returned in one enquiry, and there are two other separate cases. A sixth was returned to his force because of matters allegedly occurring in that force, and a seventh was returned over matters allegedly originating in a former regional crime squad. The remainder were returned for a variety of reasons unrelated to corruption, such as drink driving (even if off duty) and failing to adhere to our exceptionally strict administrative procedures.

You state that I am leaving because of my concern about corruption. That is untrue. I announced four months ago my intention to retire at the end of this year after nearly 40 years police service.
Roy Penrose, Director General, National Crime Squad, London SW1

Unsung hero

As one of the alpinists who will be gathering under the shadow of Mont Blanc on 3 June to honour 'all the members' of the French team who successfully climbed the first-ever 8,000-metre peak, Annapurna, 50 years ago (World, last week), I would like to mention the famous alpinist and guide who in fact rescued Maurice Herzog and Louis Lachenal from the upper camp when both of them were delirious.

It was Gaston Rebuffat who also rescued Lionel Terray, that other giant of a mountaineer who was struck down with snow-blindness. These three helpless climbers were not abandoned by Rebuffat; through storms he brought them all safely to base-camp where magnificently Sherpas took over the rescue, carrying the team eventually to safety.
Dennis Morrod, Saltash, Cornwall

Blair's old idea

There is nothing new about The Third Way. It dates back to the 1880s when Sydney Webb and the Fabians won the argument with H.M. Hyndman's Social Democratic Federation over gradual, as opposed to radical, social reform. This political stance could perhaps be more graphically called The Snail Way. Mr Blair might now be advised to attach a rocket to its tail, otherwise the forces of conservatism he seems so concerned about will surely put salt on it, and the poor Snail will never reach its destination.
Jack Seddon, Chesham, Bucks

Executive stress

Like Tony Robinson, I have just been elected to Labour's National Executive Committee for the first time. I can tell him that members do not need to be managed; they need to be listened to. They warned of the 75p pension fiasco a year ago, and they can provide the collective wisdom which will win Labour further terms in government.
Ann Black, Oxford

Sad to lose Andy

Andy Kershaw's show (News, last week) has given me great pleasure - despite the Beeb's best efforts - over many years, and has introduced me to a huge variety of music - from all over Africa, but also from Cuba, from South America, from the US and from the UK - which I almost certainly could not have heard anywhere else. I've always thought of this as an example of public service broadcasting at its very best, so it's very sad to find that the BBC no longer think it's worth doing.
Philip Bromberg, Wembley Park, Middx

fields.headline: Rijkaard unites the orange factions
fields.standfirst: With expectations high, the Dutch coach is leaving nothing to chance, writes Richard Williams
fields.trailText: This time the Dutch will be practising their penalties. "Certainly," Frank Rijkaard replied with a grin when the question was put to him at his team's training camp in Switzerland at the weekend. "Everybody in the squad will be practising."
fields.body:
This time the Dutch will be practising their penalties. "Certainly," Frank Rijkaard replied with a grin when the question was put to him at his team's training camp in Switzerland at the weekend. "Everybody in the squad will be practising."

The Dutch, as we know, usually find a way of beating themselves. Sometimes, as in the World Cup final of 1974, the cause is a fatal belief in their own superiority. And in three of their last four major competitions - the European championships of 1992 and 1996 and the World Cup of 1998 - they paid a heavy price for the assumption that any footballer in a Holland shirt can take a penalty under pressure.

So now the great improvisers of European football are leaving nothing to chance. As co-hosts of Euro 2000 they are subject to immense expectations. They have the players, in the form of a squad packed with the superstars of the Liga, Serie A and the Premiership, and they have the history. This time they must make their advantages count or disappoint the vast army of fans currently painting the country orange.

"Expectations are always very high," Rijkaard said. "It means that many people have confidence in our team, and that's a good sign. On the other hand I think there are only small differences between the top teams. We have to be in very good shape and we've got to have the right team spirit and then we have the possibility to do something."

Behind Rijkaard, who was sitting in a dugout by the side of a pitch at a sports centre on the banks of Lake Geneva, the Dutch players were wandering away at the end of the day's final training session in a state of exhaustion from a series of complicated routines devised to improve their physical conditioning. This week, back in Holland, they will refine their tactics in preparation for their Group D meetings with the Czech Republic, Denmark and France.

The weight of history lies heavy on this squad's shoulders. Their training is supervised by Johan Neeskens and Ruud Krol, Rijkaard's assistant coaches, members of the generation of total footballers led by Johan Cruyff who reached two World Cup finals - the second without Cruyff - and, in the colours of Ajax, dominated European club competition in the early 1970s. Rijkaard himself is a symbol of the next generation, that of Ruud Gullit and Marco van Basten, with whom he won the 1988 European championship - still Holland's only title - before the trio moved on to Milan.

Now Rijkaard, who defined the role of the modern "holding" midfield player, is hoping to make a different kind of mark on the international scene. In his first coaching job, at the age of 37, he has the opportunity to guide the present generation of players to their place in history. For some of them, like Dennis Bergkamp and the De Boer brothers, it probably represents a last chance. But after the failures of 1996 and 1998, are they ready to claim immortality?

"I think so," Rijkaard said. "They're experienced and they're at the right age. They've been successful with their club teams. They're good players, wonderful players, and this is a great opportunity for them to be part of Dutch soccer history."

The players are hardly unaware of the burden. "We have to win, if we want to be compared with the generations before us," Marc Overmars said during a break in training. "If we want to have something to look back on when we're older, we need victory. So every player is keen to prove it. And the possibilities are there. The mix of talent is great. But it was the same in France in '98. We played well and we didn't make it in the end. So I just want to get through the first round."

The sense of realism extends throughout the squad. "What the press and the fans are saying," Jaap Stam observed, "is that, with the team we've got now, we have to win the championship. Everybody knows there's a lot of quality in the team, but that's not a guarantee for winning. Yes, if everything comes together at the right time, then we can go a long way. And I hope that we go into history as well. But we don't think too much about it. We try to concentrate on our own game. We'll do our own thing and we'll see how it goes."

Many of Holland's biggest footballing disasters have been accompanied by stories of internal dissent. In Euro 96, for instance, the squad was said to have been divided by a line between black and white players. Rijkaard, whose father was among the first Surinam-born players to appear in the Dutch league, seems to have restored a sense of collective endeavour, although with the Dutch one can never quite be sure. "It's a good squad," Stam asserted. "There's nothing going on. We all mingle and the atmosphere is very good."

The coach's relative youth, and the fact that he played with or against almost all the members of his squad, is on his side. "The thing is that he understands how it goes at the real top level," Overmars said. "He knows how you feel. He can look in your eyes and tell if you're not happy."

After hanging up his boots in the mid-90s Rijkaard took a break from football. He returned in 1998, joining the national squad as an assistant to Guus Hiddink in time for the World Cup campaign, taking over after Holland were eliminated by Brazil's greater efficiency with penalties. He seemed popular enough with the 200 fans who had followed the squad to Switzerland last week, who gave him a warm personal ovation and chanted his name when he trotted out on to the pitch at the Stade Nyonnais. "He's doing very well," Stam said. "He knows what he wants and what he expects from the players. And he knows what's going on in modern football."

Having worked under Michels, Cruyff, Sacchi, Capello and Van Gaal during his playing career Rijkaard claims to have been influenced by none of them in particular. "With every coach you work with, you learn something. Then at the end of your career, when you become a trainer, you take something from every coach that you think is useful for you. So, if you see a bad example, you can do something with it because you want to be different. You want to be yourself. There are coaches with habits you don't like and you tell yourself, I don't want to be like that. But there's no one way to success."

In his position the first responsibility is to entertain. "The Dutch public always wants to see a team that is trying to be dominant, trying to play attractive football, and after that, hopefully, a team that is winning. It's normal. The players are used to it because they've been brought up in the Dutch football school."

But Rijkaard was always a winner and he is concerned to establish a solid base from which the team can construct its attacks. "The differences between the top teams in Euro 2000 are so minimal that I think you have to be very clever in defence and stop your opponents getting opportunities. Top games like these can be decided in one or two moments. The main thing for us is to have a good organisation, so that we know what to do if we don't have the ball. We have players in attack who are skilful and fast. If we manage not to give away a goal, we can score a goal."

Stam, who will be alongside Frank de Boer in the middle of a four-man defence, reinforced Rijkaard's words. "The coach wants to have a solid team, starting at the back, giving nothing away. We've got a lot of players who can decide a game in a split second - we have strong players up front and in midfield who can score goals very easily - so the main thing for the team is to stay solid and not concede any goals, because in every game we play we make chances."

The price of automatic qualification is the lack of competitive matches leading up to the finals, meaning that Rijkaard's ideas have yet to be tested in genuinely competitive conditions. Although Holland have not lost a match since the World Cup semi-final two years ago, a string of lacklustre performances in friendlies - including 10 consecutive drawn games - did nothing to inspire confidence.

"The results so far haven't been the best," said Overmars, "and we've had a lot of criticism, even the manager. But it doesn't really bother me. I look at it in a positive way. If you win the last 10 matches before the tournament, you might start thinking you're going to win it easily."

Last night in Lausanne's little Olympic Stadium, in front of a crowd of 7,500, Rijkaard's team beat Poland 3-1 in their final warm-up match before returning to Hoenderloo, their base for the tournament. Playing a 4-1-2-2-1 formation, starting with the veteran Aaron Winter in front of the back four and with Boudewijn Zenden in place of the injured Overmars alongside Bergkamp in support of Patrick Kluivert, they produced plenty of attractive attacking moves while confirming suspicions about the vulnerability at the centre of their defence.

Although Stam and Frank de Boer looked worryingly cumbersome as Marcin Zewlakov and Pawel Kryszalowicz cut them open to create four good chances in the opening quarter, the Dutch forwards had already begun to assert themselves when De Boer put them ahead after 28 minutes with a curling left-footed free-kick. Kryszalowicz's equaliser, nine minutes later, came after Edwin van der Sar had beaten away Zewlakov's shot with the defenders slow to respond.

The arrival after the interval of Edgar Davids, still recovering from the recent removal of an in-growing toenail but nevertheless displaying the sort of energy more suited to a World Cup final, allowed the Dutch to raise their tempo. And, thanks to the work of two more half-time substitutes, the two goals with which Kluivert won the game were certainly the genuine article. For the first, after 55 minutes, he slid the ball home from Peter van Vossen's beautifully delayed pass. And five minutes later he raced in to meet a low cross from Ronald de Boer with a spectacular header.

But once the real thing gets under way, can Rijkaard control the independence and self-confidence for which Dutch footballers are justly renowned? "The coach respects everybody as an individual," Stam said, "but the players know that when we're on the pitch we have to do it together, not alone. It's true that most Dutch people are very confident. I wouldn't say we are over-confident. We're not saying we're going to win it. But we know we can."

fields.headline: Fiji still on tourist trail
fields.trailText: British tourists are still travelling to Fiji, despite the coup on 19 May and martial law.
fields.body:
British tourists are still travelling to Fiji, despite the coup on 19 May and martial law. The Foreign Office advises against all travel to Suva, the capital in the east of the main island, and against all but essential travel to the rest of Fiji. But tourism is concentrated in the west, particularly on a string of outlying islands, and international and domestic flights are operating normally to Nadi, 120 miles from Suva.

Roger Poulton, UK Manager for Air New Zealand: said: 'Our four flights per week between Los Angeles and Fiji, which connect with our flights from Heathrow, are all operating. Most of our passengers seem aware that hotels in the Nadi area and the outer islands are running normally. Only a handful of passengers have asked to change their travel plans.'

Garth Downey, owner of Yasawa Island Resort, a luxury retreat in a remote island group 35 minutes flying time from Nadi, reported business as normal. 'Like all the offshore islands, we've not experienced any real impact from the trouble in Suva which is a long way to the east. Life here is as relaxed as ever.'

Katie Spears, a sales supervisor with Austravel, returned last week from a visit to Fiji. 'You would not have known there was anything wrong when we stayed at the Sheraton Royal Denaru near Nadi airport,' she said. 'And the islands seemed a million miles from anywhere. No one even mentioned the coup.'

Tour operators say holidaymakers can curtail their holidays or stay on, and those booked to travel within the next six weeks may cancel or change their itineraries without charge.
fields.bodyText: British tourists are still travelling to Fiji, despite the coup on 19 May and martial law. The Foreign Office advises against all travel to Suva, the capital in the east of the main island, and against all but essential travel to the rest of Fiji. But tourism is concentrated in the west, particularly on a string of outlying islands, and international and domestic flights are operating normally to Nadi, 120 miles from Suva. Roger Poulton, UK Manager for Air New Zealand: said: 'Our four flights per week between Los Angeles and Fiji, which connect with our flights from Heathrow, are all operating. Most of our passengers seem aware that hotels in the Nadi area and the outer islands are running normally. Only a handful of passengers have asked to change their travel plans.' Garth Downey, owner of Yasawa Island Resort, a luxury retreat in a remote island group 35 minutes flying time from Nadi, reported business as normal. 'Like all the offshore islands, we've not experienced any real impact from the trouble in Suva which is a long way to the east. Life here is as relaxed as ever.' Katie Spears, a sales supervisor with Austravel, returned last week from a visit to Fiji. 'You would not have known there was anything wrong when we stayed at the Sheraton Royal Denaru near Nadi airport,' she said. 'And the islands seemed a million miles from anywhere. No one even mentioned the coup.' Tour operators say holidaymakers can curtail their holidays or stay on, and those booked to travel within the next six weeks may cancel or change their itineraries without charge.

fields.headline: A Greek concierge reveals all
fields.standfirst:
Hotel Grande Bretagne, Athens
Panagiotis Christou, concierge
fields.trailText: Any famous guests?
fields.body:
Any famous guests?

Recently several political figures have stayed here, such as the Prime Minister of Belgium and the President of the Czech Republic. We had Pele staying here, for a major football tournament. Joan Collins has been here several times on her way to one of the islands, as has Elizabeth Taylor. We also had Oliver Reed as a guest, who was no trouble at all.

Any unusual requests?

It's part of this job to get difficult requests, and I never really think of them as unusual. When people are staying in a hotel, they expect to be able to pick up the phone and get something, just as they would at home. Everything seems very easy to many of them - some people ask for things and like to be looked after straight away. I have been asked to provide some social escorts and this kind of thing; that can put you in a corner and embarrass you. We give them the paper with the ads and they can make the calls - this is all we can do for them.

What about a night out?

When a guest asks for a recommendation for dinner, we always try to understand what exactly he wants. It's important to know what kind of meal they would like to have, how much they would like to pay, and whether or not they would like traditional Greek food. We try to recommend places close to the hotel as getting back by taxi late at night can be a problem. For Greek food, Daphne's in the old part of the city is excellent. There is a lovely garden and usually guitar music playing. Pilpool serves continental food and has an excellent view of the Acropolis, which is something lots of guests ask for. Dionysus is on Lycavitos Hill and has a fantastic view of the city - people travel up on a cable car. There is the open-air theatre of Herodion beneath the Acropolis which hosts international music or ancient plays during the summer. Vanessa Mae played there two days ago.

What about a day out?

The city is a show in itself and guests can take in the sights either on an organised bus tour or in a private car. It's a good idea to try going outside the city , maybe to take a drive along the coast to see the Temple of Poseidon. The Acropolis is an obvious place for people to go, as is the National Archaeological Museum. The Cycladic Museum is showing the latest relics excavated during the recent works on the Paris Metro. Away from the museums, people really enjoy wandering around the flea markets and enjoying the atmosphere.

Hotel Grande Bretagne: 00 301 331 4444

Cycladic Museum: 00 301 724 9706

Dionysus Restaurant: 00 301 923 3182

Pilpool Restaurant: 00 301 342 3665

Daphne's: 00 301 322 7971

webTitle: Win a week for two in the Peloponnese

fields.headline: Win a week for two in the Peloponnese
fields.trailText: Win a week's self-catering holiday for two in the southern Peloponnese - by answering the question below (Clue: the answer can be found in this week's Escape).
fields.body:
Win a week's self-catering holiday for two in the southern Peloponnese - by answering the question below (Clue: the answer can be found in this week's Escape).

The vast Peloponnese peninsula has few tourists, glorious scenery and timeless villages. Chrani is one of these, in a fertile area known as the Garden of Peloponnese. It's a quiet seaside hamlet with views across the Messinian Gulf to the mountainous Mani opposite, a good beach, good swimming and enticing tavernas.

Sunvil Holidays, which is celebrating 30 years of specialist holidays in Greece and the Greek Islands, is offering the prizewinner and partner a choice of departure dates - all Sundays - 25 June, 2 July or 9 July - to a one-bedroom apartment in the Villa Sophia. The apartment has stunning views from its large balcony and is just yards from a small pebble beach. Flights are from Gatwick, departing at 7.30am, arriving at 1pm, direct to Kalamata airport, which is 45 minutes from Chrani. The return flight leaves at 2pm and arrives at Gatwick at 3.35pm. Flights, transfers and accommodation are included.

The question: Which ancient city was home to 40,000 people in its heyday and a flourishing centre for Byzantine arts? Answers on a postcard by 12 June to Sunvil Holidays/Observer Competition, Sunvil House, Upper Square, Old Isleworth, Middlesex TW7 7BJ. Include your name, address and telephone number. For a copy of Sunvil's Specialist Greece brochure call 020 8758 4747.

fields.headline: England's second string unravelled
fields.standfirst: On today's performance, says Lawrence Booth, Schofield, Giddins and co. won't make the difference against the Windies
fields.trailText: England's most ordinary day of the series may turn out to be the most useful. At Lord's it was hard to draw any real conclusions about the quality of the support bowling, however much Ed Giddins was praised for his absurdly flattering five-for. Here, with Andy Caddick and Darren Gough quieter than usual, we learnt some more revealing lessons as the game meandered towards a draw.
fields.body:
England's most ordinary day of the series may turn out to be the most useful. At Lord's it was hard to draw any real conclusions about the quality of the support bowling, however much Ed Giddins was praised for his absurdly flattering five-for. Here, with Andy Caddick and Darren Gough quieter than usual, we learnt some more revealing lessons as the game meandered towards a draw.

Murray Goodwin, whose Test average is higher than Mike Atherton's, batted outstandingly to make the highest score by a Zimbabwean against England, passing the 112 Andy Flower made at Bulawayo in 1996-97. His cutting and driving were sheer perfection. But the ease with which he coped with Giddins, Andy Flintoff and the legspin of Chris Schofield suggests England might be in trouble when the West Indies series starts in less than a fortnight.

The pitch had less in it for the bowlers than yesterday, but that is precisely the time when a bowler has to show he can keep it tight. Instead, it was back to the bad old days as Caddick fretted about the damp run-ups and England unwrapped a gift for the opposition in a legspinner who has two stock balls - the full toss and the long hop. It was like watching Ian Salisbury bowling to Steve Waugh.

Giddins was harmless (no greentop, this), and it's hard to imagine Angus Fraser feeding Goodwin's favourite cut shot as Flintoff (who should have been tried earlier than 162 for 3) did after tea.

In fact Fraser would be just the sort of miserly bowler the West Indies don't like facing. He's been in the wickets for Middlesex this season, his record against West Indies (70 wickets at 23.70) is world-class, and with their own batting line-up full of dashers, discipline will be essential. And if Gus replaced Giddins, he would actually strengthen the batting.

As for Schofield (18-2-73-0), unless he improves overnight, he can't start the first Test at Edgbaston, which is likely to be a seamer's wicket anyway. His place in the side is further weakened by the fact that West Indies are packed with left-handers: if England must play a spinner in Birmingham, they should have someone who turns it the other way instead. Peter Such may not be the most progressive pick, but with Robert Croft struggling to pick up wickets for Glamorgan, there aren't many other options.

Suddenly, Lord's seems light years away.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

fields.headline: Our top 20 Greek islands
fields.standfirst: Mixing the Ancients with the modern... a tour, by
fields.trailText: Mixing the Ancients with the modern... a tour, by Robin Barton
fields.body:
The most formidable obstacle to holidaying on Greek islands is the choice. There are 1,400 to consider, carelessly scattered throughout the Aegean and Ionian seas, and they are all different. Some offer throbbing night-clubs, others just a few tavernas and isolated beaches. Here we have chosen representatives from each of the major groups (the enchantingly named Cyclades, Sporades, Ionian, Aegean, Saronic Gulf and Dodecanese). The prices are offered as a guideline, but sometimes specific availabilities are highlighted.

1 Corfu pop: 40,000

History and literature permeate the second largest Ionian island like its many springs and rivers. Corfu was Homer's 'beautiful and rich' land, and Odysseus's final stop on his way home to Ithaca. Shakespeare is also believed to have set The Tempest on the island and, more recently, Lawrence Durrell made Corfu his home. Two weeks in the high season at the Paloumbi Mansion in the secluded village of Sinarades will cost from £870 per person, including flights, with Simply Ionian (020 8995 1121).

2 Paxos pop: 2,200

This small Ionian island has a captivating landscape of ancient olive groves, farmhouses and olive presses. Thankfully Paxos has escaped mass tourism and is highly recommended by discriminating tour companies. The capital, Gaios, is a crumbling and attractive port. Planos Holidays (01373 836000) operate solely in Paxos and have a varied range of properties. The Villa Violetta sleeps six to eight and enjoys superb views over Lakka Bay. Two weeks during the summer months will cost from £757 per person, including return flights and car hire.

3 Lefkas pop: 21,100

The fourth largest island in the Ionian group has 10 satellite islets. The islanders are proud of their mountainous, but fertile, home and many of the older women wear traditional costume. The last two weeks of August are dominated by the International Festival of Literature and Art. Sunvil Activity Holidays (020 8232 9779) use Nidri on Lefkas as a base for their Greek sailing holidays. The flotillas explore the central Ionian islands, including Ithaca and Cephallonia. Prices start at £1,120 for two weeks aboard a Discovery 3,000 yacht during the high season, and include return flights (from Heathrow).

4 Kephalonia pop: 32,500

Louis de Bernière's Captain Corelli's Mandolin was set here, among the rugged mountains and abundant wild flowers and herbs of the largest Ionian island. There are package tourists but not as many as on Corfu. Nature lovers should note that the island is also a nesting ground for loggerhead turtles. Tapestry (020 8235 7788) have availability during the mid and high season at the Panorama Apartments in the northern fishing village of Assos. Prices for one week of self-catering accommodation start from £480 per person and include flights, transfers and a welcome hamper.

5 Zakynthos pop: 32,500

Unfortunately the Venetians' name for Zakynthos, 'flower of the orient', is a little misleading these days. Much of the island was insensitively rebuilt after an earthquake in 1953, but Zakynthos has been more seriously blighted by mass tourism along the coastline. However, the beaches are beautiful, and unspoilt areas can be found inland. One place to escape the worst of the crowds is Vassilikos. Two weeks at the Lena Villas in the village starts at £687 per person (based on four sharing). This is a mid-season price, and includes return flights from Gatwick to Zakynthos and car hire. Call Greek Islands Club on 020 8232 9780.

6 Spetses pop: 3,700

The most remote of the Saronic Gulf islands is a favourite with British holiday-makers. Pine-covered Spetses became wealthy through ship-building but is probably best known as the setting for the novel The Magus (author John Fowles taught English on the island in 1950). CV Travel (0870 606 0013) have availability at the Villa Ioanna from 24 June to 8 July. The villa, which sleeps eight, costs £1,535 per week (excluding flights).

7 Skiathos pop: 4,100

The island's golden beaches attract hordes of package tourists, especially during August, but people also come for the nightlife. There are quieter areas and walks inland. Summer prices for 14 nights at the family-sized Villa Petraki start at £719 with Skiathos Travel (020 8940 5157) and include return flights to the island. The villa overlooks Kanapitsa beach, with views across to Skopelos and there is availability for two weeks from 30 June.

8 Skopelos pop: 5000

Skopelos is less commercial than Skiathos, but probably not for long. There are two main settlements, the port and the lovely hill village, Glossa, while the south-east coast has many sheltered, pebbled beaches. Travel A La Carte (01635 863030) are offering seven nights self-catering at Liakada Cottage from £409, departing 30 June. This includes return flights and, since Skopelos does not have an airport, ferry transfers.

9 Alonissos pop: 3,000

Alonissos has been discovered by tour companies, but the lack of an airport helps to restrict mass tourism. In 1965 an earthquake destroyed the hilltop capital and inhabitants abandoned their homes. In recent years many of the derelict houses have been bought and restored by British and German expats: Old Alonissos is now a vibrant artist community. The seawater around the island is the cleanest in the Aegean. Two weeks at Villa Eirene with Skiathos Travel (0208 940 5157) during July and September will cost from £588, including flights.

10 Skyros pop: 2,800

The island is some distance from the rest of the the Sporades, and actually feels more like the Cyclades, particularly in the stark, cubist Skyros Town. The south side of the island is almost uninhabited and there are few package tourists. Some people specifically come to recuperate at the Skyros Centre, a holistic health centre, but another key reason to visit is the Skyros Lenten Carnival, Greece's quirkiest festival which involves much dressing-up in goat costume (for the men). Manos Holidays (01273 427 333) are offering a lead-in price of £464 for two weeks' B & B (plus flights and transfers) at the Skyros Palace Hotel, based on two sharing.

11 Samos pop: 32,000

The most southerly of the North-Eastern Aegean islands and the closest to Turkey, Samos also has the most tourists. Expeditions inland reveal unspoilt villages and mountain vistas and an exotic and tropical atmosphere is everywhere, thanks to the floral scents (especially jasmine): orchids are even grown for export. Samos is consequently a popular place for rambling and more demanding mountain treks in the spring and autumn. Prices start at £577 (including flights but not transfers) for 14 nights' B & B during the high season at the Hotel Aeolis with Filoxenia (01422 375 999). The waterfront hotel boasts a roof-top bar and a swimming pool.

12 Patmos pop: 2,660

Orthodox and Western Christians have long made pilgrimages to Patmos because it was here that St John, then living in a cave, wrote the Book of Revelations . Sun worshippers now congregate with the devout on the island. Patmos is quite small and accommodation tends to get booked up very quickly. However, CV Travel (0870 606 0013) have availability for one or two weeks at a large house, Langada, which sleeps eight. The villa costs £2,130 per week (excluding flights), and is set on a hillside, around a courtyard and restored chapel.

13 Lipsi pop: 606

The idyllic, laid-back island of Lipsi is just eight miles east of Patmos. There are relatively small numbers of tourists so neither the pretty beaches, such as Platys Gialos, nor the locals are overwhelmed. The port town is the only settlement, and there are actually more goats than people. Laskarina Holidays (01629 822 203), specialising in the less well-known islands, have availability for 14 nights at the one-bedroom Kalypso apartments from 20 July, at £505 per person.

14 Kalymnos pop: 18,200

Although this arid island was previously renowned for its sponge fishing, the demise of that industry has meant that Kalymnos's economy relies upon tourism. However, on New Year's Eve 1995, a local fisherman brought in the catch of the day when he netted a two-metre bronze statue of a woman, believed to be the work of the sculptor Praxiteles in 4BC. Prices for two weeks at Ilias Studios, in the heart of the Panormos resort (which may or may not be an advantage), begin at £489 in July with Airtours (0800 028 4934).

15 Kos pop: 26,400

Kos is a large and fertile island, although sunbeds and parasols have sprouted up all over the sandy beaches. One of the most popular and lively islands, it is definitely one for the youngsters (or the young at heart). Kos Town has two streets, Diakon and Nafklirou, that are wall-to-wall bars, plus three nightclubs. Seven nights at the All Inclusive Kourous Club complex, close to the Mastihari resort, leads in at £371 per person with Manos Holidays (01273 427 333). The package, as the name suggests, includes everything from flights to those all-important drinks.

16 Symi pop: 2,332

Symi has a long tradition of sponge-diving and ship-building, but is now more reliant on daytrippers from nearby Rhodes. It has a scenic, wooded interior and a multitude of small bays and beaches, but suffers from severe water shortages. The Symi International Festival runs through July, August and September with music from all over the world, theatre and Greek dancing. Laskarina (01629 822 203) sponsor two weeks of classical music concerts from 20 August and have availability at the harbourside Kyklameno Studio, for that fortnight, for £620 per person (inclusive).

17 Rhodes pop: 98,000

The number one package tour destination in the Dodecanese, with 300 days of sunshine and an east coast of uninterrupted sandy beaches, is also a beautiful island, with unspoilt villages in the interior foothills. The World Heritage-listed old town of Rhodes City is the largest inhabited medieval town in Europe, with imposing fortifications. The self-contained Miramare resort boasts swimming pools, sports facilities, shops and modern suites. The Best of Greece (01784 492 492) offer two weeks B&B at the resort from £1,194 per person. This includes a direct flight from Gatwick and Rhodes

18 Karpathos pop: 5,323

This thin island is bisected by an east-west mountain range. For hundreds of years the north and south parts of the island developed independently - the northern village of Olymbos is of endless fascination to ethnologists for the age-old customs of the villagers. Despite having an airport, Karpathos has not suffered too much from mass tourism. Two weeks at the Blue Sea Hotel in Amopi Bay with Greek Sun Holidays (01732 740 317) costs from £448 per person in October to £559 in August (based on two people sharing). The price includes scheduled flights and breakfast.

19 Crete pop: 160,000

The largest and most southerly Greek island is arguably the most beautiful too. Three mountain ranges are punctuated by agricultural plateaus and numerous sandy beaches fringe the coast. Scenery aside, the island was also the birthplace of Europe's original advanced civilisation, the Minoan. More recently, however, the island has the dubious honour of playing host to a quarter of Greece's tourists, so much of the north coast is over-built with hotels. Catherine Secker (020 8460 8022) has specialised in Cretan holidays for 22 years and offers several properties on the quiet, rural Akrotiri Peninsula. Two weeks at the secluded Villas Hibiscus costs from £500 per person (based on four people sharing). Flights (included) depart Gatwick every Tuesday to Chania.

20 Santorini pop: 9,500

Santorini is often described as unique and spectacular, and justifiably so. An enormous volcanic eruption around 1650 BC created an astonishing caldera (a submerged crater) at the centre of the island. The volcanic volatility persists today, but tourists flock to the photogenic island. Other side-effects include black sand beaches and rather good wines. A traditional cottage in Finikia is available through CV Travel (0870 606 0013) from 18 July for£1,405 per week.
