There are two main settlements, the port and the lovely hill village, Glossa, while the south-east coast has many sheltered, pebbled beaches. Travel A La Carte (01635 863030) are offering seven nights self-catering at Liakada Cottage from £409, departing 30 June. This includes return flights and, since Skopelos does not have an airport, ferry transfers. 9 Alonissos pop: 3,000 Alonissos has been discovered by tour companies, but the lack of an airport helps to restrict mass tourism. In 1965 an earthquake destroyed the hilltop capital and inhabitants abandoned their homes. In recent years many of the derelict houses have been bought and restored by British and German expats: Old Alonissos is now a vibrant artist community. The seawater around the island is the cleanest in the Aegean. Two weeks at Villa Eirene with Skiathos Travel (0208 940 5157) during July and September will cost from £588, including flights. 10 Skyros pop: 2,800 The island is some distance from the rest of the the Sporades, and actually feels more like the Cyclades, particularly in the stark, cubist Skyros Town. The south side of the island is almost uninhabited and there are few package tourists. Some people specifically come to recuperate at the Skyros Centre, a holistic health centre, but another key reason to visit is the Skyros Lenten Carnival, Greece's quirkiest festival which involves much dressing-up in goat costume (for the men). Manos Holidays (01273 427 333) are offering a lead-in price of £464 for two weeks' B & B (plus flights and transfers) at the Skyros Palace Hotel, based on two sharing. 11 Samos pop: 32,000 The most southerly of the North-Eastern Aegean islands and the closest to Turkey, Samos also has the most tourists. Expeditions inland reveal unspoilt villages and mountain vistas and an exotic and tropical atmosphere is everywhere, thanks to the floral scents (especially jasmine): orchids are even grown for export. Samos is consequently a popular place for rambling and more demanding mountain treks in the spring and autumn. Prices start at £577 (including flights but not transfers) for 14 nights' B & B during the high season at the Hotel Aeolis with Filoxenia (01422 375 999). The waterfront hotel boasts a roof-top bar and a swimming pool. 12 Patmos pop: 2,660 Orthodox and Western Christians have long made pilgrimages to Patmos because it was here that St John, then living in a cave, wrote the Book of Revelations . Sun worshippers now congregate with the devout on the island. Patmos is quite small and accommodation tends to get booked up very quickly. However, CV Travel (0870 606 0013) have availability for one or two weeks at a large house, Langada, which sleeps eight. The villa costs £2,130 per week (excluding flights), and is set on a hillside, around a courtyard and restored chapel. 13 Lipsi pop: 606 The idyllic, laid-back island of Lipsi is just eight miles east of Patmos. There are relatively small numbers of tourists so neither the pretty beaches, such as Platys Gialos, nor the locals are overwhelmed. The port town is the only settlement, and there are actually more goats than people. Laskarina Holidays (01629 822 203), specialising in the less well-known islands, have availability for 14 nights at the one-bedroom Kalypso apartments from 20 July, at £505 per person. 14 Kalymnos pop: 18,200 Although this arid island was previously renowned for its sponge fishing, the demise of that industry has meant that Kalymnos's economy relies upon tourism. However, on New Year's Eve 1995, a local fisherman brought in the catch of the day when he netted a two-metre bronze statue of a woman, believed to be the work of the sculptor Praxiteles in 4BC. Prices for two weeks at Ilias Studios, in the heart of the Panormos resort (which may or may not be an advantage), begin at £489 in July with Airtours (0800 028 4934). 15 Kos pop: 26,400 Kos is a large and fertile island, although sunbeds and parasols have sprouted up all over the sandy beaches. One of the most popular and lively islands, it is definitely one for the youngsters (or the young at heart). Kos Town has two streets, Diakon and Nafklirou, that are wall-to-wall bars, plus three nightclubs. Seven nights at the All Inclusive Kourous Club complex, close to the Mastihari resort, leads in at £371 per person with Manos Holidays (01273 427 333). The package, as the name suggests, includes everything from flights to those all-important drinks. 16 Symi pop: 2,332 Symi has a long tradition of sponge-diving and ship-building, but is now more reliant on daytrippers from nearby Rhodes. It has a scenic, wooded interior and a multitude of small bays and beaches, but suffers from severe water shortages. The Symi International Festival runs through July, August and September with music from all over the world, theatre and Greek dancing. Laskarina (01629 822 203) sponsor two weeks of classical music concerts from 20 August and have availability at the harbourside Kyklameno Studio, for that fortnight, for £620 per person (inclusive). 17 Rhodes pop: 98,000 The number one package tour destination in the Dodecanese, with 300 days of sunshine and an east coast of uninterrupted sandy beaches, is also a beautiful island, with unspoilt villages in the interior foothills. The World Heritage-listed old town of Rhodes City is the largest inhabited medieval town in Europe, with imposing fortifications. The self-contained Miramare resort boasts swimming pools, sports facilities, shops and modern suites. The Best of Greece (01784 492 492) offer two weeks B&B at the resort from £1,194 per person. This includes a direct flight from Gatwick and Rhodes 18 Karpathos pop: 5,323 This thin island is bisected by an east-west mountain range. For hundreds of years the north and south parts of the island developed independently - the northern village of Olymbos is of endless fascination to ethnologists for the age-old customs of the villagers. Despite having an airport, Karpathos has not suffered too much from mass tourism. Two weeks at the Blue Sea Hotel in Amopi Bay with Greek Sun Holidays (01732 740 317) costs from £448 per person in October to £559 in August (based on two people sharing). The price includes scheduled flights and breakfast. 19 Crete pop: 160,000 The largest and most southerly Greek island is arguably the most beautiful too. Three mountain ranges are punctuated by agricultural plateaus and numerous sandy beaches fringe the coast. Scenery aside, the island was also the birthplace of Europe's original advanced civilisation, the Minoan. More recently, however, the island has the dubious honour of playing host to a quarter of Greece's tourists, so much of the north coast is over-built with hotels. Catherine Secker (020 8460 8022) has specialised in Cretan holidays for 22 years and offers several properties on the quiet, rural Akrotiri Peninsula. Two weeks at the secluded Villas Hibiscus costs from £500 per person (based on four people sharing). Flights (included) depart Gatwick every Tuesday to Chania. 20 Santorini pop: 9,500 Santorini is often described as unique and spectacular, and justifiably so. An enormous volcanic eruption around 1650 BC created an astonishing caldera (a submerged crater) at the centre of the island. The volcanic volatility persists today, but tourists flock to the photogenic island. Other side-effects include black sand beaches and rather good wines. A traditional cottage in Finikia is available through CV Travel (0870 606 0013) from 18 July for£1,405 per week.

fields.headline: Let's go!
fields.standfirst: Ten things to do today
fields.trailText: Ten things to do today
fields.body:
 Be among the first to see Warning Shots at The Royal Armouries' Museum, Leeds, a contemporary art collection that explores conflict in modern society and promises to be very different from most military exhibitions. 0113 2201999. Free. 10.30am-5.30pm.

 Moss Bank Park in Bolton hosts a traditional day out: classic cars, steam train rides, fairground attractions and children's activities promise to wear little ones out. 11am-5pm. Phone 01204 522311. Free.

 Learn about Bath's inauspicious beginnings from Michael Dacre at Farleigh Hungerford Castle, as he recounts the tale of a leper who accidentally discovered the curative properties of the waters there. There will be workshops on mask and hat making for those with a weaker stomach. 12noon-5pm. Adults £3.50, kids £2.60. Phone 01225 754 026.

 Spying in the Second World War is given the Hogarth Heroes treatment at Pendennis Castle, Cornwall, as the group of actors - as hapless military secret agents - use exploding footballs, a Trojan cow and a rocket-powered car. Noon-5pm. Adults £4, kids £2. Phone 01326 316594.

 The dome in Edwardian Central Hall, Storey's Gate, London, provides panoramic views of London and can be scaled during today's special open day to the sound of organ recitals from 1.30pm. Entry to and tours of the hall are free, while tours of the dome cost £3. Phone 020 7222 8010.

 Several of London's private garden squares are throwing open their gates and admitting the public. There will also be classical music, children's games and refreshments. The adult fee (£5) goes to green charities. 020 7839 3969 for participating squares/times.

 Newcastle and Durham universities try to oust Oxford and Cambridge from the pinnacle of university boat races. Their race on the River Tyne is preceded by riverbank entertainment from 12.30 and boating spectaculars from 2.30pm. The best view is from Sandgate Quayside. Free.

 Aliens are invading Vogrie Country Park, Gorebridge, in an exhibition featuring original and replica props, costumes and models from popular sci-fi films. Dr. Who obsessives are well catered for. Phone 01875 821 990. 10am-7pm. Adults £2.50, kids £1.50.

 Scottish Wildlife Trust experts will be on hand at Mugdock Country Park to offer advice on plant and animal life during the Loch Ardinning Open Day. Kids can follow tree trails and explore pond life in pond dipping sessions. Phone 0141 956 6100. 2pm-5pm. Free.

 Be a living sculpture or hide in a mood pod at the Centre for Visual Arts, Cardiff, as part of the Fantasmic exhibition aimed at involving children in art through interactive events. Open 11am-5pm. Phone 02920 394040. Adults £3.50, kids £2.

webTitle: Need a guide? Then you definitely need Pausanias

fields.headline: Need a guide? Then you definitely need Pausanias
fields.standfirst: Liz Potter hails a peerless ancient
fields.trailText: Pausanias lived in the second century AD and wrote the earliest guide to Greece that has survived. He provides us with our most complete picture of what the ancient Greek world would have looked like, and has been plundered by travel guides ever since.
fields.body:
Odysseus, Pericles, Thucydides - these names will be dropped, somewhere, by every modern guidebook worth its salt which attempts to introduce you to the archaic and classical past of Greece. Another name will often crop up, usually unexplained, in its descriptions of ancient sites. It is less familiar, but worth noticing: Pausanias.

Pausanias lived in the second century AD and wrote the earliest guide to Greece that has survived. He provides us with our most complete picture of what the ancient Greek world would have looked like, and has been plundered by travel guides ever since.

His was a grand plan: to describe the experience of visiting all of Greece, or at least those places and things in Greece he deemed impor tant. He was aiming at the educated tourist (a growth industry at the time), particularly the élite from his native Asia Minor who could be expected to make their own Grand Tour. He would also have hoped to inform the armchair tourist back at home, or even in Rome.

Because the Greeks could teach the Romans a thing or two about the past, Pausanias's account, though revealing aspects of Greece's life under Roman rule, is in fact far more interested in the past. He guides us round Greece with an eye to antique objects: he has a noticeable preference for the sculpture and painting of the fifth century BC, and rather loses interest after 150BC. (You wouldn't know from his account of the Acropolis, for instance, of certain statues and temples erected by Roman emperors which must have been prominent at the time he was writing.)

He describes ancient statues, pictures, tombs and sanctuaries, digressing at length on their legends, history and religious traditions. From these, he seems to be saying, stems the Greek identity. There is more than a touch of 'ya boo' to the Romans - you might have conquered the land, but the Greek past will ever be present.

Yet for all the details he provides for this burgeoning tourist market, Pausanias was probably not widely read in antiquity (and particularly not on site: imagine all those scrolls_) So why the fuss?

Largely because, being the sole complete survivor of the 'ancient guidebook' tradition, he has proved invaluable to excavation work. His information helped early archaeologists to locate ancient sites which had been neglected or silted over. It then helped them to work out what to look for, and to imagine what the remains represented. He comes in particularly useful on statues. A base often remains without its statue, but reconstuction books can have a field day using Pausanias's descriptions to re-draw what they might have looked like. The current reconstruction work at Epi davros and Delphi is helped not least by our Pausanias.

All in all, a service to the modern traveller - because, let's face it, when you get to the Glory of Greece, you can often miss the glory for what appears to be simply a pile of old stones. A friend of mine, who teaches classics, once asked a group of teenagers to write down as many adjectives as they could to describe the statue of Athene. They came up with 'broken', 'old' and 'statue' (a tribute to their imagination and their grammar). If you too arrive on site and feel dismayed at what seems like a mess of broken old statues, turn to Pausanias.

 Pausanias's Guide to Greece is available in two volumes from Penguin Classics, £10.99 each.

webTitle: Where a flame   goes on burning

fields.headline: Where a flame   goes on burning
fields.standfirst: Michael Holland finds an untarnished link between our world and the classical age
fields.trailText: Michael Holland finds an untarnished link between our world and the classical age.
fields.body:
Why go to Greece? What is the point? Well, to uncover, of course. To strip away our grimy northern layers of inhibition. To lay ourselves open to the Mediterranean light and its lambent sea. Maybe even to get laid.

Why not? This is, after all, a deep and passionate land of sex and death; the land of Agamemnon and of Clytemnestra whose magnificent tholos-tombs, 3,500 years old, can be seen at Mycenae, home to the Homeric legends that shaped so much of the classical world, which in its turn still defines so many of the contours of our own culture.

Less than an hour's drive away is Epidavros, home of Asklepios, the God of healing, whose symbol of a serpent appears on so many badges of modern medicine. Today, it is better known for the outstanding acoustics of its 2,000-year-old theatre, which rings to the declamations of the Oresteia every summer.

Away to the west, over the mountains of Arcadia, lies Olympia, born out of legend but realised through the hard graft of its quadrennial sporting contests. After more than 1,000 years of the games, they were axed by the anti-pagan Emperor Theodosius in 394AD, then revived as the modern Olympiad 1,500 years later by Baron Pierre de Coubertin, whose embalmed heart now lies buried near the original stadium.

If Greece can slake our corporeal thirst, it can also feed our spiritual hunger, its abundance providing rich nutrients for the soul. But they can be hard to uncover. Only in the past two centuries have we located, let alone excavated, many of the ancient sites, helped by early tour guides such as the second-century Pausanias (see overleaf). To each new culture, the previous one seemed irrelevant; its infrastructure for the most part redundant.

But today, as old stone blocks were used in new buildings, we can see, standing amid the hillside beauty of Delphi or next to one of the stoa in Corinth (whose inhabitants were so berated by St Paul for their loose living), just how umbilically connected we are to the classical world.

Most of us wanting to pay homage to the ancient Greeks among the olive groves and orange trees, to rake over our collective runes amid the rocks and ruins (which is which, it's often difficult to tell), first suffer the mule kick of modern Athens. While hundreds of coaches disgorge thousands of jostling tourists on to the worn rubble of the Acropolis each day, it is often difficult to remember why we have decided to come here.

As an antidote to this itinerary mayhem, walk northwards from the Acropolis to the huge open field, peaceful and engaging, that was the Agora, or market place, of the ancient city. Fringed by the flea markets of Monastiraki and the groaning restaurant tables of the Plaka, the Agora is an ocean of reflective calm. It is as if today's traders have turned their backs on the once-booming commercial and social centre of the city, as so often happened when the classical world collapsed.

Here in Britain, for example, when the Roman legions quit in 409AD, they left their cities intact. But gradually over the next century they lost their original purpose, as each new generation wondered what the temples and forums were intended for. By the early sixth century, many cities were deserted as local tribes camped outside their walls and looked on in awe and ignorance at the crumbling buildings.

As Roman gods eclipsed the Greek, as one God eclipsed the many, as Islam eclipsed Christianity, temples not converted into churches withered and died. Then churches not converted into mosques went the same way.

In Athens under the Ottoman Turks for nearly 500 years until independence in the 1820s, the Parthenon, the crowning glory of the Acropolis, was used as a munitions store. Why not? Its thick walls could keep the gunpowder dry and safe, they thought - though wrongly, as attacking Venetians showed in 1687 when they blew a massive hole in the south side of the building.

Why should the Turks care, though? When a mad British aristocrat wanted some old marble statuary, why not let him have it? After all, such re-creation of the human form was expressly forbidden by the Koran. Now modern Greece wants the Elgin marbles back. It says they help define its soul. It's true, they do. Just as Greece itself helps define our souls, if we allow it.

In the red-brown dimness of the church of the Pantanassa high above the plains of Sparta a small flame burns. It is tended by the nuns of the adjoining convent whose whitewashed cells sparkle in the Lakonic sun. These gentle elderly women are the last people whose home is the mountain fastness of Mystras, a mighty city in its heyday of 40,000 souls and seat of a final efflorescence of Byzantine arts and letters to rival the city of Constantinople itself.

Lower down the mountainside is the cathedral of Agios Dimitrios where, in 1449, on a spot now marked with a double-headed eagle, Constantine XI Palaeologos was crowned 'Believer in Christ Pantokrator and emperor of the Romaioi'. He didn't know it then, as he set out for Constantinople, but he would be the last of the emperors whose throne stretched back 1,500 years to Caesar himself. Four years later the imperial city fell to the Ottomans and seven years after that Mystras too succumbed to the invader.

Bloodthirsty though they may have been (and not alone in that), the Ottoman Turks were God-fearing Muslims, and to others also of the Book they showed a tolerance often remarkable in contrast to their crude cousins in Christendom. Mystras's men and women of letters and arts, pupils of the neoplatonist Gemistos Plethon, may have left to spark the Renaissance in Rome and Florence, though, under the Turks, the churches, convents and monasteries stayed.

Despite that the point of the city, apart from a brief economic boom under Venetian rule from 1687 to 1715, declined and with it inexorably any remaining clerics and monks. But the nuns stayed and their flame, burning through the gloom, lights a singular path not just back to Byzantium, but beyond to the Romans and further to their cultural progenitors, the Greeks of the ancient world; to the world whose codes in law and literature, in art and sport, still so powerfully resonate today; to the world whose cradle is here in the Peloponnese of Greece.

 Michael Holland flew to the Peloponnese via Athens with Sunvil Holidays (020 8568 4499, email greece@sunvil.co.uk) whose fly-drive packages without accommodation start from £411 per person for a week or £492 for a fortnight; those with accommodation start from £567 for a week, or £880 for a fortnight.

But the nuns stayed and their flame, burning through the gloom, lights a singular path not just back to Byzantium, but beyond to the Romans and further to their cultural progenitors, the Greeks of the ancient world; to the world whose codes in law and literature, in art and sport, still so powerfully resonate today; to the world whose cradle is here in the Peloponnese of Greece.  Michael Holland flew to the Peloponnese via Athens with Sunvil Holidays (020 8568 4499, email greece@sunvil.co.uk) whose fly-drive packages without accommodation start from £411 per person for a week or £492 for a fortnight; those with accommodation start from £567 for a week, or £880 for a fortnight.

fields.headline: More breaks on the net
fields.trailText: Two contrasting websites offering weekend breaks were launched last week.
fields.body:
Two contrasting websites offering weekend breaks were launched last week. One - www.webweekends.co.uk - claims to be the first interactive website dedicated to the weekend break market and has a database of 2,000 weekends from 50 leading tour operators. The other - www.weekenderplus.com - allows direct booking at 320 Crowne Plaza, Holiday Inn and Express by Holiday Inn hotels throughout Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

Webweekends is the classic example of a website acting like a new-age travel agent, offering a search facility for holidays from various operators in different categories - such as luxury, spa/health, sports to stag - and matching the choices. Searches can be refined by specifying the budget, location or time of year. Booking is still by phone or email but some of the weekends should be available for online purchase by the end of the year.

Weekenderplus illustrates how suppliers - in this case a hotel chain - can drum up their own business in the net. Savings of up to 60 per cent are offered on this site from Bass Hotels and Resorts, just the ticket for those already booking their own flights on other websites. Bookings can be made online or through a call centre.

webTitle: The old 'uns are still the best 'uns

fields.headline: The old 'uns are still the best 'uns
fields.standfirst: In an age of youthful fluff and flannel, we need a group of wise old men to give televised football focus, writes Martin Kelner
fields.trailText: The critic James Agee once wrote that the film Random Harvest would be enjoyed by anyone "who could with pleasure eat a bowl of Yardley's shaving soap for breakfast".
fields.body:
The critic James Agee once wrote that the film Random Harvest would be enjoyed by anyone "who could with pleasure eat a bowl of Yardley's shaving soap for breakfast".

For some reason the quote came back to me during Saturday afternoon's dismal proceedings in Malta. My humour was not helped by the constant complaints about the Maltese heat, which I gave a less than sympathetic ear as the wind continued to rattle my window frames and the rain fell from a slate-grey west Yorkshire sky.

Just as I was thinking that only the introduction of Michael Owen could possibly lighten the mood, Martin Tyler announced that after the match we would be "getting the thoughts of Jimmy Hill". At last. A reason to sharpen the pencil. Welcome back, Jimmy.

Football's premier curmudgeon dissecting a disappointing England performance; it does not get much better than that. Sky should use him more often. I had not realised just how deeply I was missing him until he started lambasting not only Kevin Keegan but also Glenn Hoddle, Terry Venables and pretty well the entire sports broadcasting establishment. His point was that the time Sky spent interviewing Keegan after the match would be far better employed listening to what he himself had to say, given that all they were likely to get from the England coach was "flannel".

From this promising beginning he launched into a full-blown attack on the readiness with which still working managers take the broadcasters' shilling, and the eagerness of the television companies to employ them in preference to someone who could give them independent expert analysis. Someone such as Jimmy Hill.

"Glenn Hoddle, Terry Venables and Kevin Keegan will all be working with ITV during Euro 2000," said Hill, neatly scuppering Richard Keys's cunning plan to keep quiet about the European championship matches in the hope the audience would not twig they were available elsewhere. "You won't get honesty from these people, because they are not in a position to be honest." It was difficult to disagree.

David O'Leary, for instance, who is part of the BBC's panel, might conceivably be asked to comment on the performance of a player he is trying to sign for Leeds, in which case his views will not be worth the airtime they are granted.

The proposed alternative to the weasel words of football's managerial top table will not come as a total surprise to dedicated Hill-watchers, what with its heavy dependence on the wisdom of a bearded former Coventry City supremo. "I will always give an honest view, because I am a free agent and I have many years of experience," he enthused. "The public deserve that honesty instead of the silken flannel they are getting."

Hill is always at his most entertaining when he mounts his high horse. I distinctly remember him once launching into one of his more pompous perorations with "When I joined the BBC several years ago in a minor capacity..." only to be brought up short by Des Lynam, who said: "You're still in a minor capacity, Jimmy."

I fear Euro 2000 may be sadly lacking that sort of cut and thrust. More and more these days I find that the well-spun views of football's talking heads leave me pining for the kipper-tie era of the 70s and wild men of soccer analysis such as Paddy Crerand and Brian Clough.

There seems to be a dangerous tendency in broadcasting these days to assume that just because somebody is older than the average age of the target audience he no longer has anything of value to contribute. That this is arrant nonsense, whether applied to Andy Kershaw on Radio One or Jimmy Hill on BBC football shows, is a truth of which I become more convinced the older I get.

fields.headline: Our choice
fields.trailText: Overland to Istanbul | Cruising a Broad | Flora in the Dolomites | Family insurance deal
fields.body:
Overland to Istanbul

An overland journey from Cairo to Istanbul via Jordan and Syria is now available at a 25 per cent discount from Dragoman. The four-week tour, departing from Cairo on 3 July, focuses on the Middle East's most important historical sites, including the Roman city of Jerash, the remains of Nabatean Petra dating from the third century BC and the twelfth-century crusader castle Krak des Chevaliers. Dragoman's use of their own rough-terrain Mercedes Benz vehicles mean that connections are never a problem and every need is taken care of with its onboard fridge, library and the services of a two-person crew. The tour costs £520 plus a kitty of £180. The price includes transport, camping, hotel accommodation, all camp meals, but not flights which must be booked separately. Phone 01728 861 133.

Cruising a Broad

Cruising holidays usually bring to mind opulent scenes on the Mediterranean or the Aegean, but it can also mean lazy days on the Norfolk Broads. Blakes Boating offers vessels that sleep from two to 10 people and promises that no expertise is needed to sail them. The cruisers are motor-driven and the short tuition provided before each trip begins ensures passengers can steer in a straight line. Suggested routes take in the River Ant and the River Bure towards Great Yarmouth, or inland to Horning and Wroxham. Many of the boatyards provide bike hire for those picking up boats so people suffering from cabin fever can get out and explore the surrounding countryside. A week's cruising for four people costs £336, with other prices available by phoning 01603 739 400.

Flora in the Dolomites

Alpine botanist Reginald Farrer had no idea what he was starting when he wrote his taxonomy of plant life in the Dolomites at the turn of the last century. His work has become the basis for a Naturetrek holiday in the Fassa Valley during which holidaymakers will have the chance to explore the rich flora of the lowland meadows, including Military, Dwarf and Marsh orchid species. The valley is home to so many different kinds of rock that a wealth of varieties flourish in the different environments. The trip, leaving London on 24 June, is led by expert botanists and follows many of Farrer's routes around the north-eastern Dolomites. The price of £895 includes flights, accommodation, all meals and the guides' services. Phone 01962 733051

Family insurance deal

Holiday insurance can be a problem for families that swing into hyperdrive during the summer, packing several different children off on as many different activity holidays as possible, indulging in older kids' desire to take their first sun holiday with their friends, while still finding time for parents to get a break. MRL insurance has devised an annual multi-trip insurance package that covers members of the same family, or two people of the same sex living at the same address, whether travelling together or separately. Winter sports and school trips are covered, as are young people in full time education up to the age of 23 and all under-18s. An added advantage for more chaotic travellers is that no notice of intention to travel is needed. A family package costs £99, while a couple can be covered for £89. Phone 01737 552100.

fields.headline: Ferguson renews interest in Desailly
fields.trailText: Marcel Desailly's preparations for Euro 2000 took an unexpected twist yesterday when it emerged that Manchester United are keen to sign him.
fields.body:
Marcel Desailly's preparations for Euro 2000 took an unexpected twist yesterday when it emerged that Manchester United are keen to sign him.

Sir Alex Ferguson tried to buy the centre-half three years ago, before Desailly's move to Chelsea, but was defeated by United's wage structure. Now he has reopened negotiations, seeking a world-class partner for Jaap Stam after last season's disappointment in the Champions League.

According to L'Equipe, Ferguson renewed his interest about a month ago. And Desailly made it clear from France's hotel in Casablanca that he could be tempted to move to Old Trafford.

"I know all about the approach from Alex Ferguson," said the 31-year-old. "I'm flattered, because who doesn't dream of playing for Manchester United, even though eight other big European clubs are interested in taking me.

"At the moment I'm a Chelsea player and I must respect the club that employs me. As far as the negotiations are concerned, that's between Chelsea and the interested clubs. To say that Manchester United are a priority for me would be a bit hasty because it's just one proposal, albeit a prestigious one, among several that have come my way."

Desailly's refusal to commit himself to Chelsea will surely disappoint Gianluca Vialli, who would be loth to lose the most experienced and highly rated member of his defence, particularly as Frank Leboeuf announced at the weekend that he plans to leave.

Vialli made Desailly one of his first signings, paying Milan £4.6m two summers ago. He is unlikely to approve of selling the World Cup winner to his key rivals, whom Chelsea must overhaul to win their first league title since 1955.

Not surprisingly, though, Stam was excited at the thought of teaming up with Desailly: "He's powerful, he's fast, he reads the game well. It would be good to play with him. But between him and [Fabien] Barthez I'd better start learning French."

Desailly's agent, Pape Diouf, acknowledged that Chelsea were keen to keep the player but refused to rule out a move. "On the one hand, Marcel is under contract to Chelsea for two more seasons. It's for the club to decide what happens. Colin Hutchison [Chelsea's managing director] is very firm in his position. Marcel is one of his key players. He's counting on him to help build a strong and successful squad for next season. On the other hand it is necessary to take into account other approaches."

Those are believed to include Real Madrid, Lazio and Marseille. If Desailly chooses to leave the Premiership, which he has described as too aggressive at times, he is least likely to opt for Marseille, one of his former clubs, given that they only just avoided relegation in May. Lazio, the Serie A champions, confirmed their interest in December. "We are watching the situation," their president Sergio Cragnotti said then.

Italy seems to be the preferred destination for Leboeuf. He has talked of joining Napoli, who were promoted to Serie A yesterday, after admitting his time was up at Chelsea.

"I have seen everything I meant to see in England and won everything I meant to win," the 32-year-old said. "It has been a good experience... But now I want something different. I would really love to be able to train and play in a warmer climate and appear in front of Latin crowds."

webTitle: Come on in, the central heating's lovely...

fields.headline: Come on in, the central heating's lovely...
fields.standfirst: Kit Spring  found that the cradle of Minoan civilisation is enticing even in the rain
fields.trailText: Kit Spring found that the cradle of Minoan civilisation is enticing even in the rain
fields.body:
It was a bit of a shock, really. We left Britain in the greyest, most drizzly and dreary of springs and flew south to sunshine, blue skies and basking. Well, that's what we thought. But when the plane started to descend towards Chania, in western Crete, we decided we had been duped. The pilot must have just taken a few turns around Gatwick. Because what we were faced with was grey, drizzly, dreary weather.

'It's been lovely,' people told us as we shivered in a taverna by the beach (we got the same cheery comment from friends when we arrived back in Britain a week later). But that old African wind to which Crete can be prone had blown up, covering cars with red Libyan dust and rattling the shutters on our very nice little apartment set on a hillside overlooking the beautiful Bay of Souda.

We had fallen in love with the island on our first visit and this was our third trip, so we weren't fazed by the weather - which turned into glorious sunshine after three days in any case. It was a good opportunity to visit old haunts. Freed from the responsibility of getting a tan, we could spend delicious hours over lunches of small fish and large shrimps by the waterfront in Chania.

The town has what must be one of the most picturesque harbours in the world. Narrow houses in a faded splendour of ice-cream colours - yellow, blue, cream and terracotta - cluster around the front. Behind them is an intertwining of narrow streets and fascinating alleys. We scrambled out along the harbour walls, trying to avoid the odd wave that came crashing over our heads, to the old Venetian lighthouse at the furthest extent. It's a slightly perilous climb, but the view to the sea pounding and foaming on the rocks below was worth it. In the summer you can drink elaborate cocktails by the water's edge, and watch the sun set in a frenzy of vivid colours. As it wasn't summer, we cut straight to dinner in Dino's, which is by the old harbour - for succulent calamari and swordfish, followed by shots of raki.

Our previous visits had been in the summer, when the sun soaks into your bones and the cicadas shriek so loudly they can be heard above the engine as you drive along. It was curious to be on the island at the start of the season and see a different set of visitors from the sun-seekers who come later.

Plenty of people go to Crete in April and May to avoid the crowds at the ancient sites such as Knossos, to ramble and bird-watch in the mountains and to delight in the wild flowers that cover the hillsides and colour the olive groves. Unlike us, they come sensibly equipped with anoraks and walking shoes.

We were used to the sun baking down on the streets and having to slip from one harshly etched shadow to another. It was a novelty to see a hastily hand-written notice put out by someone who knew an opportunity when he saw one: 'Come inside. We have central heating!' And it was a pleasure to linger over the stalls in Chania's 'Leather Lane' and take our time picking up bargains (a pair of sandals for £10, a bag for £12). The town has a wonderful covered market, full of cheese, nuts, herbs, honey, fish and vegetables, where you can pick up supper for that evening if you choose to stay in. The only problem is that it's hard not to buy everything in sight and the tavernas offer such cheap and delicious food that you're torn between the two.

Western Crete is less developed than the north-east of the island, but has everything you need if you're into beaches, tavernas, charming villages and Byzantine monasteries, rather than a rip-roaring nightlife. Our apartment was a short drive from the airport in the village of Megala Chorafia. Behind us, the White Mountains soared with snow still settled in stripes down their grey flanks. Below us, the hillside - populated by bell-tinkling sheep - fell away to the Bay of Souda. This is the sea into which Icarus (You've gone a bit too far this time, son!) fell to his death. Its colour changes breathtakingly as the day draws on - blues, greens and patches of indigo smooth into a plate of beaten silver by the evening. Tiny fishing smacks bringing home the catch are brave dots on the water and the great white ferry from Souda heads out towards Piraeus.

Crete is, of course, famous for its ancient sites such as the Minoan palace of Knossos near Heraklion on the north coast. This is where King Minos ruled and Theseus slew the Minotaur. The palace, which was at the heart of a thriving civilisation 3,000 years ago, has been carefully excavated and restored. We had marvelled at Knossos on previous trips, so we turned our attention this time to the ruins of Aptera above Megala Chorafia, a short walk from our apartment. This was one of the island's most important cities from the fifth century BC into early Christian times. Neglected for years, the ruins and land round about have been bought up by the Ministry of Culture and are now being carefully excavated.

The experience is more immediate than Knossos because there are no turnstiles or cafés and not many people - it's quite easy to find yourself alone, although that will change as the site is developed.

We walked up the hillside, and suddenly there were massive walls ahead of us and vast Roman cisterns stretching along the way. You can wander at will, and the ancient feeling of the place seeps into you as you imagine the feet that trod the same path hundreds of years ago. It doesn't take much imagination to edit the houses out of the view, and see what the original inhabitants must have seen as they gazed out from the old Roman fort.

We spotted a large old vaulted building set back along a track, and went to investigate. Peering into the gloom inside, we realised it was flooded with murky, still, green water. Cold, full of shadows and quiet as the grave apart from the distorted and echoed cooings of invisible pigeons, the place seemed haunted.

We shivered and moved gladly back into the sun, taking the path up to the Turkish fort which stands on the edge of the mountain, commanding a view across the bay that takes your breath away, though I doubt the soldiers posted there in the old days took much delight in it.

On our last day the sun was blazing and we returned to a favourite spot, the nearby village of Kalives, which has a fine beach (biggish waves one end and a calm shallow bay the other) and the best taverna we know - Manoli's, which is by the beach and profuse with flowering plants and friendly service. We had Manoli's special salad, a divine bowl of shrimps, ham, cheese, eggs, lettuce and tomatoes in a tangy sauce.

Bliss is sitting here in sun-dappled shade among a riot of geraniums, ice-cold Amstel by our side, the sun bouncing diamonds off the sea. Ahead lies a six-hour delay at the airport. But we don't know that yet. And we're completely happy.

 Kit Spring travelled with Simply Crete (020 8541 2277). Seven nights self-catering at the Aptera apartments in Megala Chorafia, overlooking Souda Bay, costs from £496 to £598 per person including flights from Gatwick or Heathrow and car hire. There is a £20 supplement for aManchester flight and £50 for Cardiff. Simply Crete has a special offer of £399 per person to the Marika Apartments near Expolis and the White Mountains for 20 June departures.

It was curious to be on the island at the start of the season and see a different set of visitors from the sun-seekers who come later. Plenty of people go to Crete in April and May to avoid the crowds at the ancient sites such as Knossos, to ramble and bird-watch in the mountains and to delight in the wild flowers that cover the hillsides and colour the olive groves. Unlike us, they come sensibly equipped with anoraks and walking shoes. We were used to the sun baking down on the streets and having to slip from one harshly etched shadow to another. It was a novelty to see a hastily hand-written notice put out by someone who knew an opportunity when he saw one: 'Come inside. We have central heating!' And it was a pleasure to linger over the stalls in Chania's 'Leather Lane' and take our time picking up bargains (a pair of sandals for £10, a bag for £12). The town has a wonderful covered market, full of cheese, nuts, herbs, honey, fish and vegetables, where you can pick up supper for that evening if you choose to stay in. The only problem is that it's hard not to buy everything in sight and the tavernas offer such cheap and delicious food that you're torn between the two. Western Crete is less developed than the north-east of the island, but has everything you need if you're into beaches, tavernas, charming villages and Byzantine monasteries, rather than a rip-roaring nightlife. Our apartment was a short drive from the airport in the village of Megala Chorafia. Behind us, the White Mountains soared with snow still settled in stripes down their grey flanks. Below us, the hillside - populated by bell-tinkling sheep - fell away to the Bay of Souda. This is the sea into which Icarus (You've gone a bit too far this time, son!) fell to his death. Its colour changes breathtakingly as the day draws on - blues, greens and patches of indigo smooth into a plate of beaten silver by the evening. Tiny fishing smacks bringing home the catch are brave dots on the water and the great white ferry from Souda heads out towards Piraeus. Crete is, of course, famous for its ancient sites such as the Minoan palace of Knossos near Heraklion on the north coast. This is where King Minos ruled and Theseus slew the Minotaur. The palace, which was at the heart of a thriving civilisation 3,000 years ago, has been carefully excavated and restored. We had marvelled at Knossos on previous trips, so we turned our attention this time to the ruins of Aptera above Megala Chorafia, a short walk from our apartment. This was one of the island's most important cities from the fifth century BC into early Christian times. Neglected for years, the ruins and land round about have been bought up by the Ministry of Culture and are now being carefully excavated. The experience is more immediate than Knossos because there are no turnstiles or cafés and not many people - it's quite easy to find yourself alone, although that will change as the site is developed. We walked up the hillside, and suddenly there were massive walls ahead of us and vast Roman cisterns stretching along the way. You can wander at will, and the ancient feeling of the place seeps into you as you imagine the feet that trod the same path hundreds of years ago. It doesn't take much imagination to edit the houses out of the view, and see what the original inhabitants must have seen as they gazed out from the old Roman fort. We spotted a large old vaulted building set back along a track, and went to investigate. Peering into the gloom inside, we realised it was flooded with murky, still, green water. Cold, full of shadows and quiet as the grave apart from the distorted and echoed cooings of invisible pigeons, the place seemed haunted. We shivered and moved gladly back into the sun, taking the path up to the Turkish fort which stands on the edge of the mountain, commanding a view across the bay that takes your breath away, though I doubt the soldiers posted there in the old days took much delight in it. On our last day the sun was blazing and we returned to a favourite spot, the nearby village of Kalives, which has a fine beach (biggish waves one end and a calm shallow bay the other) and the best taverna we know - Manoli's, which is by the beach and profuse with flowering plants and friendly service. We had Manoli's special salad, a divine bowl of shrimps, ham, cheese, eggs, lettuce and tomatoes in a tangy sauce. Bliss is sitting here in sun-dappled shade among a riot of geraniums, ice-cold Amstel by our side, the sun bouncing diamonds off the sea. Ahead lies a six-hour delay at the airport. But we don't know that yet. And we're completely happy.  Kit Spring travelled with Simply Crete (020 8541 2277). Seven nights self-catering at the Aptera apartments in Megala Chorafia, overlooking Souda Bay, costs from £496 to £598 per person including flights from Gatwick or Heathrow and car hire. There is a £20 supplement for aManchester flight and £50 for Cardiff. Simply Crete has a special offer of £399 per person to the Marika Apartments near Expolis and the White Mountains for 20 June departures.

fields.headline: Complementary covers
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Cook on guide books
fields.trailText: Jonathan Cook on guide books.
fields.body:
Insight Guide:
Greek Islands
APA Publications
£16.99

There's something about the Insight Guides - they're too pristine, too glossy and just too damn heavy to risk taking along on holiday. Better to flick through the pages before you go to whet your appetite and then savour the book as a souvenir on your return.

Apart from gorgeous photographs - as you would expect from the Insight series - this guide offers quirky and often fascinating titbits in the side panels and lively background features on the people, customs and places. The only criticism is that maybe this book is trying to do too much and in the process has sacrificed detail about the islands themselves.

Crete Condensed
Lonely Planet
£5.99

Is this what those who travel light have been waiting for? Lonely Planet describes its new six-title series as the ultimate pocket guides and I'm tempted to agree. Rather than treating the island geographically, the Condensed gives us the highlights thematically. So there are colour-coded sections on the best sights, shopping, eating, entertainment etc.

Nothing is deemed worthy of more than a page (and a small picture) but somehow nothing seems to be missed either. The format works brilliantly but LP may have problems expanding the series' range beyond islands and big cities. Oh, and it really does fit in a pocket!

AA Essential:
Mainland Greece
AA Publishing
£4.99

OK, so the AA series is cheap. And that's about the best compliment I can pay these little guides.

This one deals with mainland Greece in about the same space the Lonely Planet Condensed dedicates just to Crete.

If you're on a package holiday or passing through on business, this guide will probably give you some ideas for add-ons to your trip. But if you're trying to organise anything complicated for yourself, or want to get below the surface of the country, you'll come away little the wiser. Essential it isn't. Invest in a grown-up guide instead.

Eyewitness Travel Guide:
The Greek Islands
Dorling Kindersley
£15.99

The Eyewitness guides are like that great teacher who finally made sense of maths or history for you. This guide takes the dry, worthy stuff of travel - such as archaeology, flora and fauna or architecture - and makes it come alive. The same pictorial quality is brought to other subjects, including a photographic menu of Greek dishes more enticing than anything you're likely to see in a restaurant window. Where it falls down is on practical tips. If you're doing any serious island-hopping, this guide may not stop you missing the boat. But you'll find it indispensable in helping you to decide which boat to catch.

Rhodes and the Dodecanese
Dana Facaros
Cadogan
£9.99

How does the Cadogan series survive when the guides still look like something your grandparents might have taken with them on their holidays in the Forties? The Dodecanese guide, with its ridiculous line drawings, feeble maps and grey pages of text, makes absolutely no concession to its glossy and design-led competitors. But it must have something. And the answer is to be found in the selection of the author, who brings a personal and intimate knowledge to the things she writes about - if you can find what you're looking for amid all that greyness. But £9.99? It's too much.

The Ionian Islands
Rough Guides
£8.99

If you're serious about your travelling, the Rough Guide is still probably indispensable. It provides just about all the information you need apart from comprehensive island-by-island ferry timetables.

That said, there is something a little tired -and po-faced - about the formula. Lots of anoraky detail about what each town and village has to offer, but no help with deciding what's a must-see. It's not as though the handful of pictures provide much of a clue either. Take the Rough Guide along because you'll need it - but treat yourself to something more exciting too.

fields.headline: The island of quiet revelations
fields.standfirst: Introducing our Greek Special, Robert McCrum follows St John the Divine - and Madonna - to Patmos, the sacred island where the rituals of the monks transport travellers back through the centuries
fields.trailText: Introducing our Greek Special, Robert McCrum follows St John the Divine - and Madonna - to Patmos, the sacred island where the rituals of the monks transport travellers back through the centuries
fields.body:
'It is, of course, a dream.' The professorial-looking German tour guide standing near the prow of the Flying Dolphin hydrofoil to Patmos is gazing intently at the Cubist jumble of whitewashed houses gleaming in the sunshine on the distant island mountaintop. He is leading a tour of middle-aged Germans on a millennial tour via Chios (Homer), and Samos (Pythagoras), and all around us are the inspiring waters of the Aegean, the nautical thoroughfare of classical Greece.

'This is where all the big ideas are, jah?' I try to respond to his conversation with cunning references to the Iliad and the square of the hypotenuse, but he's not really interested. Patmos, home of St John the Divine, is the one he cares about. 'I have been here four, five, six times, but for me it is always the thing I am looking forward to. St John, you know, was imprisoned here. I wish I am being so lucky.'

Patmos ('the island of the revelation') is a dream in another sense, too. It offers the Greek Island Experience (limpid water, unspoilt beaches, vagrant goat herds, etc etc) in an almost pre-tourist form. Although at the height of the summer season its main port, Skala, plays host to a procession of cruise ships disgorging busloads of package trip visitors on a whistle-stop tour of the holy sites, Patmos has managed to retain some independence and dignity. It also sustains a certain measure of cool, offering an occasional refuge for stars such as Richard Gere, David Bowie and Madonna, and minor royalty.

Skala lies at the centre of the island, guarding the narrow isthmus that links the northern and southern peninsulas. People say that Patmos resembles a Greek Omega, but I couldn't see it. Perhaps just as fancifully, it describes the quirky curves of a seahorse, and measures, from north to south no more than about 12 miles. An energetic visitor can see it all in 48 hours.

Another part of the island's charm, and perhaps the key to its character, is its remoteness. Piraeus, the port of Athens, is nearly 200 miles away, or 12 hours sailing on one of the converted cross-Channel steamers that ply the Aegean in the hectic summer months. Alternatively, you can fly to Samos, or to Kos, and take a Flying Dolphin, a resprayed hydrofoil from the Soviet Union. Either way, Patmos is too much of a trek for the wet T-shirt brigade.

Which is just as well, because the island has a history that goes back to the day Zeus gave it to his daughter Artemis as a birthday present. Another legend, which is weirdly available in the Monastery of St John the Divine, says that Orestes, pursued by the Furies for the murder of his mother, took refuge here, and built the temple of Artemis. Pagan, or Orthodox Christian, Patmos is steeped in some consoling myths.

The biggest of these, of course, is the story of St John. In Protestant Christianity, he is St John the Divine, and quite distinct from the author of the gospels, as if the mind that could come up with the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse and all that stuff about Armageddon and Babylon the Great, the Mother of Harlots and Abominations of the Earth was simply too outrageously exotic to share a credit with the author of the fourth gospel. The Greeks will have none of this. To them, he is St John the Evangelist, the disciple who in AD95 was banished here by the Emperor Domitian.

The exiled John became the island's teacher, and brought the people of Patmos to Christ. He himself lived a simple, spiritual existence in a cave overlooking the sea. It was here that he heard 'a great voice, as of a trumpet', and saw a figure 'like unto the son of man' who instructed him to set down the apocalyptic vision known as The Book of Revelations.

Say what you like about 'I saw a new heaven and a new earth' as theology, in tourist terms, it was a masterstroke. Overnight, Patmos became the Mount Sinai of Greece and, after the Temple in Jerusalem, one of the holiest sites in the Christian world. Pilgrims, sacred and profane, have been com ing here ever since. The 'Sacred Cavern', a natural opening in the elephant-grey rock of the hillside, is now cluttered with the tatty, iconographic paraphernalia peculiar to religious shrines, and lies midway between the port of Skala and the hilltop town of Hora. It remains the focus of every tourist visit, and some, like the German on the hydrofoil, can't get enough of it.

In the 'sacred cave', according to the Patmos guidebook, 'a person's ego melts into the essence of God and merges with Him and with the soul of the great Seer hovering inside the Cavern. He can almost hear Almighty God saying, "I am Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the end"...'

Well, maybe. Today, you are more likely to hear a Greek-American teenager from Detroit complaining that her mobile phone has lost its signal. Greece, in the years since the dark days of the Colonels, has become transformed by international tourism. Swimming pools, air-conditioning units, airstrips, the onyx and marble Athens underground, and Captain Corelli's Mandolin have all played their part in the modernisation of the land of the Hellenes.

Capitalism has inevitably brought corruption, and not even the monks of the Monastery of St John have been able to escape the lure of Mammon. The monastery's former abbot, Bishop Isodoros of Tralleon, is one of four monks who now face criminal indictments for embezzlement on a colossal scale (as much as £500 million, according to some reports). These charges have inevitably been accompanied by lurid and hard-to-prove stories of under-the-cassock impropriety, both sexual and financial.

Despite this, Patmos offers a society which, behind the garish facade of globalisation, seems closer to the world of St John than St Dow Jones. On Patmos, for instance, once you get away from downtown Skala - two minutes on a moped - you are in a world of whitewashed domatia and remote, shingly beaches with quiet, secluded coves. This is the Aegean paradise to which so many want to escape.

Escape. Patmos seems to embody the word. Almost everyone I met or spoke with seemed to be playing truant from their lives in some way. There were the various delightful representatives of Laskarina Holidays, each of whom had in different ways turned their backs on the rat-race and suburban normality. There was Mrs Scoutari, the formidable proprietor of the island's premier luxury hotel, the Scoutari, who told me that it was the 'Greek way' to 'live in the present'. There was Theodora 'Doris', the Greek Australian who came to Patmos for love, and now runs a harbourside gift shop. Her dream, she said, was 'to retire to Australia'.

And then there was Wayne, the refugee from Canvey Island. I found him in George's Place, the beachside taverna in which he has worked for several years (he is also a partner in the business). An ex-merchant seaman, he had come to Patmos in the Seventies on a whim, fallen in love with the place, become a 'beach bum' and devoted himself to the stone-by-stone construction of a mountain-top eyrie that has become, in Patmos circles, a byword for English eccentricity. He acknowledges the escapism, but is unabashed about his motives: 'Everyone has their reasons for being here.' Wayne is a loner ('I like the solitude'), and Patmos is an island for loners.

Looking down on Patmos from Wayne's roof, it's obvious that another part of the island's appeal is its size and the profound sense that it conveys of centuries of religious settlement. On many hilltops, and in many secret rocky valleys, you find tiny whitewashed churches and chapels, the legacy of the Patmian tradition of consecrating shrines to the memory of loved ones.

The ultimate Patmos shrine, of course, is the monastery at the top of the hill in Hora. On my last night I climbed the darkened, blustery steps to observe the name-day Vigil for the island's saint. The tiny chapel of Christodoulous contains some incredibly sacred treasures, including the skull of Doubting Thomas, which is about as good as you get in the relic business. Inside, lit by guttering candles, enacting a scene that could have been a hundred, even a thousand years old, the monks of the monastery were lost in a monotonous, hypnotic chanting, a kind of ecclesiastical jazz that would continue, I was assured, until the small hours. The air was clogged with incense and the smoke of tallow. The shadowy Coptic faces of the monks glowed in the yellow religious gloom like icons. While it's not what most people go to the Greek islands for, it does add another dimension to the experience.

 Robert McCrum travelled to Patmos with Laskarina (01629 822203). Seven nights B&B at the Porto Scoutari Hotel costs from £505 including flights from Gatwick and transfers.

fields.headline: Getting there... and getting around
fields.trailText: By air: Athens airport is the main hub for travel onwards to the islands. Prices for easyJet flights to and from Luton and Athens range from £47.50 to £177.50 and can be bought online at www.easyjet.co.uk or on 0870 6 000 000. British Airways has special World Offers to Athens from £153, but return flights are usually over £200. Call 0845 773 3377 or try www.british-airways.com. Olympic Airways (0870 606 0460 or www.olympic-airways.gr) fly from Heathrow to Athens three times daily (from £209) and from Gatwick to Thessalonika once a day. They also handle most of the internal flights.

By sea: Few islands have airports so most travel between islands is done by ferry. The major operators have websites, which are worth checking for up-to-date prices and routes. Try: www.agapitos-ferries.gr; www.anek.gr; www.minoan.gr; www.strintzis.gr; and www.ventouris.gr

fields.headline: Labour in the 'political wilderness'
fields.standfirst:
Former Labour deputy leader Roy Hattersley argues that the anodyne debate on elitism over the last fortnight masks Tony Blair's central dilemma: in politics anyone who is afraid to make enemies loses friends

Education Unlimited
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: It had to happen. A government which prides itself on its contempt for ideology, led by a Prime Minister who despises 'tribal loyalty', was bound to lose its way. And for most of May, Labour wandered through the political wilderness without map or compass.
fields.body:
It had to happen. A government which prides itself on its contempt for ideology, led by a Prime Minister who despises 'tribal loyalty', was bound to lose its way. And for most of May, Labour wandered through the political wilderness without map or compass.

The assault on Oxbridge élitism - about number 127 in the list of educational priorities - illustrated the penalties of clutching principles out of the air. On the evidence, Tony Blair remains temperamentally incapable of charting a steady course. That is because of his reluctance to make the enemies which philosophical consistency inevitably creates. In politics, anyone who is afraid to make enemies loses friends.

The Prime Minister is the consensus man. That is less a tribute to his emollient character than proof of his contempt for philosophic speculation. He really does believe - against all the evidence - that the rich and poor have a community of interests. Whenever he toys with a new political theory - stakeholding, communitarianism, the Third Way - it is always in the hope of finding a formula which justifies ecumenical government.

His innocence of economic reality was encapsulated in the single phrase which was the keynote of his address to last year's party conference: 'The class war is over.' In truth, it will continue for as long as there are classes. Tony Blair, who believes in meritocracy, aspires to no more than shifting patterns of inequality. In the sort of society which he wants to build, class conflicts are unavoidable.

No doubt Blair is worried about the class war's Marxist overtones. Perhaps he believes that it is best illustrated by the storming of the Winter Palace. But its existence is recognised by philosophers from every position in the political spectrum. John Rawls explained that in a free society 'liberties collide with one another' and that it is the duty of a democratic government to adjudicate between the conflicting demands of different sections of society. Those conflicts are the class war. And it is Tony Blair's wilful refusal to adjudicate between different groups which has blurred his government's image.

The idea that politicians of good will can meet everybody's need simultaneously is sentimental nonsense. Talk of being 'fair' gets us nowhere. 'Fairness' means different things to different people. To Hayek, it is rewards allocated by the unrestricted market, but to Tawney it is active promotion of greater equality. Only an ideological definition of that notion can give 'fairness' an honest meaning. Pretending 'we all know what it means' is the death of decisive government.

The Government has just lived through a textbook example of the unavoidable conflicts that divide our society. It was called 'the right to roam'. Hikers wanted freedom to walk the countryside. Landowners were determined to preserve the privacy of their property. Those two demands cannot be reconciled. Attempts at compromise - limited access supervised by a regulatory authority, headed by a vocal opponent of extended access - left everyone dissatisfied. In local Labour parties, they accuse Tony Blair of being on the side of power and privilege. He is not guilty of that offence. His problem is not knowing whose side he is on.

Whenever there is a conflict of class interest, the Government favours an uneasy compromise. The minimum wage is set at barely above subsistence level. The social chapter of the Maastricht Treaty is adopted in part. Most recently, the ancient universities are excoriated for giving preference to applicants from public schools, but Eton and Harrow are allowed to keep their charitable status and therefore enjoy what amounts to a tax subsidy.

Cynics will say that the juggling of favours is part of New Labour's preoccupation with public relations. If that is so, the Prime Minister needs to employ new image advisers. The balancing act pleases nobody and the Government looks infirm of purpose.

Yet, even last week, John Prescott intoned the old mantra about 'not falling into the Tory trap of seeming to represent only one section of the country'. The danger, at least in terms of re-election with a large majority, is not that Labour will look as if it cares only for the heartlands, but that it will appear not to care for them enough. Nobody suggests that they are totally neglected. They are part of the perceived consensus. But these are grouped in society - the unemployed poor, the old and the ethnic minorities - who need the Government to discriminate in their favour, even if that means reducing the benefits enjoyed by more privileged parts of the community.

As the gap between rich and poor widens, families at the bottom of the heap (who are poorer than they were three years ago in absolute as well as relative terms) are entitled to have a clear view on the class war. If it is over, somebody needs to start it again.

When the Government does accept the need for a limited measure of redistribution, it denies that it is taking from the rich to give to the poor. Instead, it announces that every stratum of society has an equal interest in increased prosperity. That view of economic progress is romantic but wrong. Unregulated economic growth invariably benefits the rich and by-passes the poor. The idea that as long as the rich get richer, the poor become less poor is, in reality, the discredited trickle-down effect. Kenneth Galbraith compares it to the notion that the best way to help sparrows is feed high-quality grain to thoroughbred horses thus producing more digestible ordure. It is a strange theory to be adopted by a government which calls itself Labour.

The lesson of the last few weeks is that anodyne politics do not pay - even in terms of opinion-poll popularity. A government without a guiding light loses its way in the gloom of the middle ground. Perhaps the New Labour leadership cannot be persuaded that taking sides is morally right. But at least it ought to understand that it is politically essential.

webTitle: Government should address the root cause of failure

fields.headline: Government should address the root cause of failure
fields.standfirst:
Rather than attacking excellence in our educational establishments, Government spokesman should be addressing the root cause of failure in our schools, says Michael Portillo

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: What can be the explanation for three of the most senior members of the Government - the Chancellor, Foreign Secretary and Deputy Prime Minister - straying beyond their departmental briefs and demeaning their offices, in order to launch ill-informed attacks on British universities?
fields.body:
What can be the explanation for three of the most senior members of the Government - the Chancellor, Foreign Secretary and Deputy Prime Minister - straying beyond their departmental briefs and demeaning their offices, in order to launch ill-informed attacks on British universities?

Superficially, this was a diversionary tactic, intended to distract attention from Labour's failure in office to deliver any improvement in public services. Class sizes have increased and the waiting list to see a consultant is up by 154,000. There are fewer policemen and crime is rising. The pensioners are disillusioned with a 75 pence increase, which doesn't begin to cover the extra stealth taxes that they have to pay. The Labour heartlands feel abandoned, as 200 manufacturing jobs disappear every day.

The attacks marked a return to old Labour themes cherished by Brown, Cook and Prescott. They believe there are votes in attacking excellence, because it can be misrepresented as élitism or privilege. Their instinct is to level down; egalitarianism is more important than raising expectations.

Teaching in Britain has been afflicted for decades by leftist theories devised in some of our university departments of education and enthusiastically applied by Labour education authorities. Such thinking discouraged rigour, competition and comparison. Under the influence of Tony Crosland, many great state schools were destroyed. The Left in Britain lowered the expectations of pupils from humble backgrounds.

My own state grammar school disappeared in the wash of such thinking, though it was actually abolished under a Conservative government. In its last year, it sent 22 pupils to Oxford and Cambridge, 21 of them with exhibitions or scholarships. There are few state schools today that set their sights so high. Educational achievement in Britain has been running at about half the level of Germany and France, based on the proportion of A to C passes at GCSE or equivalent.

Mr Blunkett and Margaret Hodge, in their days as council leaders, have played their part in lowering standards and dashing the hopes of a generation of pupils from modest backgrounds. Mr Blair and Harriet Harman, in the choices they have made for their own children's education, have demonstrated that those parents who can afford to do so avoid the mess that such local education authorities have created.

Is it not then a bit rich for Ministers to rail against the universities, for not taking more students from state schools? The evidence is that the colleges go out of their way to spot potential in those who have been educated in schools that expected too little of them. Magdalen College, Oxford didn't offer Laura Spence a place to read medicine, but of the five accepted, two were from state schools and three from ethnic minorities. Our universities are coping as best they can with a genuine dilemma: to what extent should they lower their own standards and expectations to accommodate young people damaged by the shortcomings of their schools or LEAs?

The success of the public schools is deeply offensive to the Government. They demonstrate not only what wealth can purchase, but also what rigour, discipline and high expectations can achieve.

The last Conservative government was not particularly successful in rooting out political correctness from the university departments of education. But it struck an important blow against the levelling down of schools. The grant-maintained schools received their money directly from government and they were free to create their own ethos. Labour hated them because they were different and because they moved ahead. They offended Labour's demand for uniformity. There can be no advance in education standards unless we allow schools the freedom to do things differently, and some will indeed get ahead.They will be the schools in demand.

To me, the difference between Conservative and Labour education policy illustrates a fundamental philosophical divide. Labour believes that change for good in society comes about by the actions of government. We believe it derives from the actions of people. Conservatives believe that if you empower a headteacher, great results may well follow. The grant-maintained schools gave heads responsibility and encouraged them to use their initiative. Standards and expectations soared.

Tony Blair once said that what matters is what works, and that standards, not structures, were important. Why then, were GM schools destroyed? Why did he legislate to enable grammar schools to be abolished by ballot? Recently, Mr Blunkett was heard to muse about passing more money directly to schools. What credibility can he claim, when he swept away the mechanism, the grant-maintained school, which achieved precisely that?

It seems that the new Mr Blunkett, the Education Secretary rather than the leader of Sheffield City Council, has some inkling of the damage that leftist policies have done and of the poor condition of state education. But he remains pinned down by dogma to set our schools free, to do as the Conservatives propose, and pass money directly to schools, which will run themselves.

A pity, because what matters is what works.

webTitle: Harvard: Even more élitist than Oxbridge

fields.headline: Harvard: Even more élitist than Oxbridge
fields.standfirst:
Maureen Freely, who conducts interviews in Britain on behalf of Harvard, warns students that they are applying to an institution even more élitist than Oxbridge

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: As the great Laura Spence Debate enters its second week, there seems to be only one thing on which all parties are in agreement - the more they fret about Oxford and its élitist ways, the more convinced they are that Harvard has all the answers.
fields.body:
As the great Laura Spence Debate enters its second week, there seems to be only one thing on which all parties are in agreement - the more they fret about Oxford and its élitist ways, the more convinced they are that Harvard has all the answers.

Although they note in passing that your typical four-year Harvard undergraduate course costs $140,000 and is therefore beyond the range of most American families, they go on to admire Harvard's 'need-blind' admissions policy and the generous financial aid programme that underpins it. I spent my four years at Harvard on a need-based scholarship that was even more generous than the one they've offered Laura. Never once during that time did I feel this put me at a social disadvantage. There was as many of 'us' as there were of 'them.'

It's the same today. Harvard continues to take the question of diversity very seriously. About half of its 6,500 undergraduates receive at least some financial aid from Harvard, with the average award running at $18,000. Of the 2,035 applicants who were accepted for entry in the autumn, 16.1 per cent were Asian-American, 9.9 per cent were African-American, 8.8 per cent were Puerto Rican or Hispanic-American, 1 per cent were Native-American, and 8 per cent were from abroad.

When they file into Memorial Hall this September, they will all hear the same thing I did when I sat in there in 1970 - no matter where they come from, from now on they all have equal standing, as members of tomorrow's ruling élite. Now, you don't get more inclusive than that, do you? But there are a few things you should know.

Let's begin with the thing you cannot know, because the university's Office of Public Affairs has decided not to tell you. There are no figures for the number of students who come from private schools and the number who come from state schools. Neither is there a breakdown that might tell you how many students come from suburban schools (for which read middle class) and how many come from inner cities. We cannot know how many of the students who have been awarded need-based scholarships on the basis of their academic prowess, and how many are there by virtue of being the state butterfly champion. But the most important thing we cannot know is how many of its students are sons and daughters of Harvard graduates.

The legatee system (the practice of giving preferential treatment to the children of alumni) is not specific to Harvard. In a very real way, it is what makes US private higher education possible. If Harvard stands out from the crowd, it is because no other institution can match its game. Here, as elsewhere, the system depends on the rules remaining somewhat shadowy. The line you will get from the admissions people is that 'all things being equal,' a parent who is a Harvard graduate can be a 'factor.' But the message we graduates get from the fund-raising department is rather different.

A word on 'all things being equal'. There were more applicants this year who scored perfect marks on their standardised maths or verbal aptitude tests than there were available places. As a rule, people just don't bother to apply to Harvard unless they're in the very top percentiles. They also do not apply unless they are willing to contribute their own earnings and their families are willing to take out large loans on their behalf.

This means that the pool of candidates is largely a middle-class pool, in which most things are already pretty equal. As one old classmate puts it: 'It is common knowledge among North American Harvard alumni that having one or more Harvard parents in your gene pool is an enormous help.'

Granted, this complacency is dented almost annually by scare stories about very giving captains of industry who fail to get their children past the post. Even so, the system is heavily weighted in our favour. We all know that it is thanks to us that Harvard is the richest university in the world and that it will only continue to be America's most powerful centre of excellence if we keep up the good work.

The campaign for donations reaches fever pitch as the time approaches for alumnae to pack their bags for their twenty-fifth reunion - a six day extravaganza that will begin for the class of 1975 tomorrow evening. What will their class gift add up to? I wonder. Will they be able to top my class, the class of 1974? Just this time last year, we gave $14 million. Well, I suppose I should be honest. They, the 50 per cent who earn more than $200,000, were the ones who gave most of it. When I canvassed my old scholarship friends, I couldn't find a single one who had given more than $100. But even the scholarship students who had made good in Wall Street had not come near to matching the ones who had been born into the sorts of families that have made Harvard what it is.

Boys and girls from these backgrounds give double value - not only do they pay their own way; as generous alumnae, they go on to pay everyone else's, too. They run the show, for the simple reason that the show would not go on without them. For all their impressive outreach programmes, their most important programme is still affirmative action for the rich.

If we allow the Government to continue to run down state subsidies for higher education, we could see the same thing happening here. So now's the time to sit down and ask yourself - is this really what you want?
