webTitle: PM wades into assault on elitism

fields.headline: PM wades into assault on elitism
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited: elitism special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will enter the elitism debate for the first time this week when he uses a keynote speech on Wednesday to continue the Government's attack on the British establishment.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will enter the elitism debate for the first time this week when he uses a keynote speech on Wednesday to continue the Government's attack on the British establishment.

Blair will say that he is against all elitism, whether it is in universities, the medical profession or the judiciary. He will say that opportunity for all is nothing to do with the class war or envy, but about making sure of equal opportunity.

The Prime Minister hopes that his speech will move the elitism debate on and distance the Government from the row over Laura Spence, the Tyneside comprehensive pupil rejected by Oxford.

The Cabinet is split over the way Gordon Brown kicked the issue onto front pages when he called Spence's treatment 'scandalous' and said Oxford and Cambridge are biased against state schools.

Ministers, including David Blunkett, the Education Secretary, have expressed concern that the Spence affair has clouded the message on elitism.

fields.headline: Your privacy ends here
fields.standfirst:
A Bill which is slipping through the House of Lords will allow MI5 access to all our online communications, says John Naughton. It could mean we're all guilty until proven innocent. So why don't we care more?

Free speech on the net: special report
fields.trailText: A Bill which is slipping through the House of Lords will allow MI5 access to all our online communications, says John Naughton. It could mean we're all guilty until proven innocent. So why don't we care more?
fields.body:
When you wake on Thursday 5 October next, you will find yourself living in a different country. An ancient bulwark of English law - the principle that someone is presumed innocent until proven guilty - will have been overturned. And that is just for starters. From that date also the police and security services will enjoy sweeping powers to snoop on your email traffic and web use without let or hindrance from the Commissioner for Data Protection.

Every UK internet service provider (ISP) will have to install a black box which monitors all the data-traffic passing through its computers, hard-wired to a special centre currently being installed in MI5's London headquarters. This new mass surveillance facility is called the Government Technical Assistance Centre (GTAC). Who said Jack Straw had no sense of humour?

The Regulation of Investigatory Powers (RIP) Bill which is now before the Lords gives the Home Secretary powers of interception and surveillance which would be the envy of the most draconian regime. In addition to encroaching on civil liberties, the same Bill will also drive hordes of e-commerce companies from Britain to countries like Ireland where their encryption keys - extended pin numbers allowing users to decipher jumbled data - will be protected from government prying. An administration which complains continually about making Britain 'the most e-friendly country in the world' by 2002 is busily making sure that exactly the opposite happens.

How has this extraordinary state of affairs come about? Is it another manifestation of the cock-up theory of history, or are there more sinister forces at work? The answer is a bit of both. For some time, it has been obvious to Ministers and civil servants that British law needed updating to cope with the internet. In an era when online trading becomes ubiquitous, for example, some way has to be found of making 'digital signatures' legally valid. Accordingly, a special Cabinet Office unit headed by Professor Jim Norton set to work to devise a new legislative framework for the emerging world of e-commerce and online communications. The main result of his labour was the Electronic Commerce Bill.

As that Bill went through its Parliamentary hoops, it became clear that some parts of it - mainly the sections dealing with data encryption, interception and surveillance - were so deeply flawed that they threatened to sink the Bill. Given the Government's desire to make headway on the e-commerce front, the problematic sections were eventually jettisoned and the Electronic Commerce Bill became law in 1999.

It was a smart decision, but it left unresolved the problem of what to do about the encryption stuff. The DTI, smarting from its bruising at the hands of the computer scientists who had comprehensively shredded the original encryption proposals, wanted nothing more to do with it. Accordingly the poisoned chalice passed to the Home Office, which knows little of business and even less about the internet, but is endlessly attentive to the needs of the police, the security services and the Byzantine imperatives of official secrecy. The RIP Bill is the fruit of that secretive bureaucratic milieu.

The official rationale for the legislation is that it is required to bring UK law into conformance with the European Convention on Human Rights. In the end, this will have to be tested in the courts, but Straw's confidence is not shared by the Commons Trade & Industry Select Committee which last October recommended that the Government publish a detailed analysis to substantiate its confidence that the Bill does not contravene the Convention. This the Government has so far declined to do.

The Bill has four main parts. The first deals with the interception of communications. the second covers 'surveillance and covert human intelligence sources'. The third tackles encryption and the fourth covers the 'scrutiny of investigatory powers and of the functions of the intelligence services'. Parts I to III propose massive extensions of the state's powers to spy on its citizens while the fourth suggests a regulatory regime which seems laughably inadequate to anyone familiar with internet technology. All sections of the Bill have been heavily criticised by external experts and a small number of committed MPs, but the legislation has passed through its Commons scrutiny with its central provisions intact.

Part I gives the Home Secretary the power to issue a warrant requiring ISPs to intercept the communications of one or more of their subscribers. The problem is that the internet is not like the telephone system - where it is technically feasible to tap into a particular individual's communications link. In order to monitor a person's internet traffic, you have to tap into all the traffic running through his or her ISP. As a result, the expectation is that Part I of the Bill will be implemented using so-called 'passive monitoring': ISPs will be required to install a 'black box' which will monitor all their data traffic and pass it to the GTAC centre.

The news that henceforth all UK internet traffic will find its way to MI5 does not seem to have yet reached MPs, most of whom don't understand the technology and assume that the Home Office must know what it is doing. Defenders of the Bill point out that MI5 can only legally read the content of communications for which specific warrants exist, which is true. But they fail to notice that the Bill affords no such protection to the pattern of one's internet connections.

In other words, while MI5 may need a warrant actually to read your email, many other people will have essentially unregulated access to logs of the websites you access, the pages you download, the addresses of those with whom you exchange email, the discussion groups to which you belong and the chat rooms you frequent - in short, a comprehensive record of what you do online and with whom. It will be interesting to see how this squares with the European Convention's requirements about privacy.

It is Part III of the Bill, however, which is most likely to contravene the Convention. Section 46 gives the Home Secretary the power to compel the surrender of keys used to encrypt communications data. Failure to comply carries a prison sentence of two years. If someone cannot comply because they have lost or forgotten the key then they have to prove that to the satisfaction of a court. In other words, the burden of proof is shifted from the prosecution to the defence - one is presumed guilty until proved innocent. And how do you prove that you have forgotten something?

Even more oppressive is the Bill's creation of a secondary offence - revealing that you have been required to supply, or supplied, a decryption key - which carries an even stiffer penalty. Under the terms of the Bill, for example, the police could arrive at 4am and demand that you produce such a key. If you were unable to comply and were taken in for questioning, it would be a criminal offence punishable by five years' imprisonment to explain to your family why you were being dragged off.

Civil liberties campaigners are predictably opposed to the RIP Bill. But it is also widely opposed by the business community. Even Professor Norton, the architect of the Government's e-commerce legislation, describes the proposals as 'a classic own goal' that will undermine the aim of making Britain a centre for e-commerce. Encryption is central to e-business, and many companies have contractual agreements with clients for whom they hold cryptographic keys. Under the RIP Bill they would be banned from revealing that they had surrendered a key and thereby compromised the client's security.

'This is a clear case,' says Norton, 'of the futility of government treating internet policy as a national issue when what is needed is international agreement. A UK firm which handed over the key of a multinational client would be vulnerable to a compensation claim in an overseas court for compromising that client's global security. US businesses are not happy about that liability and will opt to work in countries like Ireland.'

The most astonishing thing about . Straw's pre-emptive strike on civil liberties and e-commerce is that, to date, there has been almost no public discussion of it. The Ministers driving his Bill through Parliament concede that the powers they seek are sweeping, but argue that they can be trusted to apply them reasonably and that in any case the powers are commensurate with the threat from online criminals, terrorists, paedophiles and pornographers. In the absence of proper safeguards, the first argument is absurd.

As far as the second is concerned, nobody has yet produced any convincing empirical evidence that the supposed threats are more than the fantasies of security services and hysterical projections of some newspapers. The internet undoubtedly provides a conduit for criminal conversations and porno graphic transactions. But then so does the telephone system and the Royal Mail, and yet nobody proposes tapping every phone in the land or scanning every letter. A terrifying erosion in our liberties is being planned, yet the threat is largely ignored.

Could it be that this collective passivity is because, for most citizens, the liberties that are being eroded lie in the future rather than the present? Most people do not currently encrypt their email, even though an unencrypted email is as vulnerable to snooping as an ordinary postcard. But in five years' encryption will have become a necessity.

Human nature being what it is, people will lose or forget their decryption keys - and some will find themselves attempting to convince a judge that they are not paedophiles feigning amnesia to qualify for a shorter sentence. Will they then remember Burke's warning that for evil to triumph it is necessary only for good men to do nothing? And will they wonder why they had not been more alarmed on the morning of 5 October 2000?

Rest of the world

Most countries impose no restrictions on the use of encryption by their citizens. The exceptions tend to be authoritarian regimes such as those in Russia and China.

IRELAND: New e-commerce Bill makes it illegal for government to access commercial cryptographic keys.

FRANCE: The government has recently announced a new policy of totally relaxing controls on domestic use of encryption.

US: No domestic controls on use of cryptography, though Washington looks enviously at the UK RIP bill.

GERMANY: Has long been the European leader in opposing restrictions on citizens' use of encryption.

Over the coming weeks The Observer will print a series of articles and opinion pieces on the proposed RIP Bill. If you wish to voice your opinion online you can do so here. To find out more about the Bill see www.fipr.org/rip/

fields.headline: Jack Black
fields.trailText: The best scene at the cinema this year comes halfway through Jesus' Son. It involves a man coming into a near-deserted hospital with a huge steak knife stuck in his eye, and Jack Black as an orderly who has been busily stealing and consuming drugs from his workplace. It would be hilarious if wasn't so disturbing. Or possibly disturbing if it wasn't so hilarious. You could say pretty much the same thing about the scene in High Fidelity when Barry (Black) terrorises his fellow record shop workers into listening to Katrina And The Waves' 'Walking On Sunshine' just because he wants their day to get off to a cheery start. (On the other hand, Black singing Marvin Gaye's 'Let's Get It On' later in the film is as unambiguously disturbing as it gets).
fields.body:
The best scene at the cinema this year comes halfway through Jesus' Son. It involves a man coming into a near-deserted hospital with a huge steak knife stuck in his eye, and Jack Black as an orderly who has been busily stealing and consuming drugs from his workplace. It would be hilarious if wasn't so disturbing. Or possibly disturbing if it wasn't so hilarious. You could say pretty much the same thing about the scene in High Fidelity when Barry (Black) terrorises his fellow record shop workers into listening to Katrina And The Waves' 'Walking On Sunshine' just because he wants their day to get off to a cheery start. (On the other hand, Black singing Marvin Gaye's 'Let's Get It On' later in the film is as unambiguously disturbing as it gets).

If you want someone who is big, obnoxious and funny in a slightly terrifying way, Jack Black's your guy. Unless you're the star of a film and bothered by the fact that Black walks away with the show - even if, as in the case of Jesus' Son, an excellent indie movie about junkies in the early Seventies, he's only in a few scenes. But for his next film - Saving Silverman, about two men trying to stop their best friend marrying the wrong woman - Black gets his first million-dollar wage packet: it seems like all that scene-stealing has paid off.

He has a weird intensity that has made him easy to spot from the start. Born in 1969 in LA, he turned to acting after a messy adolescence. 'I was a very needy of attention kid. I wanted to be tough so I tried to be a heavy metaller dude. Wasn't really pulling it off and I had this weird part of me that was really into Bobby McFerrin and other really cheesed-out things.' His break came when he met Tim Robbins. Black was in the cast of Carnage , the play Robbins brought to the Edinburgh Festival in 1989. He has been memorable in all three films Robbins has directed: as a creepy fan who worships Bob Roberts, as Sean Penn's brother in Dead Man Walking and as an idiotic ventriloquist in Cradle Will Rock. But this isn't just a tale of one big group of friends - Robbins and High Fidelity star/writer/executive producer John Cusack are also best buddies - because Black was equally effective in Enemy Of The State, Mars Attacks and even the appalling I Still Know What You Did Last Summer.

But that's just the acting. Black is one half of Tenacious D, a comedy rock band who have their own TV series and have supported Beck and Pearl Jam. Or maybe 'supported' is the wrong word. 'There was some slight nervous nilly. But then we realised, "Wait a second. We're not opening for Pearl Jam. They're just going on after us. So thank you, Pearl Jam, for coming down to the Tenacious D show. And, people, after we're done, please don't leave. There are other bands. Be courteous." Luckily they listened to us; otherwise it would have been really embarrassing for the Pearls.'

Five things you should know about Jack Black

1 His parents are satellite engineers: 'I did not inherit any of the mathematical aptitude for the sciences or any of that.'

2His favourite album is Radiohead's The Bends . Or possibly AC/DC's Back In Black.

3 He knows - and will sing in public - Gene Roddenberry's rarely used words to the original Star Trek theme.

4 His band, Tenacious D, are a successful live draw in the US: 'We're kind of a hybrid of Cheech And Chong and Beavis And Butthead.'

5 He's frequently asked if that's really him singing 'Let's Get It On' in High Fidelity . It is.

fields.headline: Soccer war warning ignored
fields.standfirst: Belgian town braced for mayhem after Germany vetoed move to switch Euro 2000 clash with England
fields.trailText: Belgian town braced for mayhem after Germany vetoed move to switch Euro 2000 clash with England.
fields.body:
The small Belgian town hosting England's soccer showdown with Germany is braced for violent clashes between Europe's most notorious hooligans after football's rulers ignored warnings that it is an unsuitable venue for a high-risk game.

An Observer investigation reveals that Charleroi is set to be turned into a battlefield with visiting thugs, local Turks and neo-Nazi troublemakers based in the town staging bloody confrontations. The authorities privately admit mayhem is almost guaranteed because huge numbers of mainly ticketless fans will crowd into Charleroi's narrow streets.

Even one of the match organisers admits that the Anglo-German clash on 17 June - potentially the most volatile fixture in the tournament starting this week - is a disaster waiting to happen.

Up to 50,000 England fans are expected to travel to Belgium for the game, even though only 5,000 have been able to buy tickets officially. Almost as many Germans may make the short trip to Charleroi, even though they have also been restricted to 5,000 seats at the 30,000-capacity Stade du Pays.

Both sets of fans contain thugs with a reputation for causing havoc. England followers have repeatedly provoked disturbances abroad, while four German hooligans beat up a French policeman so savagely at the last World Cup that he was left brain-damaged.

There is concern that the 2,500 police on duty will not be able to keep order both at the stadium and in the town centre. 'Charleroi is simply too small to cope with so many people,' said a match organiser.

Uefa, European football's ruling body, has rejected pleas to move the game to nearby Brussels, where fans would be more widely dispersed and the stadium has room for 50,000 spectators.

Commissioner Francine Biot, head of the Charleroi police, said: 'We have made plans for everything to go right, but risk zero doesn't exist. We saw what happened in Istanbul and Copenhagen and will take all action to avoid that situation.'

Charleroi's main square, the Place Charles II, is the likeliest flashpoint. Thousands of fans will assemble to drink in the square's many bars and around the fountain in the middle. Police are also worried that Charleroi's main Turkish area in the Place du Manège and Rue Chavannes, 200 yards from the main square, will become another war zone.

Since the stabbing to death of two Leeds United fans in Istanbul in March, the Turks have replaced the Germans as 'enemy number one' for many English hooligans. Some may seek to assault Turks and attack their snackbars and shops, as Arsenal thugs did in north London when their team lost to Galatasaray of Turkey in Copenhagen.

Charleroi's own hooligans - a 100-strong racist mob known as the Walloon Boys - have been in touch with English thugs offering to join them in attacking Turks.

'Of course, we are worried about trouble between English fans and local Turks,' said Biot. 'Our Turkish population are quiet and not aggressive in normal times, but who can say they will be like that when English people are in Charleroi?'

François Goffe, who runs the Charleroi FC fans project, said: 'The Turks are expecting trouble, but they are not frightened. If English people make trouble, Turkish people from as far away as Brussels will come to help the snackbar owners, some of whom have guns.'

There will be no alcohol ban in Charleroi on the day of the game, except at the stadium. Fans will be able to drink all day before going to the match at 7.45pm. The only special drinks measure for the occasion is a requirement that all alcohol must be consumed from paper or plastic containers; glass objects will be banned.

Up to half of the town centre's 70 bars are considering closing on the day of the match. Ironically, that could lead to hundreds of rival fans congregating around any bar that stays open.

Charleroi's well-intentioned plan to try to keep ticketless fans off the streets while the match is on, by erecting video screens in and around a dozen public buildings, could prove another miscalculation.'I worry there could be trouble if these fans mix. But I hope not,' Biot said.

When a similar screen was erected on the beach at Marseilles for ticketless England fans during the 1998 World Cup, there were clashes between English followers and local youths.

Many people believe Charleroi's Stade du Pays is unsuitable to host England-Germany. Concern focuses on the main stand, which is intended to act as a buffer of 12,000 'neutral' fans between the 5,000 English and German supporters behind the two goals.

The Observer has estab lished that at many as 2,000 'neutral' seats have been obtained by English fans, and that German supporters have also secured some, albeit in smaller numbers. That will ruin the 'careful segregation' that has been much vaunted by the police. The Government has added to the problems, refusing an FA request to seize the passports of known troublemakers planning to go to the match.

Lives could be lost if trouble breaks out in the stand's third tier, which is so steep it would not receive a safety licence in Britain. 'It's frightening. If there's an incident up there, people could fall over the low wall at the bottom of the seats,' said Kurt Wertelaers, a crime reporter with Belgium's Het Laatste Nieuws newspaper. 'If someone was pushed, or you were pushed against that wall during an incident, you could fall over.'

Black market tickets in the 'neutral' stand are fetching £600 among England fans. England also play Romania In Charleroi on 20 June.

The Observer can reveal that the Germans snubbed a last-ditch initiative by the Government to form an Anglo-German alliance to pressure Uefa into switching the fixture to a bigger and safer location. Otto Schily, the German Interior Minister, refused to back the move - endorsed by Prime Minister Tony Blair, Home Secretary Jack Straw and the Football Association - and thus wrecked any chance of forcing Uefa into a change.

A ministerial source revealed: 'As soon as we learnt several months ago that England-Germany was in Charleroi, we were extremely concerned at the stadium's small capacity and the ability of a small town to mount a sufficiently robust policing operation. Jack Straw wrote to Herr Schily to solicit his support for us both together asking Uefa to reconsider the venue. But Herr Schily decided to accept Uefa's reassurances that everything would be OK.'

The Government's belated admission that legislation to remove passports from known or suspected hooligans is 'desirable' has raised new questions about why it has not introduced such a law already.

The Belgians and Dutch plan to refuse entry to 1,000 known English hooligans.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Vivre Sa Vie | The Cup | Everyone Says I Love You | Red River
fields.trailText: Vivre Sa Vie | The Cup | Everyone Says I Love You | Red River
fields.body:
Vivre Sa Vie
(1962, 15, Nouveau Pictures, VHS, Rental/Retail)

Jean-Luc Godard's third feature film (though his second to be shown outside France) proved that his breathtaking debut, A Bout de Souffle , was no fluke. This innovative application of Brechtian techniques to the cinema combines traditional melodrama and detached social analysis to examine the career of a Parisian prostitute (Anna Karina), whose favourite movie is Dreyer's silent Passion of Joan of Arc . The philosopher Brice Parain appears as himself, the superb monochrome photography is by Raoul Coutard and the score is by Michel Legrand.

The Cup
(1999, PG, Alliance Atlantis, VHS Retail/Rental)

Attractive comedy set in a Himalayan monastery where the exiled Tibetan monks drink Coca-Cola and follow the 1998 World Cup on a black-and-white TV. It's like a Buddhist version of those jolly Hollywood convent comedies in which nuns follow baseball and sing pop songs. The director, Khyentse Norbu, making his debut working with a non-professional cast, is himself a monk and the reincarnation of Jamyang Khyentse Wangopo, a Tibetan saint. The picture received the Dalai Lama's imprimatur.

Everyone Says I Love You
(1996, 12, Cinema Club. VHS/Retail)

Available for under £5, along with his Bullets Over Broadway , Mighty Aphrodite and New York Stories , Woody Allen's first excursion into the musical is a trip to the moon on gossamer wings. Goldie Hawn is glorious as a rich Manhattan socialite with a social conscience and the movie concerns the happy problems of her husband (Alan Alda), ex-husband (Woody Allen), their kids and friends in idyllic versions of New York, Paris and Venice.

Everyone (except spoilsport Drew Barrymore) does their own singing and the songs are Thirties and Forties evergreens. A film to own and cherish.

Red River
(1948, PG, MGM, DVD/Retail)

One of the greatest westerns, Howard Hawks's masterpiece centres on the conflict between martinet rancher John Wayne and his humane foster son Montgomery Clift on a cattle drive from Texas to a Kansas railhead shortly after the Civil War. This majestic movie, which made Clift a star, transposes Mutiny on the Bounty to the American frontier. In giving the 40-year-old Wayne the Bligh role it re-shaped his career in preparation for aggressive middle age.

webTitle: Must I take a job move and lose a pay- off?

fields.headline: Must I take a job move and lose a pay- off?
fields.standfirst: My post has just been made redundant and I thought that I would be in line for a tidy redundancy pay-off. But the latest development is that my employers have now offered to redeploy me to a job I do not particularly want. What are my options?
fields.trailText: My post has just been made redundant and I thought that I would be in line for a tidy redundancy pay-off. But the latest development is that my employers have now offered to redeploy me to a job I do not particularly want. What are my options?
fields.body:
The basic situation is that you lose your right to redundancy money if they offer you what is known as 'reasonable alternative employment'. So if your job doing accounts for the Catering section is made redundant, you could be offered 'reasonable alternative employment' by being asked to take on the accounts for the similarly sized Transport section of your company.

If, however, you are offered employment in an office 50 miles away or your remuneration package is cut, then this is not so clearly reasonable. Similarly, if the job is a step downwards, then it is not a reasonable offer. It would not be fair to make someone lose a notch in status - from supervisor to member of a team, for instance. You could argue that it would be unreasonable to make someone take a backward step in terms of career development.

In practice, most companies rarely force redeployment on employees, unless they are tight with money. They prefer not to get into a fight and to have people in place with real enthusiasm.

 Legal advice from Charles Russell solicitors

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

webTitle: Straw forced to back down on asylum-seekers' homes

fields.headline: Straw forced to back down on asylum-seekers' homes
fields.standfirst: Asylum: myths and reality - Observer special
fields.trailText: Home Secretary Jack Straw has been forced into a climbdown over his dispersal policy for asylum seekers after The Observer revealed that property barons stood to make fortunes from housing people in slum conditions.
fields.body:
Home Secretary Jack Straw has been forced into a climbdown over his dispersal policy for asylum seekers after The Observer revealed that property barons stood to make fortunes from housing people in slum conditions.

The Home Office's head of procurement will tomorrow visit two crumbling Liverpool tower blocks where asylum seekers are living in flats sold off as unfit for council tenants.

An Observer investigation last week revealed that residents had documents withheld and were refused visitors without the permission of the landlords. A spokesman for the department said the official would take immediate action if asylum seekers were being mistreated by the landlord, Landmark Liverpool.

At the same time, strict controls are to be introduced to control the standards of the property being used in the scheme. This weekend the government department responsible for all civil service housing, the Property Advisor to the Civil Estate, was brought in to inspect the property being used under the dispersal scheme.

On Friday, all private contractors working under the dispersal scheme were called in to the Home Office and warned to adhere to the terms of their contracts, which include a commitment to ensuring that asylum seekers have access to basic education and health services.

The news of the Home Office rethink comes on the eve of an Observer debate on asylum seekers between Straw and the Shadow Home Secretary, Ann Widdecombe.

Responding to The Observer's revelations, Widdecombe said: 'We need to get the system back to what it is intended to do, which is to offer a safe and settled home to those in genuine fear of persecution. I look forward to this opportunity to debate openly with the Home Secretary as to what has gone wrong since Labour came to power.'

She said: 'This was his answer to the problem and it clearly isn't the right answer.'

A Home Office spokesman said: 'With such a large undertaking, you will have teething problems.'

fields.headline: Denmark
fields.standfirst: Odds 50/1
fields.trailText: How did they qualify? Through the play-offs, like England. Only instead of losing to Scotland on a torturous night at Wembley, the Danes blitzed Israel with an 8-0 aggregate win. 'Like a fairytale,' said Peter Schmeichel.
fields.body:
How did they qualify? Through the play-offs, like England. Only instead of losing to Scotland on a torturous night at Wembley, the Danes blitzed Israel with an 8-0 aggregate win. 'Like a fairytale,' said Peter Schmeichel.

Not another one? No, it's the same Peter Schmeichel. Sunderland's Thomas Sorensen received his long-awaited debut against Israel, but old Red-nose is expected to be first choice in the finals.

No, not another fairytale? You would be referring to the 1992 tournament in Sweden, when Denmark came from the beach (most players were on holiday) as late replacements for Yugoslavia and ended up beating Germany in the final. A repeat is highly unlikely, since this time the Danes are one of the more pallid-looking sides in Group D, Euro 2000's group of death.

Tournament record Semi-finalists in 1984, otherwise nothing much before or since 1992.

How do they beat you? Traditionally with a mixture of organised counter-attacking and individual flair from the likes of Allan Simonsen and Michael and Brian Laudrup. None of whom are available so Danish hopes rest on Spurs' Allan Nielsen and Feyenoord's Jon Dahl Tomasson.

How do you beat them? Preferably by lobbing Schmeichel, like Davor Suker did in Euro 96.

What's their manager like? Bo Johansson, a Swede, succeeded Moller Nielsen after the disappointing displays in Euro 96, but will himself give way to former Ajax coach Morten Olsen after this tournament.

A Danish view on Denmark 'It will be very hard considering the group we are in. A lot will depend on our attacking midfielders, Udinese's Martin Jorgensen and Ajax's Jesper Gronkjaer, and the key game will be the second one against Holland.' Kurt Lassen (Berlingske Tidende, Copenhagen)

The Danish Des is... Flemming Toft. 'He was in Sweden at the Euro 1992 tournament when Denmark won the title and has been the nation's favourite ever since.'

Chant 'Sejle op ad åien!' (Sailing up the river!)

fields.headline: Czech Republic
fields.standfirst: Odds 14/1
fields.trailText: How do you beat them? Pour more misery on to Pavel Srnicek. In fairness, although he has endured a miserable season at Sheffield Wednesday, he is not in the habit of conceding bucketloads for his country. Better protection clearly helps, and the Czechs' defensive trio are solid and comfortable on the ball.
fields.body:
How do you beat them? Pour more misery on to Pavel Srnicek. In fairness, although he has endured a miserable season at Sheffield Wednesday, he is not in the habit of conceding bucketloads for his country. Better protection clearly helps, and the Czechs' defensive trio are solid and comfortable on the ball.

How do they beat you? Built on the foundation of consistency and defensive stability, an average of two-and-a-half goals a game in qualifying is a more than reasonable return. Watch out for Jan Koller, a latecomer onto the international scene who made his debut last year aged 25, has found a rich vein of scoring form. But perhaps their greatest strength is in midfield, where the adventurous instincts of Liverpool's Patrick Berger and Lazio's Pavel Nedved are a constant threat.

What's their manager like? Josef Chovanec is young, only 40, yet commands respect for his tactical wisdom. He took the reigns in 1998, after the Czech Republic failed to qualify for the World Cup in France. His faultless route to Euro 2000 brought him admirers but also a heavy burden. Expectation is high, and perhaps slightly unrealistic.

Can't be that unrealistic if they broke qualification records? True. It was a procession as they became the first team ever to qualify for a European Championship with a 100 per cent record. But it must be said they swept aside opponents of dubious merit. The best they faced was Scotland, which tells you something. Otherwise it was embryonic footballing nations and the force that is the Faroe Islands.

Tournament record Pretty impressive. Winners in 1976 and third placed four years later, they then sat out three tournaments before emerging as the surprise package in Euro 96. With a squad then based largely in Prague, they cut a dash all the way to the final, where they had the misfortune to stumble into Germany.

A Czech view on the Czech Republic 'The team will do well to make it to the second round after being drawn with France and Holland.If they can do that, they are talented enough to win the whole tournament.' Franticek Bouc (Prague Post)

The Czech Des is... 'We have no-one with the character of your Mr Lynam', says Franticek with an air of genuine regret.

fields.headline: Holland
fields.standfirst: Odds 3/1 Fav
fields.trailText: How did they qualify? Automatically, as hosts. They have filled the last two years with a series of reunions, at which the players got together to tease each other, reminisce about the World Cup and compare salaries. Each reunion culminated in a beer match against another international team, who unfortunately tended to take it seriously. Of the 15 friendlies the Dutch have played since the World Cup, they won only two and drawn eleven. Nobody cares.
fields.body:
How did they qualify? Automatically, as hosts. They have filled the last two years with a series of reunions, at which the players got together to tease each other, reminisce about the World Cup and compare salaries. Each reunion culminated in a beer match against another international team, who unfortunately tended to take it seriously. Of the 15 friendlies the Dutch have played since the World Cup, they won only two and drawn eleven. Nobody cares.

How do you beat them? The best way is to take them to a penalty shoot-out, which they always lose. Dutch footballers regard penalties as silly and beneath them. Alternatively, wait for the phase in each Dutch game when the team appears to fall asleep. Psychologists are divided: are the players tripping on LSD, have they succumbed to hubris or just forgotten where they are? The phase seldom lasts more than ten minutes, generally early in the second half (do they drink vodka at half-time?) but it accounts for about 80 per cent of goals scored against Holland. A classic case was the Yugoslavia game at the last World Cup: Holland dominated the match except for a five-minute spell after half-time in which a cautious Yugoslavia scored once, missed a penalty, and should have scored more.

How do they beat you? By being better. No team can pass like the Dutch. In no team does almost every player, even the goalkeeper, and excepting only the right-back, Michael Reiziger, possess perfect ball control. And occasionally they interrupt their passing exercises to score. With Jaap Stam and Edgar Davids they even have a bit of bite.

What's their manager like? Frank Rijkaard is like a nice primary-school teacher, always willing to explain himself to anyone in words of one syllable. Rijkaard was a great footballer, almost complete, and more gifted than his childhood friend Ruud Gullit, yet he lacks arrogance. Unfortunately, Rijkaard is also somewhat tedious and uncharismatic. The players adore him, he understands football, and he presides over a happy camp, but footballers do not fear him as they do Alex Ferguson or Louis van Gaal. He is less nimble tactically than Johan Cruyff (the standard to which Dutch coaches are held), but then so is everyone else.

Tournament record Not very good, except for the time they won it in 1988.

Player the fans hate? Clarence Seedorf. Aged 24, Seedorf has been a regular for Holland since his late teens. However, he has alienated fans with his desire to play the philosopher-king in interviews, his fat backside, his awkward, back-spun, look-at-me-mum passes, and his apparently limitless self-esteem. Recently Dutch TV sent out small-time Dutch celebrities to interview footballers. When Seedorf's turn came, he suggested Nelson Mandela and Michael Jordan for the job. Neither could make it. 'When I am in Holland, I feel negative feelings. That must change,' says Seedorf, annoyingly.

Chris van Nijnatten of Algemeen Dagblad.

Hup, Holland, Hup

Don't put the beast in his slippers)

fields.headline: France
fields.standfirst: Odds 6/1
fields.trailText: How did they qualify? With palpitating hearts and shredded nerves. It all hung in the balance in the final minutes of the final day of the group. Having squeezed past plucky Iceland, the French waited on tenterhooks for news of Russia and the Ukraine which would decide their qualification fate... They cancelled each other out confirming France as group winners. Cue massive love in at the Stade de France.
fields.body:
How did they qualify? With palpitating hearts and shredded nerves. It all hung in the balance in the final minutes of the final day of the group. Having squeezed past plucky Iceland, the French waited on tenterhooks for news of Russia and the Ukraine which would decide their qualification fate... They cancelled each other out confirming France as group winners. Cue massive love in at the Stade de France.

How do they beat you? By believing they can. They exude total faith in their own ability against all comers, and to be fair they have good reason. As Frank Lebeouf was once overheard whispering to himself, 'France won the World Cup you know'.

How do you beat them? With difficulty. The experience of becoming the best on the planet has welded these proud players into a tightly-knit, highly-motivated group who refuse to accept defeat even if they are not performing well. On their day France possess one of the most finely tuned midfields around, capable of dominating and delivering with panache. Their oppponents should take heart from an increasing number of uncharacteristic glitches in a normally resolute defence (Slovenia made mugs of them in a recent friendly). But basically your best chance is to hope they don't stumble upon a solution to their striking conundrum.

Anelka, Henry, Trezeguet, Wiltord - how puzzling can it be? Quite. If any combination of the above establish themseves as regular scorers - and they are all eminently capable - France could clean up. We know all about the frightening pace of Anelka and Henry, while Bordeaux's Wiltord, who is in the shop window, and the improving Monaco forward Trezeguet top scored in the last two French championships respectively. With so much firepower at their fingertips France will probably play more than the usual lone striker.

What's their manager like? Popular. These French coaches have a knack for the human touch which endears them to their players and Roger Lemerre is no exception. Aimé Jacquet's right-hand man during the World Cup is fortunate to have inherited such a high calibre squad, even if they haven't always shown it. Uninspired, unimaginably slender victories over the mighty Andorra and Armenia raised many a Gallic eyebrow during qualification. In response, he hinted at calling it a day as soon as Euro 2000 was booked. But seeing as his contract is up at the end of the tournament anyway, and with so much talent at his disposal how could he resist the challenge? After all, no team has managed to follow World Cup success with the European trophy. Yet.

The typical French player is probably from one of France's ethnic minority communities.

The main man is Zinedine Zidane, the classic playmaker. Voted the World's best player in 1998. In that vintage year he set standards which were almost impossibly high to live up to. He is still his country's talismanic force. It's no coincidence that France's form faltered when he was troubled by a knee injury. Both club and country were relieved to see the Juventus maestro return to full power recently.

Tournament record Comme ci, comme ça. Not very brilliant until Michel Platini's beautiful team won the tournament in 1984. Last time they didn't dazzle but did get as close as a penalty shootout away from the final. This time they intend too improve on both counts.

Greatest footballing moment? Receiving the team-sheet which revealed Ronaldo's mysterious illness minutes before the World Cup final.

They'd love to beat? Tout le monde.

Fan's favourite? Zidane - affectionately known as Zizou - captured French hearts even before his goals in the World Cup Final against Brazil. Now he is up there on the most exclusive pedestal alongside Michel Platini. Laurent 'Lolo' Blanc is also adored, and having so cruelly missed French football's finest hour and a half the nation crave a final for him before the veteran libero bows out.

Player the fans love to hate? Croatia's Slaven Bilic (see Lolo's misfortune above). To explain how aggrieved they were when he got their gallant captain sent off in the semi it's worth borrowing a famous Croat curse: may his mother next recognise him as a kebab.

A French view on France 'We have a good chance for the semi-finals. The general feeling is that the basic standard of the team is very high as it will be virtually unchanged from the World Cup - maybe only five changes in the squad. No one has even suggested we won't get through the first round.' Jean-Christophe Bassignac (L'Equipe)

The French Des is... Thierry Roland. 'In touch with the supporters, with a very basic sense of humour. He has no knowledge of tactics but is popular because he has been around for a very long time.'

Chant The inspiring 'Allez les bleus' (Come On The Blues)

webTitle: The OSM lowdown on Group D

fields.headline: The OSM lowdown on Group D
fields.trailText: Observer Sport Monthly's verdict on the group and the round-up of television coverage
fields.body:
2 questions that will decide Group B

1 Will Holland qualify?

With the talent at their disposal and playing at home you might think it a formality. It probably is. But just consider the opposition: France, the world champions; the Czech Republic, the most impressive qualifiers and runners-up last time; and Denmark, who have won the tournament more recently than the Dutch.

2 How good is Pavel Nedved?

Very, very good, as you have to be to play as many games in Lazio's starting midfield as he did last season. Good enough to take his side into second place? Not quite

fields.headline: Slovenia
fields.standfirst: Odds 125/1
fields.trailText: How did they qualify? By beating Ukraine in a two-legged play-off, which considering England would have gone weak at the knees at the prospect of travelling to Kiev in the snow must rank as one of the outstanding qualification achievements of the tournament.
fields.body:
How did they qualify? By beating Ukraine in a two-legged play-off, which considering England would have gone weak at the knees at the prospect of travelling to Kiev in the snow must rank as one of the outstanding qualification achievements of the tournament.

Why haven't we heard of Slovenian football before? Independent of Yugoslavia only since 1991, Slovenia failed to qualify for Euro 96 but have reached these finals at just the second time of asking. Even so its population of two million still largely prefers skiing and basketball.

Tournament record There isn't one.

How do they beat you? Well, in the case of Ukraine, a lob from the halfway line by Milenko Acimovic late in the home leg provided the crucial advantage to defend in Kiev. Few rated Slovenia's chances in blizzard conditions when Ukraine took the lead in the second leg, but these boys are used to snow, and Miran Pavlin managed an historic equaliser.

How do you beat them? Arrange for it not to snow. Play on large, well-watered pitches in high-tec stadiums full of partisan supporters.

What's their manager like? Srecko Katanec, a former Stuttgart and Sampdoria player who was the only Slovene in the last united Yugoslavia squad at Italia 90. 'Spirit is what matters the most,' he says. 'We can only achieve good results if we are all motivated, all good friends and play with our hearts.'

A Slovenian view on Slovenia 'We're not a footballing country. We'll be surprised if we get a point but our fans will still watch and have fun. If the team play with their hearts we will love them.' Goran Obrez (Epika).

The Slovenian Des is... 'We have no Des Lynam. No-one liked football very much before now'. Fair enough.

Chant 'Slovenia gre naprej, Slovenia gre naprej' (Slovenia goes on, Slovenia goes on)

fields.headline: Norway
fields.standfirst: Odds 20/1
fields.trailText: How did they qualify? With astonishing ease, winning Group Two by an eight-point margin.
fields.body:
How did they qualify? With astonishing ease, winning Group Two by an eight-point margin.

Aren't these part-timers ranked higher than Brazil nowadays? Not quite, although they did beat Brazil in the last World Cup. They have been as high as seventh, and have absolutely earned the right to be taken seriously, even if nobody does.

Why not? Because they still play a dopey long ball game, because this is the first time they have reached the finals of the European Championships, and because there are odd results, such as losing at home to Latvia or being given the runaround by Morocco in France, which suggest the Norwegians are not the immovable obstacle the statistics imply.

Tournament record Non-existent.

How do you beat them? Just stay awake. Cesare Maldini called Norway the most defensive team he had ever seen after Italy knocked them out of France 98, which is rich coming from an Italian who lost his own job through being too cautious.

How do they beat you? Most likely with a goal from Tore Andre Flo, Ole Gunnar Solskjaer or some other striker who has honed his talent in England. Of the 21 goals Norway scored in qualifying, all but four came from Premiership players.

What's their manager like? Nils Johan Semb is the man currently walking in Egil Olsen's wellies, having taken over after the last World Cup and survived the '90-minute nightmare' of his opening game, a 3-1 home defeat byt Latvia.

A Norwegian view on Norway 'I believe Norway will finish second in their group after Spain and then meet Holland in the quarter-finals and I can't see them winning that. Ole Gunnar Solskjaer is our key man and will probably play on his own up front, relegating Tore Andre Flo to the bench or midfield. But Solskjaer's girlfriend is expecting a baby in the middle of the tournament and he has said that he might quit the team to be with her. Henning Berg will be crucial in defence now that Ronnie Johnsen is out.' Sindre Halkjelsyik (Dagbladet, Oslo)

The Norwegian Des is... Arne Scheie. 'He wins that title by a mile. He has been around since the 60s and was the first one to go to England and report on games.'

Chant 'Heja Norge!' (Come on Norway!)

fields.headline: Yugoslavia
fields.standfirst: Odds 25/1
fields.trailText: How did they qualify? Without much gloss. Against the only other tough teams in their group, Croatia and the Republic of Ireland, they won just one game in four. Their two draws against Croatia were notable chiefly for an atmosphere of hate so intense that it would have surprised Glaswegians.
fields.body:
How did they qualify? Without much gloss. Against the only other tough teams in their group, Croatia and the Republic of Ireland, they won just one game in four. Their two draws against Croatia were notable chiefly for an atmosphere of hate so intense that it would have surprised Glaswegians.

How do you beat them? Sprint past them. Yugoslavia will be probably the oldest team at Euro 2000. Any side featuring a 35-year-old playmaker based in Japan can be taken apart by pace. Furthermore, the post-war Yugoslav side has inherited the laziness that characterised pre-war Yugoslav sides. (We're talking civil war, here, by the way.) Few young players have been given a chance ahead of Euro 2000, even though several regulars are struggling. To name but two: keeper Ivica Kralj has spent almost the whole season on PSV Eindhoven's bench, while the 31-year-old striker Predrag Mijatovic has been injured almost non-stop at Fiorentina.

How do they beat you? The Yugoslavs call themselves the Brazilians of Europe (referring to their skill on the ball rather than the mess they have made of their country). They are also the team most likely to score from free-kicks, possessing as they do strikers programmed to dive and a centre-back, Sinisa Mihajlovic, who reliably bangs in left-footed set-pieces. Brazilian though they may be, the Yugoslavs are never distracted by a desire to play the beautiful game. This team defends.

What's their manager like? At 69, Vujadin Boskov is even older than his players. But he has won more than they have, at clubs like Sampdoria, Feyenoord, Roma and Real Madrid. His credibility as a coach has slipped recently, though, as he keeps taking a different line on who will be in the team. In the winter he said the nearly-pensionable Dragan Stojkovic and Dejan Stankovic were no longer part of his plans. Since then Stojkovic has captained the side. Boskov has also appeared to promise Yugoslavs that his team will win Euro 2000. That may have been foolish.

Tournament record Reasonable, when they are allowed to enter. They narrowly lost the finals of 1960 and 1968, and as hosts of the 1976 edition reached the semis, but were banned from the tournaments of 1992 and 1996 because of their various wars. Irksomely to Yugoslavs, the team chosen to replace them in 1992, Denmark, won the competition.

The main man is Sinisa Mihajlovic. Lazio's centre-back is a rare Yugoslav in that he plays regularly for a top-class team and still has full use of his limbs. At 31, he is a comparative child in this team. Yet even Mihajlovic, never fast, is starting to slow. Increasingly he is becoming like a kicker in American football, wheeled on for set-pieces but otherwise taking no part in play. Currently he is fuming at his country. A few weeks ago Serbian state television reported that he had joined Slobodan Milosevic's SPS party and showed him apparently signing the requisite documents. Mihajlovic was outraged. He said he thought he had been signing up to act as 'sports ambassador' for Yugoslavia. The trick left him considering a boycott of Euro 2000.

Team they would love to beat? All of them. The Yugoslav players tend to believe they are representing a nation that stands alone against an evil world. Their camp at the World Cup in France, in the midst of gorgeous countryside, was a grumpy place where players answered questions from foreign journalists as if under interrogation.

A Yugoslav view on Yugoslavia 'It's so hard to predict. If Mihajlovic plays, he can inspire the rest of the team to great heights. I think we can make the semi-finals. I don't believe we can win the tournament though.' Nicolas Zurovac.

The Yugoslav Des is... Milojko Pantic. 'He's the biggest name.'

Chant 'Napred Pantic!' (Go Blues!)

In the winter he said the nearly-pensionable Dragan Stojkovic and Dejan Stankovic were no longer part of his plans. Since then Stojkovic has captained the side. Boskov has also appeared to promise Yugoslavs that his team will win Euro 2000. That may have been foolish. Tournament record Reasonable, when they are allowed to enter. They narrowly lost the finals of 1960 and 1968, and as hosts of the 1976 edition reached the semis, but were banned from the tournaments of 1992 and 1996 because of their various wars. Irksomely to Yugoslavs, the team chosen to replace them in 1992, Denmark, won the competition. The main man is Sinisa Mihajlovic. Lazio's centre-back is a rare Yugoslav in that he plays regularly for a top-class team and still has full use of his limbs. At 31, he is a comparative child in this team. Yet even Mihajlovic, never fast, is starting to slow. Increasingly he is becoming like a kicker in American football, wheeled on for set-pieces but otherwise taking no part in play. Currently he is fuming at his country. A few weeks ago Serbian state television reported that he had joined Slobodan Milosevic's SPS party and showed him apparently signing the requisite documents. Mihajlovic was outraged. He said he thought he had been signing up to act as 'sports ambassador' for Yugoslavia. The trick left him considering a boycott of Euro 2000. Team they would love to beat? All of them. The Yugoslav players tend to believe they are representing a nation that stands alone against an evil world. Their camp at the World Cup in France, in the midst of gorgeous countryside, was a grumpy place where players answered questions from foreign journalists as if under interrogation. A Yugoslav view on Yugoslavia 'It's so hard to predict. If Mihajlovic plays, he can inspire the rest of the team to great heights. I think we can make the semi-finals. I don't believe we can win the tournament though.' Nicolas Zurovac. The Yugoslav Des is... Milojko Pantic. 'He's the biggest name.' Chant 'Napred Pantic!' (Go Blues!)

fields.headline: Spain
fields.standfirst: Odds 6/1
fields.trailText: How did they qualify? By finishing eight points ahead of Israel in what was admittedly a fairly straightforward Group Six. There was a scare when Spain lost their opening fixture 3-2 in Cyprus, but that was the only hiccup for a side which scored an impressive 42 goals in eight qualifying matches under new coach Jose Antonio Camacho.
fields.body:
How did they qualify? By finishing eight points ahead of Israel in what was admittedly a fairly straightforward Group Six. There was a scare when Spain lost their opening fixture 3-2 in Cyprus, but that was the only hiccup for a side which scored an impressive 42 goals in eight qualifying matches under new coach Jose Antonio Camacho.

Spain must be among the favourites then? They are one of the four seeds, but although they should be fancied for almost every major tournament, they never attract that much betting money because they are international football's most regular underachievers. 'We have no record to defend, we cannot be regarded as favourites,' said Camacho, getting his excuses in early.

How do they beat you? In theory, by utilising their wealth of unquestionably talented attacking players to outscore you.

How do you beat them? Just turn up, you never know. England beat them on penalties in Euro 96, helped by a couple of favourable refereeing decisions during open play, and they went out of the last World Cup through defeat by Nigeria and a costly goalless draw against Paraguay.

Tournament record Poor, in all tournaments. Only major success was a European Championship won on home ground in 1964, but the competition was much smaller and less significant then.

What's their manager like? Camacho was a successful player with Real Madrid, though his coaching record at Rayo Vallecano, Sevilla and Espanol is less impressive. His commitment to flair and attacking football has found favour with his employers and the Spanish public since taking over from Javier Clemente however.

The typical Spanish player defies a stereotype. But is probably a lot better than you think he is, even if you've never heard of him.

The main man is... Raul. For most British football supporters he is perhaps the least known genuine superstar of European football. The Real Madrid prodigy has been a striker of the highest quality for a number of years now, yet will not be 23 until the tournament is nearly over. Marvellous control and vision set him apart both as a scorer and creator of goals and if the Spanish are to fulfil their potential Raul will have to be one of the stars of the tournament. He is well capable.

Finest hour? Nothing at international level to match Real Madrid's eight European Cups.

Worst moment? General Franco giving the Soviet Union a bye into the semi-finals of the first ever European Championships, withdrawing from a fixture due to political differences.

Fans favourite? Raul. Fernando Hierro, if his knees are up to it.

We love to hate? No hate figures. Spain are too much of a soft touch.

A Spanish view on Spain 'Things are looking good. They should make the semi-finals at least, then... who knows? So many European teams are in poor form at the moment. Along with Spain, Holland and France must also be favourites.' Guillem Balague (Sky pundit.)

The Spanish Des is... Michael Robinson. The former Liverpool player, has carved out an amazingly successful television career in Spain.

Chant 'Espana! Espana!' (Spain! Spain! obviously)

webTitle: The OSM lowdown on Group C

fields.headline: The OSM lowdown on Group C
fields.trailText: Observer Sport Monthly's verdict on the group and the round-up of television coverage
fields.body:
2 questions that will decide Group C

1 Will Norway do a Wimbledon?

No, they parted company with Egil Olsen in plenty of time. And in any case John Hartson is Welsh. But they won't surprise many people with their workrate and direct approach so the big guns should prevent them qualifying.

2 Are Yugoslavia the new Croatia?

Controversially put. Of course Yugoslavia took great delight in edging out the Croats (who finished third at France 98) in qualification, but are unlikely to emulate their bitter rivals at the tournament itself. Yes they too play with fearsome pride and no little skill, but they are also old and lackadaisical.

OSM prediction

1 Spain

2 Yugoslavia

3 Norway

4 Slovenia

Spain v Norway (ITV, 5pm)

Sunday 18

Spain v Slovenia (BBC, 5pm)

Norway v Yugoslavia (BBC, ES, 7.45pm)

Wednesday 21

Spain v Yugoslavia (BBC to decide, 5pm)

Slovenia v Norway (BBC to decide, 5pm)

fields.headline: Turkey
fields.standfirst: Odds 66/1
fields.trailText: How did they qualify? Via the play-offs, at the Republic of Ireland's expense.
fields.body:
How did they qualify? Via the play-offs, at the Republic of Ireland's expense.

How do they beat you? Sheer bloody minded determination. They have worked hard at improving their fitness, enabling them to fight for the right to play (and when they play they are swift and skilful). They have a strong spine, from goalkeeper Rustu, through captain and defensive stalwart Ogun, via enigmatic playmaker Sergen, to worshipped striker Hakan Sukur. Turkey do need to find the scoring habit at this level though, having failed to register a single goal during Euro 96.

How do you beat them? If you chip away at their morale, and press them into submission, there's a good chance they will become tired and flat.

What's their manager like? Lucky. Not only does Mustafa Denizli benefit from a squad created by his inspired predecessor Fatih Terim, he is also set to quit for a £2.5m contract with Fenerbahce immediately after the Euros. Which is not bad going for a coach who has had his share of critics.

Tournament record Just one appearance so far, last time out at Euro 96, when they failed to make it out of their group.

But they are improving, aren't they? Absolutely. An impressive evolution in Turkish football, buoyed by Galatasaray's Uefa Cup triumph, fuels a surging self-belief.

Best footballing moment? Winning gold at under-21 level at the Mediterranean games in 1993.

They'd love to beat? Germany - which they often do - and Belgium. Turkey bear a grudge against the co-hosts for beating them to a place at France 98.

The Turks on Turkey 'We are quietly confident. Our team is united behind the aim of reaching the quarter-finals for the first time in our history. Beyond that, who knows? Hakan Suker is the main man - he will score lots' Emin Orgev (Hurriyet)

The Turkish Des is... Ercan Taner of Sine 5. 'He is very popular, very jokey like Mr Lynam.'

Chant 'En Buyok Turkiye' ('The great Turkey')

fields.headline: Sweden
fields.standfirst: Odds 14/1
fields.trailText: How did they qualify? Serenely, as every English fan knows. Topped Group Five after putting the skids under Glenn Hoddle's England in Stockholm, and had enough energy left to defeat Poland in an otherwise meaningless final game and let Kevin Keegan's side into Euro 2000 through the back door.
fields.body:
How did they qualify? Serenely, as every English fan knows. Topped Group Five after putting the skids under Glenn Hoddle's England in Stockholm, and had enough energy left to defeat Poland in an otherwise meaningless final game and let Kevin Keegan's side into Euro 2000 through the back door.

A good bet for the later stages then... Not necessarily. Henrik Larsson suffered a badly broken leg in the autumn and has hardly played since. Otherwise the Swedes' mix of bit-part players and clubmen from Europe's lesser lights looks unthreatening, though Group B is not one of the most demanding.

Tournament record Poor, though they were semi-finalists in 1992.

How do you beat them? Don't underestimate them, as England did after taking the lead in Stockholm. Coventry's Magnus Hedman is not the most secure of international goalkeepers.

How do they beat you? With difficulty these days. The organisational flair is still there but the goals are drying up. The return of Henrik Larsson may improve things in that department.

What's their manager like? Make that managers. Sweden are the only side going into Euro 2000 with joint managers, or joint coaches to be strictly accurate (they clearly never sought Gerard Houllier's advice on the subject.) The two are Tommy Soderberg, who succeeded Tommy Svensson and Lar Lagerback. A sceptical Swedish media are prone to describing them as Soderback or Lagerberg. 'Four eyes see more than two and the players hear two voices,' Soderberg insists, sounding uncannily like Roy Evans did in his brief stint as co-manager with Houllier.

A Swedish view on Sweden 'Hopes were high after we qualified but since then injuries to players such as Larsson and Schwarz have dampened the mood drastically. Ljungberg's fitness is crucial and we will struggle if he is unable to play. Don't expect fireworks but I think we will qualify from the group. I expect the Czech Republic to win the tournament.' Johan Esk (Dagens Nyheter, Stockholm)

The Swedish Des is... Arne Hegerfors . Very much in the Des mould, he won over male and female fans with his squinting eyes and humorous asides.

Chant 'Heja Sverige friskt humör, det är det som susen gör.' (Come on Sweden, keep your spirits up, that's what we need).

fields.headline: Belgium
fields.standfirst: Odds 12/1
fields.trailText: How did they qualify? Automatically, as hosts. This was lucky, because soon after the World Cup they entered an appalling phase that would have got them knocked out in any qualifying group. They drew against Luxembourg and later lost five straight games without scoring a goal. The nation turned off: on a trip to Japan and South Korea last summer, the team were accompanied by just one fan. Then came their new coach Robert Waseige and Belgium have been phenomenal since. It's hard to explain.
fields.body:
How did they qualify? Automatically, as hosts. This was lucky, because soon after the World Cup they entered an appalling phase that would have got them knocked out in any qualifying group. They drew against Luxembourg and later lost five straight games without scoring a goal. The nation turned off: on a trip to Japan and South Korea last summer, the team were accompanied by just one fan. Then came their new coach Robert Waseige and Belgium have been phenomenal since. It's hard to explain.

How do you beat them? The 36-year-old Lorenzo Staelens is slow in central defence, Filip de Wilde does not fit the lineage of great Belgian keepers, and not one Belgian plays for a top-notch European club. This is a solid team, but hardly a great one, and perhaps excepting Mpenza, the Belgians cannot rely on individual genius.

How do they beat you? God knows, but they do. Waseige, who took over last summer, has transformed this team. Belgium were traditionally a counter-attacking side, the Little Italy of European football. Under Waseige they always play the same 4-4-2 system. They still have granite defenders, led by the astute Staelens, but nowadays they can also sweep forward at pace. They lack the gifts of the legendary Belgian side of the 1980s, but their recent results have been as good.

What's their manager like? Waseige looks like a café owner. This may have got him the job, since Belgium's excellent manager of the 1980s, Guy Thijs, also looked like a café owner. Both Thijs and the fat little Waseige smoke cigars, drink whisky and have a knack for creating a happy camp, which suits the relaxed attitude of the Belgian footballer. Another point in Waseige's favour is that he is a native French-speaker who is also fluent in Dutch. The Francophone press had grown to despise the Fleming Leekens.

Tournament record Better than you might think. Belgium came third in 1972, when they hosted the tournament, and reached the final in 1980, where (and this may sound familiar) they lost to Germany on a last-minute goal.

The main man is... Marc Wilmots is known at Schalke, his German club, as 'Das Kampfschwein', or The Fighting Pig. The agricultural metaphors suit this farmer's boy, who says: 'If I lose I am hard to enjoy. Then my wife really has a couple of tough days with me.' Charging forward from central midfield à la Bryan Robson, The Fighting Pig scores freely. Exhausted at the end of the season, he plans to sleep for a week before Euro 2000.

Fans' favourite player? It depends on the fan's ethnicity. Francophones like Francophones (they would have Enzo Scifo back in the team, and make him ruler of Wallonia, if he wanted) while Dutch-speakers prefer Dutch-speakers.

Too good for the national team? Luc Nilis is known in this land of cartoonists as Lucky Luc. 'Unlucky Luc' might be more appropriate, since Belgium's most gifted player cannot currently find a place in the team. One theory is that he is too slow and old; another, that at the World Cup of 1994 he won too much money from team-mates in late-night poker sessions. Nilis's place is currently taken by Strupar, who, like many footballers before him, is a naturalised Belgian.

The typical Belgian player's characteristic demeanour is tie undone, bestubbled face, bottle of excellent Belgian beer in hand, stumbling out of the changing room after another surprise victory unhindered by any journalists wanting interviews. He will cadge a lift home from a mate or a fan.

They'd love to beat? Holland. The Belgians consider the Dutch arrogant, and call them 'Fat Necks'. But the rivalry is gentle: when the countries met at the last World Cup, there was only one incident, and it was between some Belgian fans.

A Belgian view on Belgium 'In a year the situation has completely changed. A year ago Belgium's performances were dramatic and it was generally thought they would not survive the first round. Now reaching the second round is a certainty to most. The turnaround coincided with the appointment of the new manager Robert Waseige. The line-up has hardly changed but the results are completely different. The team has grown enormously. Belgium are still no favourites for the title, but the second round could be interesting.' François Colin (Het Nieuwsblad)

The Belgian Des is... Marc Uyterhoven, a former sports journalist, who has become an immensely popular television entertainer. 'He does not present a sports program during the football season, but since the 1994 World Cup he does the big tournaments.' (Very Des-like.)

Chant 'The difficulty is that we are split in two by the two national languages. I don't ever see them unite in communal singing. Some will copy some English songs, but that's about it.'

fields.headline: Italy
fields.standfirst: Odds 9/2
fields.trailText: How did they qualify? Comfortable winners of Group One, though losing 3-2 at home to Denmark did not impress their highly critical spectators. Dino Zoff, needless to say, is already under a certain amount of pressure to do well in Euro 2000.
fields.body:
How did they qualify? Comfortable winners of Group One, though losing 3-2 at home to Denmark did not impress their highly critical spectators. Dino Zoff, needless to say, is already under a certain amount of pressure to do well in Euro 2000.

Surely Italians don't care about two-bit competitions like the European Championships? True, otherwise they would have managed to win it on more than the one occasion (1968, since you ask). But Italy are not exactly setting World Cups on fire either these days, and the country is locked in a debate about whether to stifle matches in the traditional manner or embrace the new, pan-European trend for open, entertaining football. Arrigo Sacchi bore the brunt of Italy's unexpected failure at Euro 96, and though Cesare Maldini's side looked solid enough in the last World Cup and only lost in the quarter-final to France on penalties, the manager was condemned for being too unadventurous. And for looking like Iggy Pop.

How do you beat them? Either show more attacking imagination (not difficult), or show none at all and hope the game goes to penalties. The Italians are almost as bad as England at penalty shoot-outs.

Won't they miss Christian Vieri? Well anyone would, the world's most costly footballer adding some muscle to all that Italian sophistication. But the replacements aren't bad either (see below).

How do they beat you? They have the most expensive forwards in the world (even without Vieri). Filippo Inzaghi, Vincenzo Montella and Alessandro del Piero all know where the goal is. And their defence is usually top notch too, with a long list of goalkeepers and full-backs of the calibre of Paolo Maldini and Christian Panucci to complement a newish centre-back pairing of Fabio Cannavaro and Alessandro Nesta.

Tournament record Semi-finalists in 1988, otherwise nothing to speak of since 1968. World Cup winners in 1982 and finalists in 1990, but Italy have been a declining force since rule tweaks gave an advantage to attacking teams 10 years ago.

What's their manager like? Dino Zoff, one of Italy's most famous and most capped goalkeepers and veteran of 1968, has yet to establish a style after taking over from Maldini. He's in something of a no-win situation with his public, who will no longer tolerate caution yet are reluctant to see Italy takes risks. Zoff was pilloried when Italy went looking for more goals against Denmark and paid the price for not shutting up shop. The team's confidence was still low when they subsequently lost 3-1 to Belgium in a pre-tournament friendly.

The typical Italian player looks like a film star (but is probably better paid.)

The main man is... It's time for the divinely talented Alessandro del Piero, a consistent underachiever on the international stage, to show the rest of Europe what he's capable of.

Would love to beat France or Germany in the final.

Finest hour? Winning the World Cup twice in succession in the Thirties, beating West Germany in the 1982 final, inventing practically a whole new ball game during the Sixties and Seventies.

Worst moment? Realising Brazil too, were playing something entirely different in 1970, failing to qualify for European Championships in 1976, 1984 and 1992.

Fans favourite? Paolo Maldini, one of the only constants in Italian national football in recent times.

fields.trailText: Observer Sport Monthly's verdict on the group and the round-up of television coverage
fields.body:
2 questions that will decide Group B

1 Isn't Turkish football much better than it is given credit for?

Yes, and several of their players will be flying after Galatasaray's historic feat in winning a European trophy for Turkey at long last, but their record in international tournaments is still terrible.

Actually he could. Derby's Branko Strupar has formed what the Belgians call a 'royal couple' up front with Emile Mpenza, the two of them scoring all the time. fields.headline: Romania
fields.standfirst: Odds 33/1
fields.trailText: How did they qualify? Impressively. Romania were unbeaten in Group Seven and finished on top of the table ahead of Portugal, their Euro 2000 Group A opponents, largely thanks to a 1-0 victory in Porto which was the high point of the qualification campaign.
fields.body:
How did they qualify? Impressively. Romania were unbeaten in Group Seven and finished on top of the table ahead of Portugal, their Euro 2000 Group A opponents, largely thanks to a 1-0 victory in Porto which was the high point of the qualification campaign.

So England had better watch out? Yes, particularly as Romania were 2-1 winners when the sides last met in France 98. That match turned out to be the Romanians' Cup final, however, since a disappointing draw with Tunisia, followed by defeat at the hands of Croatia saw them slide out of the World Cup at the same second round stage as England.

Tournament record Not as good as their ability to qualify with ease might suggest. Four years ago they arrived at Euro 96 as unbeaten group winners, only to depart England early after three straight defeats.

How do you beat them? Keep the pressure on, don't let them dictate the pace of the game. 'Our lack of concentration has hurt us in major competitions,' said coach Emerich Ienei. 'It's a national characteristic.'

How do they beat you? Quick break specialists. Most of their players are comfortable on the ball, which they can retain effortlessly and patiently until the time is right to launch an attack.

What's their manager like? Ienei is freshly installed, taking over from Victor Piturca once Romania had qualified, some say at the behest of Gheorge Hagi. The former Steaua Bucharest manager is not exactly new to the job, having taken Romania to Italia 90, but is seen as a stop gap capable of supervising one last hurrah from an ageing team.

A Romanian view on Romania 'It will be very hard for us to beat Germany and England but we will win against Portugal. I think Germany will win the tournament but Romania will get knocked out in the quarter-finals.' Slain Dinescu (Rompress).

The Romanian Des is... Janal Stoica. 'He's no good and he's not funny but he's very popular.' In Romania this counts as high praise indeed.

Chant 'We do not sing but we like your "We are the champions."'
