fields.headline: England
fields.standfirst: Odds 10/1
fields.trailText: How did they qualify? A question many people are still asking themselves. Briefly, they lost the lead and their first match in Sweden, then their coach lost the plot. A mini-resurgence under Kevin Keegan was followed by a series of unconvincing draws which was just enough, with Sweden's help, to secure a play-off place. A good first half at Hampden saw off Scotland, who nevertheless put a huge dampener on English optimism by winning at Wembley.
fields.body:
How did they qualify? A question many people are still asking themselves. Briefly, they lost the lead and their first match in Sweden, then their coach lost the plot. A mini-resurgence under Kevin Keegan was followed by a series of unconvincing draws which was just enough, with Sweden's help, to secure a play-off place. A good first half at Hampden saw off Scotland, who nevertheless put a huge dampener on English optimism by winning at Wembley.

So England won't be expecting too much this summer? Don't be silly. 'I definitely believe we are capable of winning Euro 2000,' says Keegan. 'We might not have been too impressive in qualifying but if we start firing on all cylinders once the real thing gets under way there are no teams out there we need fear.'

How do they beat you? They talk like Keegan does, and remind people that they won the World Cup in 1966. If that doesn't work they put crosses in for Alan Shearer, or rely on the the youthful zest of Michael Owen, probably the only English striker foreign defenders will worry about.

How do you beat them? Put a marker on Shearer and make sure David Beckham doesn't get the run of the right wing by pushing him back into defence and kick Owen. Alternatively, try and ensure the game goes to a penalty shoot-out.

Tournament record Nothing worth mentioning until reaching the semi-finals last time out in Euro 96. Quite a bit of experience in the squad though, which is basically the same group of players who lost to Germany under Terry Venables and to Argentina in the last World Cup.

What's their manager like? The thoroughly likeable, positive and media-friendly Keegan. At least, he's media-friendly now. Relations on both sides may sour dramatically if England suffer a couple of defeats. Keegan has proved himself a capable club manager at clubs with money to spend and plenty of room for improvement, though it was distinctly worrying to hear him confess a few years ago he had no idea how to take Newcastle a stage further. Appointed principally for his unalarming religious beliefs and skeleton-free cupboard, Keegan is a perfect England manager between matches, but could easily come unstuck in a tournament situation unless he can show a more decisive grasp of tactics and an ability to change things around on the pitch. If it all goes badly wrong, expect the next England manager to be a taciturn chap with a sheaf of coaching certificates. These things go in cycles.

The typical English player is keener on Keegan than Hoddle, 100 per cent committed (make that 110 per cent). Still fond of a drink.

The main man is David Beckham. The hope is that Alan Shearer will bow out with a bang, the expectation is that he will be eclipsed, as he was in France, by Michael Owen. The reality, however, is that England's most accomplished and consistent player by a distance is David Beckham. After being dropped for the first game in France 98, then making an even earlier exit than his team-mates through his petulant foul on Diego Simeone, this should be Beckham's best chance yet to shine on the international stage. England could certainly do with it.

Finest hour? 1966's Jules Rimet is still gleaming, although the 4-1 dissection of Holland at Wembley in 1996 ranks just as high in pure footballing terms.

Worst moment? Usually connected with managers - Don Revie's resignation, Graham Taylor's fly-on-the-wall documentary, Venables' business dealings, Hoddle's syntax, and so on. In recent footballing terms, England's flops at Euro 88 and Euro 92 were both spectacular.

Would love to beat Anybody. Just kidding. Things aren't quite that bad. Keegan will be forgiven a lot if he can organise a victory over Germany in Charleroi on June 17, especially if he can repeat it in World Cup qualifying games next season.

Fans' favourite player? Tony Adams, with Michael Owen waiting in the wings.

We love to hate? Diminutive Chelsea captain Dennis Wise, who should have far more England caps than he has.

An English view on England 'All 16 teams have a chance, although for once I don't think we have anything to fear from the Germans,' says Kenneth Wolstenholme, who's seen a few German sides in his time. 'I fear the Romanians more: they're a tough old bunch and we have a terrible record against them. I think Keegan knows what he's doing and England are more than capable of making the semi-finals, but I fancy Spain to beat France in the final.'

The English Des is Many have tried to snatch Des Lynam's crown, from Steve Ryder (too grey) to Gary Lineker (greying), but none have succeeded. The ITV move hasn't gone as smoothly as expected and his moustache is showing signs of waning, but Des remains the nation's favourite grey.

Chant The ubiquitous 'In-ger-land!'

fields.headline: Germany
fields.standfirst: Odds 9/1
fields.trailText: How did they qualify? Haltingly. Germany were stuck in an absurdly easy group. They handled Finland, Moldova and Northern Ireland with relative aplomb, but lost in Turkey and eventually qualified by holding the Turks 0-0 at home. The phrase, 'This is the worst German team ever', is now a German cliche.
fields.body:
How did they qualify? Haltingly. Germany were stuck in an absurdly easy group. They handled Finland, Moldova and Northern Ireland with relative aplomb, but lost in Turkey and eventually qualified by holding the Turks 0-0 at home. The phrase, 'This is the worst German team ever', is now a German cliche.

How do you beat them? With increasing ease. (Scotland and the US - twice - are among their recent conquerors.) Germany lack skill. The crucial thing is to pass the ball around and to avoid any tussles for fifty-fifty balls, which Germans always win. Franz Beckenbauer says that if you woke up the German World Cup-winners of 1990 in the night and made them play the current side barefoot, they would hammer them.

How do they beat you? Germany still possess the 'German virtues', ie they run their socks off, kick like mules, and never leave their posts, but not much else. They retain a couple of secret weapons: Oliver Kahn is possibly Europe's best keeper, and the Germans remain excellent at penalties. They even have a reserve goalie by the name of Hans-Jörg Butt who is not merely an expert at saving the things but also at taking them. If every match goes to penalties, Germany will win Euro 2000. Otherwise probably not.

What's their manager like? Erich Ribbeck is a well-coiffed , well-spoken elderly gentleman, who is generally believed to know nothing about football. In fact the Dutchman Jan Wouters, when a player at Bayern Munich, told Ribbeck: 'The only person at this club who knows nothing about football, is you.' Ribbeck was living in semi-retirement in Tenerife when the German FA handed him the job. He may now regret taking it. In recent weeks he has had to sack his assistant, Uli Stielike, suspend his key player Jens Jeremies for a match after remarks in the press, and listen to Beckenbauer declare that he would lose his job immediately after Euro 2000.

Tournament record The best, of course. Germany won the championships of 1972, 1980 and 1996, and lost in the final in 1976 and 1992. Mathematical analysis reveals that they have reached the final in five of the last seven tournaments.

The typical German player thinks flair is something to do with fashion.

The main man is... Jens Jeremies. The Germans have heralded him as the new Matthäus. That is too much honour for a man who charges about like a puppy but suffers from tunnel vision. However, the Germans say that Jeremies is still very young (he is 26) and is gradually taking more responsibility. Indeed, he recently took it upon himself to reveal to the press that the atmosphere around the national team was 'miserable'. He broke his collar bone in early May but shouldn't miss much of the competition. Jeremies, who can play in midfield or as libero, would be better suited to charismatic leadership if he washed his hair and had it cut.

Player the fans love to hate? Lothar Matthäus. He represented the arrogance of Bayern Munich, can no longer run, and undermines his former team-mates with sly remarks to his pet journalists at Bild newspaper and Kicker magazine.

Fans' favourite player? Lothar Matthäus. An international for twenty years, with more vision than all his team-mates put together, still possessed of a pass that can hit your tie-pin over sixty yards, the most astute of defenders. Among fans of the national team, he has more supporters than detractors.

Too good for the national team? Stefan Effenberg. There have been many bizarre and difficult great German footballers (Paul Breitner, Bernd Schuster and Matthäus spring to mind) but Effenberg had probably clinched the all-comers prize even before he showed his middle finger to his own fans at the World Cup of 1994. The Bayern playmaker could transform this German side. But he hates the people at the German FA, so he doesn't feel like it.

A German view on Germany 'Confidence is not so high: I think maybe Germany can reach the quarter-finals, but no further. Their defence is weak and recent results have been poor. The German fans believe that the England game will be very tough, much tougher than in the past, and of course Kevin Keegan is still very popular in Germany.' Berrys Bosmann (Die Welt)

The German Des Lynam is... Gunther Netzer. 'The former international is one of the biggest characters on German television.'

webTitle: The OSM lowdown on Group A

fields.headline: The OSM lowdown on Group A
fields.trailText: Observer Sport Monthly's verdict on the group and the round-up of television coverage
fields.body:
2 questions that will decide Group A

1 Has Alan Shearer got one last tournament in him?
Kevin Keegan obviously thinks so, but then he wasn't at the last World Cup. Not officially anyway. Shearer was feted as one of the world's best strikers during Euro 96, and few doubted the £15m Newcastle paid for him shortly afterwards, but there has been a serious injury and a disappointing World Cup since then.

2 Is this really the worst German side since the war?
The Germans certainly seem to think so, and it's not all black propaganda either. Bringing Lothar Matthäus back from America tells its own story (he's only four months younger than Gary Lineker, for goodness sake) and Germany have just lost Christian Worns, one of their better players. Anyone watching England qualify, however, might surmise Kevin Keegan too is in charge of the worst England side since the war. The Boer War.

1 Portugal
2 Germany
3 England
4 Romania

Monday 12
Germany v Romania (BBC, 5pm)
Portugal v England (ITV, ES 7.45pm)

England v Germany (BBC, ITV, 7.45pm)

webTitle: The tactical test facing Keegan the coach

fields.headline: The tactical test facing Keegan the coach
fields.standfirst: Ian Ridley offers his views on how to make the most of McManaman while Gordon Strachan and Craig Hignett give a different perspective in recommending their ideal England teams
fields.trailText: Ian Ridley offers his views on how to make the most of McManaman while Gordon Strachan and Craig Hignett give a different perspective in recommending their ideal England teams
fields.body:
It was midnight in Warsaw. England had just drawn 0-0 with Poland and looked to be heading out of the European Championships (the Poles now needing only a draw against Sweden to pip the English for a play-off place) and a weary, deflated Kevin Keegan was trying to make sense of it all. Soon the uncomfortable topic of Steve McManaman came up, his stumbling performance wide on the left symbolic of England's travails.

'I asked Steve to do a job for England in that position and I am taking something away from him by doing that,' Keegan admitted. Nine months on, the Swedes having done England a favour by beating Poland, you can only hope that Keegan has learned from the experience. English hopes rest on him finding a way of getting the most out of one of the country's most talented creative individuals for the forthcoming tournament.

McManaman's recent performances in Real Madrid's midfield, culminating in his energetic display and elegant goal in the Champions League final, seem to have taken the nation by storm and surprise, especially recalling the forlorn isolated figure in Warsaw.

Not this observer, though. A few days after Poland, he wrote: 'McManaman is potentially a great player - no please, stick with this a while longer. Granted, his air of foppish insouciance can be maddening but England are not so well blessed with such skilful ball-carriers that they can afford to throw out this baby with the bath water.'

That view was formed by McManaman's performances during Euro 96 when Terry Venables devised a system that had him receiving the ball in space, cutting inside from wide and linking with other adaptable players such as Teddy Sheringham and Darren Anderton. There is no reason why he should not do so again, rather than just being asked to fill space, and deny it to the opposition, in order to occupy a problem position. 'He can be a raider for us in the same way that Marc Overmars is for Arsenal,' says Tony Adams.

John Barnes once told me that Liverpool's way of playing was designed to feed McManaman the ball into space, that dangerous area between the opposition's midfield and attack. It is not a question of McManaman being given a free role. After all, he has shown his defensive, tackling qualities at Real and was certainly expected by Venables to track back for England. It is more about setting up the team up so that the best of his game can be inflicted on the opposition. Barnes was one who rarely did for England what he could for his club. If McManaman becomes another, it could well say more about Keegan than the player. It will be a serious examination of the manager's tactical credentials.

The Manager
Gordon Strachan (Coventry)

Martyn
G Neville, Adams, Campbell, P Neville
Beckham, Scholes, Gerrard, Guppy
Shearer, Phillips

Jason Wilcox was my first choice for the problem spot on the left, because of his ability to help Beckham in giving Shearer and Phillips a good supply of crosses. When he dropped out because of injury I would have brought in Guppy. He is more of a dribbler than Wilcox, but he is a natural left-side player and if you were tell him to get the ball into the box as early as possible, I think he would do it.

Apart from Shearer and Phillips, the other major source of England goals is obviously Scholes. He needs to have someone who can cover for him when he goes forward, and Gerrard fits the bill perfectly. Apart from being a good all-round player, he is easily the fittest of the midfielders in the England squad.

The Player
Craig Hignett (Barnsley)

Seaman
Adams, Campbell, Keown
Barmby, Beckham, Scholes, Ince, P Neville
Shearer, Phillips

I think that Barmby could do an excellent job as a right wing-back - he could actually alternate with Beckham. He is an extremely intelligent player who seems to be able to run all day. To be honest, the more I think about him in this role, the more I like the idea.

My first choice as a striking partner for Shearer would have to be Robbie Fowler, but as it is doubtful that he is going to be fit enough, I have no qualms about going for Phillips. He is such a good finisher - that is bound to take a lot of pressure off Shearer - and when comparing him with the other strikers in the squad, you also have to take into account the sort of season he has had with Sunderland.

fields.headline: Judgement days
fields.standfirst: Kevin Keegan has been lauded and lampooned in equal measure since getting the job of England coach. The next month will determine whether he was the right choice
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan has been lauded and lampooned in equal measure since getting the job of England coach. The next month will determine whether he was the right choice
fields.body:
In football, managers usually depart the way they arrive - fired with enthusiasm. Usually, too, they are chosen as the antidote to what has preceded them. Take the history of the England team over the last decade.

There was Graham Taylor, decent, honourable and well-suited to the Football Association blazer. He represented the logical conclusion of the direct-style English game of the Eighties but both he and it were ultimately found wanting when it came to the tactical nuances of the international game.

He was followed by Terry Venables, who finally succeeded in getting the most out of the more gifted players, employing to boot the adage that you had better treat them like men because sooner or later you are going to have to ask them to play like men. Venables was in tune with the development of the modern game and his mobile team promised progress. There was scepticism within the Football Association, though, about his tangled business affairs and he and they fell out.

Then came Glenn Hoddle, supposedly clean-cut, loosely described as a born-again Christian, who appeared likely to carry on the Venables modernisation programme, and who couldn't possibly embarrass them. He did, by departing from the physical to the spiritual, even if the whole episode of comments about the disabled now seems more of a fiasco than it did at the time. More significant was his dourness of character, his players never really warming to him as he kept himself at too great a distance from them.

Which brings us to Kevin Keegan, bubbly, charismatic and enthusiastic Kev, approachable and talkative, with more entries in the various entertaining volumes of the Football Book of Quotations than virtually anyone else. He was the only choice, said the FA, looking to a Mr Motivator to inspire the players and excite the nation after a hitherto listless qualifying campaign for Euro 2000. The reservations have always been about his qualifications for the job and the quality of expertise he might bring to it but the FA clearly decided it was no time for quibbling.

He has indeed at least returned some optimism to the country's game. No sooner had England qualified for this summer's European Championship finals by the play-off back door than he was showing his front by declaring, customarily wearing his mouth on his sleeve, that the country could even win it. Whether he will remain in perception as an appropriate leader will unfold over the next month. For it is only in a major tournament that an international manager's true mettle can properly be judged.

In many ways, Keegan is one of the more fortunate of England's managers. As Tony Adams, the man he has earmarked as his England captain when Alan Shearer retires from international football after Euro 2000, told me: 'He's got a lucky face.' In the usual black-and-white English fashion - how appropriate that Keegan's most memorable management days have so far been at Newcastle United - he was hailed as a worldbeater after England beat Scotland 2-0 at Hampden Park last November. Four days later, there was Euroscepticism as England lost 1-0 at Wembley. The fortuitous spin-off was that expectations this summer are consequently probably lower than they have ever been for an England team going to a tournament.

As one of its most influential figures, the Keegan story says much about the culture of the English game over the past few decades as he dragged himself up by the bootlaces from humble origins, worked tirelessly on self-improvement but was frustrated at the highest level, despite much club success. It is undoubtedly why he retains the common touch and a passion for the game to stoke the home fires, qualities for which people forgive him much amid the occasional foot-in-mouth disease from which he suffers.

Kevin Joseph Keegan OBE (for services when a player) was born in Armthorpe, near Doncaster, on Valentine's Day of 1951 and has been in love with the game ever since. There was a time when he walked away from her but eventually her allure drew him back as it always seemed likely to do. 'What do you find to replace football?' he once asked. 'Because there isn't anything.'

As a kid, he kicked a ball around a patch of green known as the Bullring in the mining area of Balby near Doncaster, a town guaranteed to give solid grounding in the game of the working man and forge ideas of better things. Keegan has retained elements of both, daring to dream while we professional doubters doubt. Not that his first professional club was glamorous. On away trips with Scunthorpe United, the local Evening Telegraph reporter (Tom Taylor, Graham's dad) would sit him on his knee on the coach and, game for a laugh, Keegan would act as ventriloquist's dummy. No dummy was he, though. Bill Shankly would sign him for Liverpool and so began one of the great English careers, one that yielded 63 caps to add to the sweet silver sound of Anfield's golden era.

Shankly also became Keegan's mentor and ever since his speech has been punctuated with the great man's aphorisms. Indeed, Keegan is fond of telling players of similar darting-striker style to 'go and drop a few hand grenades out there.' He did it with Gavin Peacock in his first match at Newcastle. Now he tells Paul Scholes for England.

It was appropriate that Keegan should have moved to Hamburg after his glittering career with Liverpool. German football was blue-collar industrious and functional and by his own admission, he made the most of what was not a natural talent, working diligently to access the depths of his playing resources. He flourished in such an atmosphere of professionalism, winning two European player of the year awards. The Germans nicknamed him Mighty Mouse.

It was fitting, too, that he should return to play for Southampton, leading them to their highest league position of runners-up, as he had now developed a fondness for unusual challenges. Finally as a player, he took Newcastle back into the top flight before being helicoptered away in front of St James' Park's wondrous gaze. In their eyes, it might have been to Mount Olympus. The Messiah had got them out of the mess.

And that seemed to be that. Perhaps drained by having extracted every ounce of his abilities, he took himself off to Spain, scene of his only World Cup, all 27 minutes of it when he was rusty after a back injury and missed a gilt-edged chance as England slipped out of the 1982 tournament. The experience, coupled with him later finding out that his international career was over from the press rather than the manager Bobby Robson, seemed for a while to sour him. He vowed that he would not be tempted back into the English game, certainly not as a manager.

Eight years later came Sir John Hall to rekindle the affair and there followed five years of rebuilding Newcastle into the regional giant it had once been. At the age of nearly 41, Keegan had his first managerial job in his second coming. After his first game, a 3-0 win over Bristol City as he fought to keep the team out of the old Third Division, he observed: 'I always thought managers were more involved but when it comes down to it, I just sit there and watch like everyone else.'

During his tenure, the man who once described himself as an open book revealed every side of himself. Early on, Keegan threatened to resign when there appeared little money to strengthen the team. 'It's not like in the brochure,' he famously said. Sir John stumped up. Keegan has a convincing line in persuasion.

Managers often try to instil in their teams that which they themselves sense they lacked; George 'Stroller'Graham's fierce work ethic at Arsenal, for example. Keegan was infatuated with players of flamboyant gift, intrinsic to them, unlike his own - David Ginola, Faustino Asprilla - though he would also value Alan Shearer's manufactured productivity that so mirrored his own. His selection of England's captain, his persona on the pitch, through some tricky times in the last year, confirms it. Keegan's Newcastle side went on to play with a cavalier flair that was short of the defensive resilience necessary to win the Premiership title. 'A rollercoaster type of team,' said his main rival Sir Alex Ferguson.

To the strains of 'My Way', Keegan pressed on with his brand of thrilling but unfulfilled football, however. When he sold Andy Cole, there was uproar but he simply invited critics to apply for the manager's job themselves. 'Welcome to the grey hair club,' he told John Aldridge, another former Liverpool striker going into management at the time (in Aldridge's case, Tranmere Rovers).

When Keegan faced the final curtain, believing his authority undermined by the City suits raising financial points of order, Tyneside was shocked. On the day he left a Sunderland-supporting train driver halted by the banks of the big river and announced that this was now the chance for any Newcastle fans aboard to throw themselves in.

'If Kevin Keegan fell into the Tyne, he'd come up with a salmon in his mouth,' Jack Charlton once said of him. Smoked salmon from the Harrods food hall actually. The penchant for the offbeat challenge resurfaced and Keegan became Mohammed Al Fayed's lucrative henchman at Fulham, charged with getting them up to the Premiership within five years.

As he was chauffeured out of Craven Cottage on his first day, having spent two hours with the press, he waved from a limo and smiled. It told of the man - more often gestures to scribes involve fewer fingers and a different expression - showing him to be humanly friendly but almost regal in the English game. Tony Blair once said that his children were unimpressed by all the world leaders traipsing through 10 Downing Street but were in awe when he said he had met Kevin Keegan.

He began at Fulham as something called chief operating officer but taking over the manager's job was only a matter of time. Job half-done, at first he resisted England's blandishments but as if to answer the question about what are minds for if not for changing, he took the caretaker's post. He liked the job so much that he agreed a three-year contract. The mistress that is the England post is like that. With its needs rampant, Graham Taylor may once have called it the impossible job but few are the men, flattered by the attention, who can resist her. As he squires his biggest squeeze at Euro 2000, she will make unprecedented demands on the character and judgement formed by his career thus far. The real deal begins here.

Typically of the English game, Kevin Keegan possesses no coaching qualifications. In Italy and Germany, those put in charge of the national team come through the ranks having been groomed and coached themselves. The France team that won the World Cup in 1998 was the product of a well-planned system, the now-Liverpool manager Gerard Houllier at its apex as technical director.

The English game seemed to have learned, with Howard Wilkinson installed as Houllier's counterpart and a structure of development put in place. Keegan's appointment seems a regression, almost a panic measure as return to the knee-jerk responses of managers' departures.

The advantages were that England were getting a popular figure with whom the supporters could identify, in contrast to the aloof Hoddle who finally appeared to have lost the mood of the country. 'Fans want to sing,' he once said about all-seater stadia, 'and unless you're Val Doonican, you can't do that sitting down.' In addition, his teams had a reputation for style. He mirrored, too, a nation's desire for passion play. 'He is like rocket fuel,' said an eccentric character by the name of Watt Nicholl, a sort of sports psychologist whom Keegan briefly invited into the England camp early on to cheer his players. Now had Hoddle employed such a figure

The reservations have also concerned an occasionally touchy temperament, leading to fears that he could simply walk away if the going gets tough, since he is a rich enough man to do so having known his own worth; £750,000 a year with Fulham, £1m, including endorsements, with England. He resents both accusations, but just about resists a temptation to bristle when they are raised, knowing that to do so would only fuel them.

He defies a critic to tell him when he has ever quit and has explanations aplenty for England after the World Cup of 1982 - he was dropped, simply saw which way the wind was blowing and announced his retirement from the international game - Newcastle in '97 - his power being diluted - and Fulham '99, which was said to be an amicable arrangement.

Nevertheless, a spat with Sir Alex Ferguson has become one of those magic television moments. It was the run-in to the 1995-96 Championship and Manchester United were closing fast on Newcastle. Ferguson had riled Keegan with some of his trademark verbal psychology and Keegan was provoked into his 'I'd luv it if we beat them, absolutely luv it,' tirade in response.

He risked his dignity, in the manner of Graham Taylor with his 'I'm waking up with my pyjamas soaking wet,' Channel 4 documentary but redeemed himself in one way. 'The day I stop being emotional about football is the day I'll be back in Spain playing golf,' Keegan subsequently said and the fans identified anew. On the other hand, the team had seen his strain. They were to crumble.

He has also been ridiculed for some of his television remarks. 'England look the only side who can go on and win this,' he said shortly before Dan Petrescu's winner for Romania at France 98; David Batty will score, he insisted, moments before that penalty was saved against Argentina a fortnight later. 'You can't do better than a 0-0 draw away from home,' he once said.

But at least he is decisive, willing to climb off the fence on which the apprehensive and cowardly sit. As someone remarked, it's not falling down that is the mistake, it is being frightened to get up once you have fallen.

You ask him now about feeling any stress as England manager and how he might react to it in the summer and his face momentarily says 'Do I not like that question.' Then he rambles engagingly, ending characteristically on an upbeat note. 'I think I'll cope all right with it,' he says. 'I've got a good staff around me and we're well-organised for the tournament. We've crossed every 't' and dotted every 'i'. The downside is that if it doesn't go well, yes the flak will fly. But I also get the chance to do what no England manager has done: that is to win a major tournament away from this country.'

It is significant that on his first full day in office he said that he wanted to emulate the boys of '66 and he has subsequently often referred to English football's touchstone moment; again in tune with the nation's sense of its own pride but naïve, and even potentially damaging with its lack of humility, about the national team's true standing these days. (His record, in truth, is no more than average: four wins from his first 11 games.)

A comment by one of his former charges, Steve Howey, is revealing. 'It's impossible to dislike Kevin,' said the Newcastle centre-back, reminiscing about life under him at the club. 'You come in one morning feeling down but watching him whizz about brought you back to life. He wasn't really bothered about things like practising free-kicks but he made five-a-side feel like the World Cup.'

While players might feel that he can be a jovial friend - and the way his own England career ended has led to him saying that he will be sensitively telling in person any player cut from the squad - they should not ignore a potential for ruthlessness. The story goes that he once went to scout a player and left after the pre-match warm-up because he didn't like the way the player ran.

There have been signs lately that Keegan, in common with all his predecessors, has been irked by press comment, notably on the question of whether England would practise penalties this time. They would, he said, but not against Germany. However, the rider that this was because it was a group game and not knock-out was lost as he was made to look foolish.

But back he soon came with a disarming way, that a charming Bobby Robson also possessed, of continuing to talk football with reporters because it so enthused him. Keegan also has the knack of making an interviewer feel valid so that he elicits understanding. He is honest, but with a tendency to people-please by giving the answer he thinks they want to hear. One week recently, for example, he said that Graeme Le Saux was definitely out of Euro 2000. A fortnight later he said he would take him if he could just play one end-of-season game. Le Saux himself, to whom Keegan did not speak for four months, knew that he was never going to be fit.

'I approach it in the same way you would if you had the job,' he said when asked about any trepidation he might feel this summer. 'You look at your squad and I think we have a really good squad. Yes you could argue that the balance could be better but every other manager or coach is thinking the same thing. We have got a mass of strikers and defenders but we don't have a lot of full-backs. No-one has perfection.'

Therein lies the acid test. Keegan may indeed be a genial fellow but the job is about technical expertise and how he melds what he has at his disposal. On that, and consequent results, he should accept, and does, that he will be judged. 'My job is to try to get the players who can win a tournament for us into the side without it being a mish-mash,' he says. 'I'll probably be the first to admit in the past that it hasn't worked when I've experimented.'

He was referring to Steve McManaman, who has proved himself over the last couple of months an outstanding creative influence on Real Madrid (see panel). Hearteningly, Keegan believes he can accommodate him now in the England team the way Terry Venables did during Euro '96 in more appropriate areas than simply being isolated wide on the left. Currently (and despite the 4-4-2 he played against Brazil) it seems quite possible that his team will line-up in 3-5-2 formation because it suits the players. He appears to have accepted that he can no longer fit square pegs in round holes. 'I'm not as cavalier as people make out,' he says now of his development. 'I do like winning and I know what it takes to win.' To do that, he will need also to be flexible enough to adapt should games need a change of approach.

If he can, it will render redundant the caveats about no left-footed player of real note and concerns that England may revert to playing in straight lines, as they often did pre-Venables, rather than with the movement and adaptability they showed in Euro 96. If not, England may finally have to look to a coach of national gravitas - possibly foreign for the first time - rather than of clubbable personality.

Unlike Hoddle, Keegan is a personality who likes to sit and eat with his players and regale them with stories, mainly of the Bill Shankly era. For the younger players, it might seem as 'now'as Tales from Hoffnung. It is to be hoped he also listens to the veterans of foreign fields like Adams and Shearer. 'Maybe a character like Kevin is what we need at the moment,' says Adams. 'When it comes to knowledge, I think there are enough of us able to share it with him.'

After just over a year as manager, one thing Keegan has learned. 'Everything about the England job is magnified,' he observes of life in the goldfish bowl. Actually, it resembles more being on exhibition in some Damien Hirst tank. The summer will tell us whether the formaldehyde will be needed.

Indeed, Keegan is fond of telling players of similar darting-striker style to 'go and drop a few hand grenades out there.' He did it with Gavin Peacock in his first match at Newcastle. Now he tells Paul Scholes for England. It was appropriate that Keegan should have moved to Hamburg after his glittering career with Liverpool. German football was blue-collar industrious and functional and by his own admission, he made the most of what was not a natural talent, working diligently to access the depths of his playing resources. He flourished in such an atmosphere of professionalism, winning two European player of the year awards. The Germans nicknamed him Mighty Mouse. It was fitting, too, that he should return to play for Southampton, leading them to their highest league position of runners-up, as he had now developed a fondness for unusual challenges. Finally as a player, he took Newcastle back into the top flight before being helicoptered away in front of St James' Park's wondrous gaze. In their eyes, it might have been to Mount Olympus. The Messiah had got them out of the mess. And that seemed to be that. Perhaps drained by having extracted every ounce of his abilities, he took himself off to Spain, scene of his only World Cup, all 27 minutes of it when he was rusty after a back injury and missed a gilt-edged chance as England slipped out of the 1982 tournament. The experience, coupled with him later finding out that his international career was over from the press rather than the manager Bobby Robson, seemed for a while to sour him. He vowed that he would not be tempted back into the English game, certainly not as a manager. Eight years later came Sir John Hall to rekindle the affair and there followed five years of rebuilding Newcastle into the regional giant it had once been. At the age of nearly 41, Keegan had his first managerial job in his second coming. After his first game, a 3-0 win over Bristol City as he fought to keep the team out of the old Third Division, he observed: 'I always thought managers were more involved but when it comes down to it, I just sit there and watch like everyone else.' During his tenure, the man who once described himself as an open book revealed every side of himself. Early on, Keegan threatened to resign when there appeared little money to strengthen the team. 'It's not like in the brochure,' he famously said. Sir John stumped up. Keegan has a convincing line in persuasion. Managers often try to instil in their teams that which they themselves sense they lacked; George 'Stroller'Graham's fierce work ethic at Arsenal, for example. Keegan was infatuated with players of flamboyant gift, intrinsic to them, unlike his own - David Ginola, Faustino Asprilla - though he would also value Alan Shearer's manufactured productivity that so mirrored his own. His selection of England's captain, his persona on the pitch, through some tricky times in the last year, confirms it. Keegan's Newcastle side went on to play with a cavalier flair that was short of the defensive resilience necessary to win the Premiership title. 'A rollercoaster type of team,' said his main rival Sir Alex Ferguson. To the strains of 'My Way', Keegan pressed on with his brand of thrilling but unfulfilled football, however. When he sold Andy Cole, there was uproar but he simply invited critics to apply for the manager's job themselves. 'Welcome to the grey hair club,' he told John Aldridge, another former Liverpool striker going into management at the time (in Aldridge's case, Tranmere Rovers). When Keegan faced the final curtain, believing his authority undermined by the City suits raising financial points of order, Tyneside was shocked. On the day he left a Sunderland-supporting train driver halted by the banks of the big river and announced that this was now the chance for any Newcastle fans aboard to throw themselves in. 'If Kevin Keegan fell into the Tyne, he'd come up with a salmon in his mouth,' Jack Charlton once said of him. Smoked salmon from the Harrods food hall actually. The penchant for the offbeat challenge resurfaced and Keegan became Mohammed Al Fayed's lucrative henchman at Fulham, charged with getting them up to the Premiership within five years. As he was chauffeured out of Craven Cottage on his first day, having spent two hours with the press, he waved from a limo and smiled. It told of the man - more often gestures to scribes involve fewer fingers and a different expression - showing him to be humanly friendly but almost regal in the English game. Tony Blair once said that his children were unimpressed by all the world leaders traipsing through 10 Downing Street but were in awe when he said he had met Kevin Keegan. He began at Fulham as something called chief operating officer but taking over the manager's job was only a matter of time. Job half-done, at first he resisted England's blandishments but as if to answer the question about what are minds for if not for changing, he took the caretaker's post. He liked the job so much that he agreed a three-year contract. The mistress that is the England post is like that. With its needs rampant, Graham Taylor may once have called it the impossible job but few are the men, flattered by the attention, who can resist her. As he squires his biggest squeeze at Euro 2000, she will make unprecedented demands on the character and judgement formed by his career thus far. The real deal begins here. Typically of the English game, Kevin Keegan possesses no coaching qualifications. In Italy and Germany, those put in charge of the national team come through the ranks having been groomed and coached themselves. The France team that won the World Cup in 1998 was the product of a well-planned system, the now-Liverpool manager Gerard Houllier at its apex as technical director. The English game seemed to have learned, with Howard Wilkinson installed as Houllier's counterpart and a structure of development put in place. Keegan's appointment seems a regression, almost a panic measure as return to the knee-jerk responses of managers' departures. The advantages were that England were getting a popular figure with whom the supporters could identify, in contrast to the aloof Hoddle who finally appeared to have lost the mood of the country. 'Fans want to sing,' he once said about all-seater stadia, 'and unless you're Val Doonican, you can't do that sitting down.' In addition, his teams had a reputation for style. He mirrored, too, a nation's desire for passion play. 'He is like rocket fuel,' said an eccentric character by the name of Watt Nicholl, a sort of sports psychologist whom Keegan briefly invited into the England camp early on to cheer his players. Now had Hoddle employed such a figure The reservations have also concerned an occasionally touchy temperament, leading to fears that he could simply walk away if the going gets tough, since he is a rich enough man to do so having known his own worth; £750,000 a year with Fulham, £1m, including endorsements, with England. He resents both accusations, but just about resists a temptation to bristle when they are raised, knowing that to do so would only fuel them. He defies a critic to tell him when he has ever quit and has explanations aplenty for England after the World Cup of 1982 - he was dropped, simply saw which way the wind was blowing and announced his retirement from the international game - Newcastle in '97 - his power being diluted - and Fulham '99, which was said to be an amicable arrangement. Nevertheless, a spat with Sir Alex Ferguson has become one of those magic television moments. It was the run-in to the 1995-96 Championship and Manchester United were closing fast on Newcastle. Ferguson had riled Keegan with some of his trademark verbal psychology and Keegan was provoked into his 'I'd luv it if we beat them, absolutely luv it,' tirade in response. He risked his dignity, in the manner of Graham Taylor with his 'I'm waking up with my pyjamas soaking wet,' Channel 4 documentary but redeemed himself in one way. 'The day I stop being emotional about football is the day I'll be back in Spain playing golf,' Keegan subsequently said and the fans identified anew. On the other hand, the team had seen his strain. They were to crumble. He has also been ridiculed for some of his television remarks. 'England look the only side who can go on and win this,' he said shortly before Dan Petrescu's winner for Romania at France 98; David Batty will score, he insisted, moments before that penalty was saved against Argentina a fortnight later. 'You can't do better than a 0-0 draw away from home,' he once said. But at least he is decisive, willing to climb off the fence on which the apprehensive and cowardly sit. As someone remarked, it's not falling down that is the mistake, it is being frightened to get up once you have fallen. You ask him now about feeling any stress as England manager and how he might react to it in the summer and his face momentarily says 'Do I not like that question.' Then he rambles engagingly, ending characteristically on an upbeat note. 'I think I'll cope all right with it,' he says. 'I've got a good staff around me and we're well-organised for the tournament. We've crossed every 't' and dotted every 'i'. The downside is that if it doesn't go well, yes the flak will fly. But I also get the chance to do what no England manager has done: that is to win a major tournament away from this country.' It is significant that on his first full day in office he said that he wanted to emulate the boys of '66 and he has subsequently often referred to English football's touchstone moment; again in tune with the nation's sense of its own pride but naïve, and even potentially damaging with its lack of humility, about the national team's true standing these days. (His record, in truth, is no more than average: four wins from his first 11 games.) A comment by one of his former charges, Steve Howey, is revealing. 'It's impossible to dislike Kevin,' said the Newcastle centre-back, reminiscing about life under him at the club. 'You come in one morning feeling down but watching him whizz about brought you back to life. He wasn't really bothered about things like practising free-kicks but he made five-a-side feel like the World Cup.' While players might feel that he can be a jovial friend - and the way his own England career ended has led to him saying that he will be sensitively telling in person any player cut from the squad - they should not ignore a potential for ruthlessness. The story goes that he once went to scout a player and left after the pre-match warm-up because he didn't like the way the player ran. There have been signs lately that Keegan, in common with all his predecessors, has been irked by press comment, notably on the question of whether England would practise penalties this time. They would, he said, but not against Germany. However, the rider that this was because it was a group game and not knock-out was lost as he was made to look foolish. But back he soon came with a disarming way, that a charming Bobby Robson also possessed, of continuing to talk football with reporters because it so enthused him. Keegan also has the knack of making an interviewer feel valid so that he elicits understanding. He is honest, but with a tendency to people-please by giving the answer he thinks they want to hear. One week recently, for example, he said that Graeme Le Saux was definitely out of Euro 2000. A fortnight later he said he would take him if he could just play one end-of-season game. Le Saux himself, to whom Keegan did not speak for four months, knew that he was never going to be fit. 'I approach it in the same way you would if you had the job,' he said when asked about any trepidation he might feel this summer. 'You look at your squad and I think we have a really good squad. Yes you could argue that the balance could be better but every other manager or coach is thinking the same thing. We have got a mass of strikers and defenders but we don't have a lot of full-backs. No-one has perfection.' Therein lies the acid test. Keegan may indeed be a genial fellow but the job is about technical expertise and how he melds what he has at his disposal. On that, and consequent results, he should accept, and does, that he will be judged. 'My job is to try to get the players who can win a tournament for us into the side without it being a mish-mash,' he says. 'I'll probably be the first to admit in the past that it hasn't worked when I've experimented.' He was referring to Steve McManaman, who has proved himself over the last couple of months an outstanding creative influence on Real Madrid (see panel). Hearteningly, Keegan believes he can accommodate him now in the England team the way Terry Venables did during Euro '96 in more appropriate areas than simply being isolated wide on the left. Currently (and despite the 4-4-2 he played against Brazil) it seems quite possible that his team will line-up in 3-5-2 formation because it suits the players. He appears to have accepted that he can no longer fit square pegs in round holes. 'I'm not as cavalier as people make out,' he says now of his development. 'I do like winning and I know what it takes to win.' To do that, he will need also to be flexible enough to adapt should games need a change of approach. If he can, it will render redundant the caveats about no left-footed player of real note and concerns that England may revert to playing in straight lines, as they often did pre-Venables, rather than with the movement and adaptability they showed in Euro 96. If not, England may finally have to look to a coach of national gravitas - possibly foreign for the first time - rather than of clubbable personality. Unlike Hoddle, Keegan is a personality who likes to sit and eat with his players and regale them with stories, mainly of the Bill Shankly era. For the younger players, it might seem as 'now'as Tales from Hoffnung. It is to be hoped he also listens to the veterans of foreign fields like Adams and Shearer. 'Maybe a character like Kevin is what we need at the moment,' says Adams. 'When it comes to knowledge, I think there are enough of us able to share it with him.' After just over a year as manager, one thing Keegan has learned. 'Everything about the England job is magnified,' he observes of life in the goldfish bowl. Actually, it resembles more being on exhibition in some Damien Hirst tank. The summer will tell us whether the formaldehyde will be needed.

webTitle: 10 worst penalty misses of all time

fields.headline: 10 worst penalty misses of all time
fields.trailText: Paul Wilson, the Observer's football correspondent justifies his choice
fields.body:
1 Roberto Baggio, Italy v Brazil, Los Angeles 1994

The divine ponytail now seems unlikely to ever win a World Cup, so it will probably be his misfortune to be remembered for losing one. The stakes could hardly have been higher as Baggio the Buddhist stepped up. Not only had Claudio Taffarel just made a crucial save to put the onus of an entire World Cup on the next kick, he had dedicated it to his Christian God by pointing to the sky. Baggio's shot went in that direction, bringing a disappointing World Cup final to an abrupt but appropriate conclusion.

2 Joint award to Stuart Pearce, Chris Waddle, Gareth Southgate, Paul Ince and David Batty

Gazza cries and Pavarotti warbles once again as England wake up to how good they really are under Bobby Robson and push the West Germans all the way in a semi-final in Turin in 1990 at the Stadio delle Alpi. An expectant nation remains optimistic when the game goes to penalties, not yet realising what the next 10 years will hold, but we begin to get the picture when Pearce strikes the fourth penalty against Bodo Illgner's legs and Waddle balloons the fifth over the bar.

Six years later it's England against the whole of Germany in the Euro 96 semi-finals at Wembley. People were expecting England to lose on penalties this time, realising that Germany were unlikely to be as generous from the spot as Spain had been in the quarter-final, which was partly why Southgate's body language seemed to say 'Why me?' from the start. The Aston Villa defender was hoping he would not be required, but it fell to this extremely occasional striker to take the first sudden-death penalty when the initial phase finished 5-5. Southgate missed, or rather Andreas Kopke saved, and Germany had arranged matters so that their experienced captain Andy Moller was available to score from the next kick and book another final at England's expense.

Two years later it's Argentina at France 98, and after a thrilling game which England were unlucky not to win in normal time, the expectation was that the penalty shoot-out would end in tears. So it did, with penalty tyro Batty attracting more criticism than Ince, who was the first England player to miss. The plain truth is that England did not have enough penalty experts on the pitch at the end, partly due to David Beckham's infamous dismissal. But Glenn Hoddle's contention that this was the best prepared England World Cup side ever looked a little glib when it emerged that his squad had never practised taking penalties.

3 Didier Six and Maxime Bossis, France v West Germany, Seville, 1982

An earlier semi-final with the World Cup's first ever shoot-out and arguably its greatest miscarriage of justice. No real blame attaches to Six and Bossis for missing their kicks, the villain of the piece was Harald Schumacher, the German goalkeeper who saved them. Schumacher should have been dismissed minutes from the end of normal time for a vicious professional foul which denied France a winning goal and put Patrick Battiston in hospital. Incredibly he was not even penalised, and stayed on to see Germany through the shoot-out after coming back from 3-1 down in extra time. Small consolation for the glorious French side of Platini, Giresse and Tigana that Italy won the final, or that France won the European Championship two years later.

5 Victor Ikpeba, Nigeria v Cameroon, 2000

The miss that wasn't - and it cost Nigeria the African Nations Cup. One of the worst refereeing decisions ever witnessed (and the linesman was most to blame as he was standing on the byline) handed the cup to Cameroon, much to the dismay of a packed crowd in Lagos last February. After a 2-2 draw the game went to a shoot-out. With the score 3-2 to Cameroon Ikpeba, who plays for Borussia Dortmund, struck his shot against the underside of the bar. It clearly crossed the line by about a foot, but the Tunisian referee, Mourad Daami, said 'no goal'. The complaints on a BBC African website would take a tree to turn into print.

6 Liu Ying, USA v China, Los Angeles, 1999

The women's World Cup may still be some way from attracting the same interest as then men's (though not in America), but at least its finals can be decided the same way. The defining motif of the 1999 Women's World Cup was Brandi Chastain in her sports bra, shirt waved in triumph above her head, after burying the USA's fifth, and winning penalty. The goat of the piece was China's Liu Ying who had taken the third spot-kick for her country. The midfielder placed it to Briana Scurry's left but not far enough. The American keeper guessed right and palmed the ball away. For Team USA the only miss of the shoot-out made legends of them all. For Liu Ying from Beijing there were only tears.

7 John Aldridge, Liverpool v Wimbledon, Wembley 1988

Of all the FA Cup finals in which to miss a penalty, it had to be this one. As soon as one or two high-minded observers of the game expressed the view that it would be bad for football were the Crazy Gang to beat Anfield's Quality Street collection in such a major showpiece, Wimbledon seemed fated to defy the odds and accomplish the unthinkable. Never more so than when Dave 'Lurch' Beasant saved Aldridge's penalty to preserve the lead Lawrie Sanchez had given the underdogs, who went on to win 1-0. 'No complaints,' said Liverpool manager Kenny Dalglish. 'I thought it was a soft penalty award anyway.'

8 Dennis Bergkamp, Arsenal v Manchester United, Villa Park 1999

This was the penalty which could have put Arsenal into a second successive FA Cup final and stopped Manchester United's Treble in its tracks. Still slugging it out with United in the League, Arsenal had held them to a draw in the first FA Cup semi-final, and appeared to have the replay sewn up when their opponents first lost Roy Keane and then conceded a penalty in injury time. Peter Schmeichel was equal to Bergkamp's kick, however, allowing Ryan Giggs to supply the extra time heroics and United to reach for glory.

9 Billy Austin, Manchester City v Newcastle United, 1926

On the last day of the 1925-26 season Manchester City went to Newcastle needing a point to avoid relegation from the First Division. A run of four consecutive wins suggested they would do so. They were awarded a penalty, only for outside-right Billy Austin to miss it. It proved a crucial error: Newcastle won 3-2 and City went down. It had been a bad week for them. A week earlier Bolton had beaten them in the FA Cup final.

10 Any penalty taken by the Corinthians The famous amateur side used to miss penalties on purpose, or tap the ball lightly back to the goalkeeper, believing that as all foul play was accidental it would be unsporting to take an unfair advantage from the penalty spot. Any resemblance between this archaic philosophy and Manchester City's penalty record is entirely coincidental, apparently.

Justifying his selection

This month's 10 were selected by Paul Wilson, The Observer's football correspondent. Here he explains his choice:

The list may be dominated by penalty shoot-outs, and fairly recent history, but that's just the way the game is these days. Doubtless there were nervous penalties and significant misses before the artificial drama of the shoot-out, though it takes a real effort to call many to mind now that the images and their like have set up permanent home in the collective subconscious.

How dramatic can an open-play penalty be in any case? The ultimate scenario would be a penalty award in the last minute of a Cup final with the scores level, but if scored the match is won and if missed the game simply goes on. John Aldridge was the first player to miss a penalty in an FA Cup final, but had he scored there is no guarantee Wimbledon would not have grabbed a winner in extra time. Dennis Bergkamp's miss in injury time in an FA Cup semi-final was arguably the most significant open play penalty drama in recent memory, since had he been successful Manchester United would surely have been denied their Treble.

Penalty shoot-outs by definition are more climactic, and the price of failure is usually instant elimination from a World Cup or a major tournament, which is why they make such compulsive viewing and why we remember them so vividly. This is a necessarily personal selection, drawn many from games I was lucky enough to attend, with a handful of important milestones thrown in. There may have been more abysmal shooting performances from the spot - the 28 penalty marathon between Hong Kong and North Korea in 1975 which lasted almost as long as the match itself springs to mind.

Shoot-outs are cruel because they are lost rather than won, and once the finger of failure points the stigma can last for years, but if two teams are still neck and neck after two hours of open play it is generally going to take something arbitrary to divide them and shoot-outs at least have the advantage of being decisive and highly watchable. We all love them really.

Now you have your say

Enraged by our choice? Unable to contain your ire at our stupidity? We thought so, and we want to hear from you. Write and tell us who your 10 would be, justifying your selection in no more than 50 words. A selection of your 10s will be published next month.

Send your cards to: 10 Worst Penalties, OSM, Observer Sports desk, 119 Farringdon Rd, London EC1R 3ER or email us at osm@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Mandolin man plays a new tune as film crew moves in

fields.headline: Mandolin man plays a new tune as film crew moves in
fields.standfirst:
Corelli author admits 'I could be wrong' in dispute over book's accuracy, reports Helena Smith in Cephalonia
De Bernières on the resistance
fields.trailText: The bestselling story of Greece's bitter struggle against Italian occupation during World War Two, Captain Corelli's Mandolin, has become embroiled in controversy even as filming of the book gets under way on its island setting of Cephalonia.
fields.body:
The bestselling story of Greece's bitter struggle against Italian occupation during World War Two, Captain Corelli's Mandolin, has become embroiled in controversy even as filming of the book gets under way on its island setting of Cephalonia.

Makers of the film, which stars Nicolas Cage, Penelope Cruz and John Hurt, have had to persuade anxious islanders that the blockbuster will be a love story, and will not reopen old wounds by concentrating on the brutal anti-fascist struggle and ensuing civil war.

Now the book's author, Louis de Bernières, has conceded that changes have been made to the Greek edition of the book because of fierce criticism of its portrayal of communist atrocities.

And, after accusations that he distorted history to portray the country's leftist partisans as 'dehumanised sadists', the author says he 'might be wrong'.

'After the writing of Corelli it became clear to me that many people were genuinely offended by the portrayal of the Communist Resistance, or simply thought that it was inaccurate,' de Bernières wrote yesterday in an email sent to The Observer. 'I haven't actually changed my mind about what I think is the truth, but I had to bear in mind the possibility that I might be wrong.'

The book describes a love triangle between a member of Greece's communist Resistance movement, an officer in the Italian occupying force on Cephalonia, and Pelagia, the beautiful daughter of the local doctor. It includes accounts of communist atrocities against their right-wing foes during the civil war that followed Italy's occupation.

Only last year the soldier-turned-writer issued a blistering assault on the tiny circulation Morning Star for accusing him of promoting crude anti-communism in the book. 'How long are you people going to sit in the dark in an air pocket, wanking each other off? Your ship has sunk, brothers. It was historically inevitable and just now the historical conditions have been fulfilled. Goodbye to the biggest failure and disappointment since the non-return of Christ,' he wrote.

Now his views appear to have mellowed. Yesterday he said: 'The story of the Resistance is extremely complex, and whereas the communists massacred entire villages in some places, I understand that in others they set up drama classes.'

De Bernières's account of the changes he has made to the Greek version of his book mirrors the efforts British film-makers have made to reassure the citizens of Cephalonia (also known as Kephalonia) about their plans. One prominent politician conceded that many did not want the book filmed on the island at all. 'There was a lot of under-the-table negotiations to have the film take place on Cephalonia,' said Gerassimos Apostolatos, a distinguished former Conservative MP from the island.

'All over our island there were cases of real-life Corellis and Pelagias, but the book is also full of things that really offend,' said Gerassimos Artelanis, mayor of Sami where much of the movie is being filmed. 'So we set up a committee of historians working alongside all the island's mayors and decided the British film company would have to confirm that what they were making was a love story and not a political story... because you know not even we Greeks have decided who was right and wrong during the civil war. It's still a bitter thing.'

The British film-makers confirm the delicacy of their negotiations. 'It is true the local prefect asked us for assurances that the film would not touch on Greece's brutal civil war,' said Kevin Loader, one of three British producers. 'We had no problem doing that because it was always going to be a love story and nothing else,' added Loader, whose London-based Working Title Films counts Four Weddings and a Funeral among its box-office draws.

De Bernières said yesterday: 'It was never part of the purpose of Corelli to stir up bad blood. Corelli is about other themes, and I wouldn't want the book to be distorted for Greek readers, which is why I agreed with my publishers and translator that some of my language and opinions should be moderated. The Greeks don't need some foreigner sticking his oar in when they can, and do, perfectly well argue among themselves.'

Although the author says 'nothing was actually cut', the novel was amended to placate a potentially hostile audience prior to its publication in Greece in 1995.

Several offending passages have been excised altogether. Greek readers who turn to chapter 63, for instance, are not told that 'the communists began to deport awkward characters to concentration camps; from a safe distance they had watched the Nazis for years, and were well-versed in all the arts of atrocity and oppression.' They do not read that 'Hitler would have been proud of such assiduous pupils'.

Nor do they see the author's note, which was published in the early English language editions of the book and appears in other foreign editions. It is in the note that de Bernières berates the 'disconnected intellectual' who has traditionally tried 'to maintain that the Greek communists were romantic heroes who were unjustly oppressed by the imperialist and duplicitous British, in order to restore the monarchy against the will of the people'.

'I have tried to be as true to history as possible,' he writes. 'I have been unable to conclude otherwise than that, when they were not totally useless, perfidious and parasitic, they were unspeakably barbaric.' With such snippets removed, the novel was initially well received in Greece where one critic wrote that a 'Greek could not have written better'.

Over 25,000 copies have been sold since Psichogios, the Athenean publishing house, first printed it in 1995. It is now being flagged as a 'Hymn to our Homeland'.

In the giant film-set that is Sami, the word is out that the British author may soon be visiting. Those thankful for the book's impact on local tourism have already implored the mayor to make him an honorary citizen. 'But you know,' said Mayor Artelanis, 'what I would really like to ask him is where he got all his information from. If they turn it into a political film, then we will take measures.'

'You can be sure that we will take the issue to the international court of justice at the Hague. We will fight it all the way. For us Captain Corelli must be what it is very good at - a love story from beginning to end.'

The low-down on the Captain

Author: Louis de Bernières

First published: 1994

Pages: 434

Price: £6.99 (Vintage pb)

Position in bestseller list: 92nd

Weeks in list: 234

Copies sold: 1.5 million

Number of final chapters: two - de Bernières added a final final chapter in 1998

Plot: Italians occupy Greek island of Cephalonia during Second World War. Doctor's daughter and fisherman lover support local resistance. Enter Captain Corelli (with mandolin) to organise occupation. Captain falls in love with doctor's daughter. Savage war brings invaders and defenders together. Mandolin gets lost. War ends. Captain leaves. Not going to tell you the rest.

fields.headline: Caught it on the grapevine
fields.standfirst: The world's vineyards are at the mercy of destructive insect-borne plagues
fields.trailText: The world's vineyards are at the mercy of destructive insect-borne plagues.
fields.body:
Black goo sounds like something out of a twopenny horror film: two parts Quatermass to one part Night of the Living Dead. ('When we found the body, officer, it was covered in this horrible slime. The guy had been Tarmacked.') Horrible it is, but only if you're a grape-grower in California, where black goo is causing significant damage in young vineyards, stunting vines and reducing yields. As I write, nurseries and producers are exchanging attorneys' letters to establish blame.

This is serious enough, but things could get worse for the wine industry. Far, far worse. Over the next decade, two little-known vineyard maladies - grapevine yellows (or flavescence dorée , as the French call it) and Pierce's disease - could make black goo look like a stubbed toe. At least one prominent vineyard consultant thinks that this nasty pair could be more devastating than phylloxera, the aphid which wiped out most of Europe's vineyards in the 19th century.

It took more than a decade to find a cure for phylloxera - the 750 suggested remedies included ashes, acids, horse urine and sealing wax. Eventually they discovered that the only solution was to graft European vines on to phylloxera-resistant American rootstocks. This is still the case today. There are some countries which are largely free of the aphid (eg, Australia and Chile), but even here, few people are willing to take the risk of planting ungrafted vines.

Grapevine yellows and Pierce's disease, however, are incurable. Both can be contained with insecticides (to reduce the populations of the insects that carry them), but once they're established, the only real solution is to pull out your vines and start again. Pierce's disease kills vines faster than grapevine yellows, but the end result is the same.

Pierce's disease is restricted to certain parts of America at the moment, but the disease is on the move, as its vector is innocently transported on plants and agricultural machinery. In its path stand the prime vineyards of northern California. Having just recovered from Phylloxera B, a mutation that attacked AXR1, the rootstock used by most of the state's wine industry, the West Coast is facing disaster once more. The American disease, grapevine yellows, is now established in France, Germany, Italy, Switzerland and Australia, but as yet no one seems concerned about it, partly because its effects are not fully understood.

The Aussie viticulturist Richard Smart, who has been watching the spread of grapevine yellows with mounting alarm, says: 'Ignorance, or perhaps denial, allows people to remain in a comfort zone. There are definitely similarities with what happened with phylloxera.'

Is there a positive side to all this? You could argue that they will reduce the surpluses threatening the wine business, but that would be a bit extreme. It's a shame the diseases can't be trained to target crap or overproduced vineyards.
